好像是为了加深我们对Villismo的感觉，我的父母还教了我们墨西哥革命最著名的两首歌曲“Adelita”和“Se llevaron el cañón para Bachimba” （“他们把大炮带到了 Bachimba”）。大约二十年后（在哈佛法学院任职期间），当我沿着查尔斯河漫步时，我会发现自己轻声唱着“Se Llevaron el cañón para Bachimba, para Bachimba, para Bachimba”一遍又一遍地。这就是我对那首凄美的反叛歌曲的全部记忆。虽然我是在那里出生的，但我一直认为“Bachimba”是一个虚构的、虚构的、类似于 Lewis Carroll 的名字。所以八年前，当我第一次回到墨西哥时，当我来到奇瓦瓦以南的一个十字路口时，看到一个古老的路标：“Bachimba 18km”，我简直惊呆了。那它就真的存在了——我在心里呐喊——巴钦巴是一个真正的小镇！摇摇晃晃地走上狭窄、铺设不佳的道路，我发动马达，飞速驶向我从小就唱过的小镇。

As if to deepen our sense of Villismo, my parents also taught us “Adelita” and “Se llevaron el cañón para Bachimba” (“They took the cannon to Bachimba”), the two most famous songs of the Mexican revolution. Some twenty years later (during my stint at Harvard Law School), while strolling along the Charles River, I would find myself softly singing “Se Llevaron el cañón para Bachimba, para Bachimba, para Bachimba” over and over again. That’s all I could remember of that poignant rebel song. Though I had been born there, I had always regarded “Bachimba” as a fictitious, made-up, Lewis Carroll kind of name. So that eight years ago, when I first returned to Mexico, I was literally stunned when I came to a crossroad south of Chihuahua and saw an old road marker: “Bachimba 18km.” Then it really exists—I shouted inwardly—Bachimba is a real town! Swinging onto the narrow, poorly paved road, I gunned the motor and sped toward the town I’d been singing about since infancy.

对于加州斯托克顿的中国移民女儿 Maxine Hong Kingston 来说，害羞和尴尬是孩子在异国他乡开始上学的主要体验。在她的《女战士》一书中恰当地称为“寻找声音”的这段话中，请注意金斯顿如何生动地回忆起美国早年那些创伤性的事实和感受：

For Maxine Hong Kingston, a daughter of Chinese immigrants in Stockton, California, shyness and embarrassment were central to the experience of being a child starting school in a strange land. In this passage, aptly called “Finding a Voice,” from her book The Woman Warrior, notice how vividly Kingston recalls both facts and feelings from those traumatic early years in America:

当我上幼儿园第一次说英语时，我变得沉默了。哑巴——一种耻辱——仍然把我的声音分成两半，即使我想随便说声“你好”，或者在结账柜台前问一个简单的问题，或者向公交车司机问路。我冻僵了....

When I went to kindergarten and had to speak English for the first time, I became silent. A dumbness—a shame—still cracks my voice in two, even when I want to say “hello” casually, or ask an easy question in front of the check-out counter, or ask directions of a bus driver. I stand frozen....

在沉默的第一年里，我在学校没有和任何人说话，上厕所前没有问过，结果幼儿园没及格。姐姐也三年没说话，操场上沉默，午饭时沉默。还有其他不属于我们家的安静的中国女孩，但她们中的大多数比我们更快地克服了它。我很享受这种沉默。起初我并没有想到我应该会说话或通过幼儿园。我在家里和课堂上的一两个中国孩子交谈过。我做了一些动作，甚至开了一些玩笑。当水从杯子里溢出时，我用玩具碟子喝了水，每个人都笑了，指着我，所以我又做了一些。我不知道美国人不喝碟子......

During the first silent year I spoke to no one at school, did not ask before going to the lavatory, and flunked kindergarten. My sister also said nothing for three years, silent in the playground and silent at lunch. There were other quiet Chinese girls not of our family, but most of them got over it sooner than we did. I enjoyed the silence. At first it did not occur to me I was supposed to talk or to pass kindergarten. I talked at home and to one or two of the Chinese kids in class. I made motions and even made some jokes. I drank out of a toy saucer when the water spilled out of the cup, and everybody laughed, pointed at me, so I did it some more. I didn’t know that Americans don’t drink out of saucers....

当我发现我不得不说话时，学校变成了一种痛苦，沉默变成了一种痛苦。我没有说话，每次我不说话都感觉很糟糕。不过，我在一年级时大声朗读，听到从我喉咙里发出的最轻微的吱吱声。“大点声，”老师说，又把声音吓跑了。其他中国女孩也不说话，所以我知道沉默与中国女孩有关。

It was when I found out I had to talk that school became a misery, that the silence became a misery. I did not speak and felt bad each time that I did not speak. I read aloud in first grade, though, and heard the barest whisper with little squeaks come out of my throat. “Louder,” said the teacher, who scared the voice away again. The other Chinese girls did not talk either, so I knew the silence had to do with being a Chinese girl.

童年的窃窃私语现在已成为成年作家的声音，以智慧和幽默向我们诉说，我很高兴能在我们中间听到这种声音。除了一位华裔美国女性，没有人能让我感受到身为一名中国女孩在美国幼儿园安顿下来并期望成为一名美国女孩的感觉。回忆录是理解文化差异的一种方式，文化差异可能是当今美国日常生活中一个痛苦的事实。想想刘易斯·P·约翰逊 (Lewis P. Johnson) 在下面的文章“为了我的印第安女儿”中所描述的对身份的追求。约翰逊在密歇根长大，是最后一位公认的 Potawatomi Ottawas 酋长的曾孙：

That childhood whisper is now an adult writer’s voice that speaks to us with wisdom and humor, and I’m grateful to have that voice in our midst. Nobody but a Chinese-American woman could have made me feel what it’s like to be a Chinese girl plunked down in an American kindergarten and expected to be an American girl. Memoir is one way to make sense of the cultural differences that can be a painful fact of daily life in America today. Consider the quest for identity described by Lewis P. Johnson in the following essay, “For My Indian Daughter.” Johnson, who grew up in Michigan, is a great-grandson of the last recognized chief of the Potawatomi Ottawas:

有一天，在我 35 岁左右的时候，我听说了一场印度教仪式。我父亲曾经参加过他们，因此怀着极大的好奇心和发现我的一部分遗产的奇怪喜悦，我决定为这次盛会做准备的事情就是让我的朋友在他的锻造厂里为我做一把长矛。钢很细，呈蓝色，呈虹彩状。轴上的羽毛明亮而自豪。

One day when I was 35 or thereabouts I heard about an Indian powwow. My father used to attend them and so with great curiosity and a strange joy at discovering a part of my heritage, I decided the thing to do to get ready for the big event was to have my friend make me a spear in his forge. The steel was fine and blue and iridescent. The feathers on the shaft were bright and proud.

在印第安纳州南部一个尘土飞扬的州集市上，我发现白人打扮成印第安人。我了解到他们是“业余爱好者”，也就是说，周末假扮成印度人是他们的业余爱好和消遣。我觉得我的矛很可笑，我就离开了。

In a dusty state fairground in southern Indiana, I found white people dressed as Indians. I learned they were “hobbyists,” that is, it was their hobby and leisure pastime to masquerade as Indians on weekends. I felt ridiculous with my spear, and I left.

过了很多年，我才可以告诉任何人这个周末的尴尬，并从中看出任何幽默。但在某种程度上，就是那个周末，尽管它很平静，但那是我的觉醒。我意识到我不知道我是谁。我没有印度名字。我不会说印度语。我不知道印度的习俗。我模糊地记得渥太华的狗这个词，但它是一个婴儿词，kahgee ，而不是我后来才知道的完整词muhkahgee 。更模糊的是，我想起了一个命名仪式（我自己的）。我记得双腿在我身边舞动，尘土飞扬。那是什么地方？我是谁？“Suwaukquat，”当我问起时，妈妈告诉我，“树开始生长的地方。”

It was years before I could tell anyone of the embarrassment of this weekend and see any humor in it. But in a way it was that weekend, for all its stillness, that was my awakening. I realized I didn’t know who I was. I didn’t have an Indian name. I didn’t speak the Indian language. I didn’t know the Indian customs. Dimly I remembered the Ottawa word for dog, but it was a baby word, kahgee, not the full word, muhkahgee, which I was later to learn. Even more hazily I remembered a naming ceremony (my own). I remembered legs dancing around me, dust. Where had that been? Who had I been? “Suwaukquat,” my mother told me when I asked, “where the tree begins to grow.”

那是 1968 年，我不是这个国家唯一感到需要记住自己是谁的印度人。还有其他人。他们有 powwows，真实的，最终我找到了他们。我们一起研究了我们的过去，对我来说，这次探索在 1978 年华盛顿最长的步行中达到了顶峰。也许是因为我现在知道身为印度人意味着什么，令我惊讶的是其他人却不知道。当然，我们剩下的人不多了。普通人在平均一生中认识普通印度人的机会非常渺茫。

That was 1968, and I was not the only Indian in the country who was feeling the need to remember who he or she was. There were others. They had powwows, real ones, and eventually I found them. Together we researched our past, a search that for me culminated in the Longest Walk, a march on Washington in 1978. Maybe because I now know what it means to be Indian, it surprises me that others don’t. Of course there aren’t very many of us left. The chances of an average person knowing an average Indian in an average lifetime are pretty slim.

回忆录的关键要素当然是人。声音、气味、歌曲和睡觉的门廊将带您到此为止。最后，你必须召回那些在你生命中显着走过的男人、女人和孩子。是什么让他们难忘——什么样的想法，什么样的疯狂习惯？约翰·莫蒂默的父亲是一名盲人大律师，来自回忆录广阔的鸟舍，这是一只典型的怪鸟，正如他儿子在《紧贴残骸》中所回忆的那样，这部回忆录既温柔又滑稽。莫蒂默本人是一名律师，也是一位多产的作家和剧作家，最著名的作品是《贝利河边的浪坡》，写道当他的父亲失明时，他“坚持继续他的法律实践，就好像什么都没发生过一样”，而他的母亲也因此成为了为他朗读他的案情摘要并为他的案件做笔记的人。

The crucial ingredient in memoir is, of course, people. Sounds and smells and songs and sleeping porches will take you just so far. Finally you must summon back the men and women and children who notably crossed your life. What was it that made them memorable—what turn of mind, what crazy habits? A typical odd bird from memoir’s vast aviary is John Mortimer’s father, a blind barrister, as recalled by the son in Clinging to the Wreckage, a memoir that manages the feat of being both tender and hilarious. Mortimer, a lawyer himself and a prolific author and playwright, best known for Rumpole of the Bailey, writes that when his father became blind he “insisted on continuing with his legal practice as though nothing had happened” and that his mother thereupon became the person who would read his briefs to him and make notes on his cases.

她成为法庭上的知名人物，众所周知的 Tipstaff 或首席大法官勋爵，带领我父亲从一个法庭到另一个法庭，当他用他那根浑浊的马六甲手杖敲打铺砌的地板时耐心地微笑，并大声辱骂任何一个她或他的指示律师，或同时向他们两人。从战争早期开始，当他们在乡下永久定居时，我母亲每天开车送我父亲 14 英里到亨利车站，然后坐火车接他。坐在角落的座位上，穿得像温斯顿·丘吉尔，黑色夹克和条纹裤子，领结搭配翼领，靴子和长靴，我父亲会要求她用响亮而清晰的声音朗读文件中的证据离婚案件将是他一天的工作。当火车在梅登黑德附近停下时，头等车厢会安静下来，因为我的母亲正在宣读私家侦探关于他们详细观察到的通奸行为的报告。如果她压低声音描述弄脏的床单、四处散落的男女衣物或汽车内的不当行为，我父亲就会大声喊道：“说出来，凯丝！” 他们的旅伴将享受另一部激动人心的作品。

She became a well-known figure in the Law Courts, as well known as the Tipstaff or the Lord Chief Justice, leading my father from Court to Court, smiling patiently as he tapped the paved floors with his clouded malacca cane and shouted abuse either at her or at his instructing solicitor, or at both of them at the same time. From early in the war, when they settled permanently in the country, my mother drove my father fourteen miles a day to Henley Station and took him up in the train. Ensconced in a corner seat, dressed like Winston Churchill, in a black jacket and striped trousers, bow-tie worn with a wing-collar, boots and spats, my father would require her to read in a loud and clear voice the evidence in the divorce case that would be his day’s work. As the train ground to a halt around Maidenhead the first-class carriage would fall silent as my mother read out the reports of Private Investigators on adulterous behavior which they had observed in detail. If she dropped her voice over descriptions of stained bed-linen, male and female clothing found scattered about, or misconduct in motor cars, my father would call out, “Speak up, Kath!” and their fellow travelers would be treated to another thrilling installment.

但我们希望，回忆录中最有趣的人物将是写这本书的人。那个男人或女人从生活的高山低谷中学到了什么？弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫热衷于使用高度个人化的形式——回忆录、期刊、日记、信件——来阐明她的思想和情感。（我们有多少次出于义务开始写信，却在第三段才发现我们真的有话要对收信人说。）其他女人与类似的天使和恶魔搏斗。肯尼迪·弗雷泽 (Kennedy Fraser) 在对一本关于伍尔夫 (Woolf) 受虐少女时代的书进行评论时承认欠债，她以自己的回忆录开头，以其诚实和脆弱吸引了我们的注意力：

But the most interesting character in a memoir, we hope, will turn out to be the person who wrote it. What did that man or woman learn from the hills and valleys of life? Virginia Woolf was an avid user of highly personal forms—memoirs, journals, diaries, letters—to clarify her thoughts and emotions. (How often we start writing a letter out of obligation and only discover in the third paragraph that we have something we really want to say to the person we’re writing to.) What Virginia Woolf intimately wrote during her lifetime has been immensely helpful to other women wrestling with similar angels and demons. Acknowledging that debt in a review of a book about Woolf’s abused girlhood, Kennedy Fraser begins with a memoir of her own that seizes our attention with its honesty and vulnerability:

曾经有一段时间，我的生活对我来说是如此痛苦，以至于阅读其他女作家的生活是为数不多的可以提供帮助的事情之一。我很不高兴，并为此感到羞愧。我对自己的生活感到困惑。在我三十出头的几年里，我会坐在扶手椅上阅读关于这些其他生活的书籍。有时读到最后，我会坐下来从头开始读一遍。我记得这一切令人难以置信的紧张，还有一种鬼鬼祟祟的感觉——好像我害怕有人会透过窗户看到我。即使是现在，我也觉得我应该假装我只读这些女性的小说或诗歌——她们选择呈现的生活，炼金术般的艺术。但那将是一个谎言。我真正喜欢的是私人信息——日记和信件，以及自传和传记，只要他们似乎在说实话。那时我感到非常孤独，自我陶醉，与世隔绝。我需要所有这些低声的合唱，这些真实生活故事的连续体，来帮助我度过难关。对我来说，她们就像母亲和姐妹一样，这些文学女性，其中许多人已经去世；不仅仅是我自己的家人，他们似乎伸出了一只手。我年轻时来到纽约，就像很多人一样，为了创造自己。而且，像许多现代人——尤其是现代女性——一样，我跳出了我的背景……[作家的] 成功当然给了我希望，但我最喜欢的是那些绝望的片段。我正在寻找方向，收集线索。我特别感谢这些女人的秘密、可耻的事情——痛苦：堕胎和错误的婚姻，她们吃的药，他们喝的量。又是什么让她们以女同性恋的身份生活，或爱上男同性恋者，或有妻室的男人？

There was a time when my life seemed so painful to me that reading about the lives of other women writers was one of the few things that could help. I was unhappy, and ashamed of it; I was baffled by my life. For several years in my early thirties, I would sit in my armchair reading books about these other lives. Sometimes when I came to the end, I would sit down and read the book through from the beginning again. I remember an incredible intensity about all this, and also a kind of furtiveness—as if I were afraid that someone might look through the window and find me out. Even now, I feel I should pretend that I was reading only these women’s fiction or their poetry—their lives as they chose to present them, alchemized as art. But that would be a lie. It was the private messages I really liked—the journals and letters, and autobiographies and biographies whenever they seemed to be telling the truth. I felt very lonely then, self absorbed, shut off. I needed all this murmured chorus, this continuum of true-life stories, to pull me through. They were like mothers and sisters to me, these literary women, many of them already dead; more than my own family, they seemed to stretch out a hand. I had come to New York when I was young, as so many come, in order to invent myself. And, like many modern people—modern women, especially—I had catapulted out of my context.... The successes [of the writers] gave me hope, of course, yet it was the desperate bits I liked best. I was looking for directions, gathering clues. I was especially grateful for the secret, shameful things about these women—the pain: the abortions and misalliances, the pills they took, the amount they drank. And what had made them live as lesbians, or fall in love with homosexual men, or men with wives?

当你写下个人历史时，最好的礼物就是你自己。允许自己写关于自己的文章，并乐在其中。

The best gift you have to offer when you write personal history is the gift of yourself. Give yourself permission to write about yourself, and have a good time doing it.

15

15

科学和技术

Science and Technology

在一所文理学院找一门写作课的学生，让他们写一些科学方面的文章，教室里就会响起一阵可怜的呻吟声。“不！不科学！” 呻吟声说。学生们有一个共同的苦恼：对科学的恐惧。他们在很小的时候就被化学或物理老师告知，他们没有“科学头脑”。

Take a class of writing students in a liberal arts college and assign them to write about some aspect of science, and a pitiful moan will go around the room. “No! Not science!” the moan says. The students have a common affliction: fear of science. They were told at an early age by a chemistry or a physics teacher that they don’t have “a head for science.”

找一位成年化学家、物理学家或工程师请他或她写一份报告，你会看到近乎恐慌的东西。“不！别逼我们写！” 他们说。他们还有一个共同的苦恼：害怕写作。一位英语老师在他们很小的时候就告诉他们，他们没有“文字天赋”。

Take an adult chemist or physicist or engineer and ask him or her to write a report, and you’ll see something close to panic. “No! Don’t make us write!” they say. They also have a common affliction: fear of writing. They were told at an early age by an English teacher that they don’t have “a gift for words.”

两者都是生活中不必要的恐惧，在本章中，我想帮助您缓解您的恐惧。本章基于一个简单的原则：写作不是英语老师拥有的特殊语言。写作是在纸上思考。任何想清楚的人都可以清楚地写下任何事情。揭开神秘面纱的科学只是另一个非小说类主题。揭开神秘面纱的写作只是科学家传播他们所知道的东西的另一种方式。

Both are unnecessary fears to lug through life, and in this chapter I’d like to help you ease whichever one is yours. The chapter is based on a simple principle: writing is not a special language owned by the English teacher. Writing is thinking on paper. Anyone who thinks clearly can write clearly, about anything at all. Science, demystified, is just another nonfiction subject. Writing, demystified, is just another way for scientists to transmit what they know.

在这两种恐惧中，我的一直是对科学的恐惧。我曾经不及格一门由一位女士教授的化学课程，她已成为拥有三代学生的传奇人物，传说她可以教任何人化学。即使在今天，我也不比詹姆斯·瑟伯的祖母走得更远，正如他在《我的生活》和《艰难岁月》中回忆起她的那样，她认为墙上的插座“电流无形地滴落到整个房子”。但作为一名作家，我了解到外行人也可以接触到科学和技术材料。这只是一个接一个句子的问题。然而，“之后”是至关重要的。在其他任何地方，您都不必如此努力地编写构成线性序列的句子。这不是幻想的飞跃或隐含的真理的地方。事实和演绎是统治家庭。

Of the two fears, mine has been fear of science. I once flunked a chemistry course taught by a woman who had become a legend with three generations of students, the legend being she could teach chemistry to anybody. Even today I’m not much farther along than James Thurber’s grandmother, who, as he recalled her in My Life and Hard Times, thought “electricity was dripping invisibly all over the house” from wall sockets. But as a writer I’ve learned that scientific and technical material can be made accessible to the layman. It’s just a matter of putting one sentence after another. The “after,” however, is crucial. Nowhere else must you work so hard to write sentences that form a linear sequence. This is no place for fanciful leaps or implied truths. Fact and deduction are the ruling family.

我给学生的科学作业很简单。我只是让他们描述一些东西是如何工作的。我不在乎风格或任何其他优雅。我只想让他们告诉我，比方说，缝纫机是如何工作的，或者泵是如何工作的，或者苹果为什么会掉下来，或者眼睛如何告诉大脑它看到了什么。任何过程都可以，“科学”可以宽泛地定义为包括技术、医学和自然。

The science assignment that I give to students is a simple one. I just ask them to describe how something works. I don’t care about style or any other graces. I only want them to tell me, say, how a sewing machine does what it does, or how a pump operates, or why an apple falls down, or how the eye tells the brain what it sees. Any process will do, and “science” can be defined loosely to include technology, medicine and nature.

新闻业的一个原则是“读者一无所知”。就信条而言，这并不讨人喜欢，但技术作家永远不会忘记它。你不能假设你的读者知道你假设每个人都知道的东西，或者他们仍然记得曾经向他们解释过的东西。经过数百次演示后，我仍然不确定我是否能穿上航空公司空乘人员给我看的救生衣：“简单地”将我的手臂穿过带子，“简单地”向下拉两个切换旋钮（或它是横向的吗？）并“简单地”将其炸毁——但不会太快。我有信心我能做的唯一一步就是过早地把它炸毁。

A tenet of journalism is that “the reader knows nothing.” As tenets go, it’s not flattering, but a technical writer can never forget it. You can’t assume that your readers know what you assume everybody knows, or that they still remember what was once explained to them. After hundreds of demonstrations I’m still not sure I could get into one of those life jackets that airline flight attendants have shown me: something about “simply” putting my arms through the straps, “simply” pulling two toggle knobs sharply downward (or is it sideways?) and “simply” blowing it up—but not too soon. The only step I’m confident I could perform is to blow it up too soon.

出于两个原因，描述流程如何工作很有价值。它迫使你确保你知道它是如何工作的。然后，它会迫使你让读者通过相同的想法和推论顺序，让你清楚地了解这个过程。我发现这对许多思维混乱的学生来说是一个突破口。其中一位聪明的耶鲁二年级学生在期中考试时仍然在页面上写满了模糊的概括，他兴高采烈地来到课堂上，问他是否可以阅读他关于灭火器工作原理的论文。我确信我们会陷入混乱。但他的作品以简单和逻辑移动。它清楚地解释了三种不同的灭火器如何扑灭三种不同的火灾。我为他一夜之间变成一个学会按顺序写作的作家而感到高兴，他也是。到大三结束时，他写了一本比我读过的任何书都畅销的指南书写。

Describing how a process works is valuable for two reasons. It forces you to make sure you know how it works. Then it forces you to take the reader through the same sequence of ideas and deductions that made the process clear to you. I’ve found it to be a breakthrough for many students whose thinking was disorderly. One of them, a bright Yale sophomore still spraying the page with fuzzy generalities at midterm, came to class in a high mood and asked if he could read his paper on how a fire extinguisher works. I was sure we were in for chaos. But his piece moved with simplicity and logic. It clearly explained how three different kinds of fires are attacked by three different kinds of fire extinguishers. I was elated by his overnight change into a writer who had learned to write sequentially, and so was he. By the end of his junior year he had written a how-to book that sold better than any book I had written.

许多其他模糊的学生尝试了同样的治疗方法，并且从那时起就写得很清楚了。尝试一下。因为科学和技术写作的原则适用于所有非虚构写作。这是引导一无所知的读者逐步掌握他们认为自己没有能力或害怕自己太笨而无法理解的主题的原则。

Many other fuzzy students tried the same cure and have written with clarity ever since. Try it. For the principle of scientific and technical writing applies to all nonfiction writing. It’s the principle of leading readers who know nothing, step by step, to a grasp of subjects they didn’t think they had an aptitude for or were afraid they were too dumb to understand.

将科学写作想象成一个倒置的金字塔。从底部开始，读者必须知道一个事实才能继续学习。第二句扩展了第一个陈述的内容，使金字塔变得更宽，第三句扩展了第二句，这样你就可以逐渐超越事实，进入意义和推测——一个新发现如何改变已知的东西，它有哪些新的研究途径可能会开放，研究可能会应用到哪里。金字塔的宽度是没有限制的，但是你的读者只有从一个狭隘的事实开始，才会理解其广泛的含义。

Imagine science writing as an upside-down pyramid. Start at the bottom with the one fact a reader must know before he can learn any more. The second sentence broadens what was stated first, making the pyramid wider, and the third sentence broadens the second, so that you can gradually move beyond fact into significance and speculation—how a new discovery alters what was known, what new avenues of research it might open, where the research might be applied. There’s no limit to how wide the pyramid can become, but your readers will understand the broad implications only if they start with one narrow fact.

一个很好的例子是 Harold M. Schmeck, Jr. 的一篇文章，该文章刊登在纽约时报的第一页上。

A good example is an article by Harold M. Schmeck, Jr., which ran on page 1 of the New York Times.

华盛顿——加利福尼亚有一只黑猩猩，它有玩滴答游戏的天赋。它的培训师对这种学习证据感到高兴，但他们对其他事情印象更深。他们发现他们可以从动物的大脑中分辨出任何特定的动作是对还是错。这取决于黑猩猩的注意力状态。当受过训练的动物注意力集中时，他就做出了正确的举动。

WASHINGTON—There was a chimpanzee in California with a talent for playing ticktacktoe. Its trainers were delighted with this evidence of learning, but they were even more impressed by something else. They found they could tell from the animal’s brain whether any particular move would be right or wrong. It depended on the chimpanzee’s state of attention. When the trained animal was properly attentive, he made the right move.

嗯，这是一个相当有趣的事实。但为什么它值得在《泰晤士报》的第一页上发表呢？第 2 段告诉我：

Well, that’s a reasonably interesting fact. But why is it worth page 1 of the Times? Paragraph 2 tells me:

重要的事实是科学家能够识别这种状态。通过对脑电波信号进行精密的计算机分析，他们正在学习区分所谓的“心理状态”。

The significant fact was that scientists were able to recognize that state. By elaborate computer analysis of brain wave signals they were learning to distinguish what might be called “states of mind.”

但这在以前不是可能的吗？

But hadn’t this been possible before?

这比简单地检测觉醒、困倦或睡眠的总体状态要雄心勃勃得多。这是了解大脑工作原理的新一步。

This was far more ambitious than simply detecting gross states of arousal, drowsiness or sleep. It was a new step toward understanding how the brain works.

如何迈出新的一步？

How is it a new step?

黑猩猩和加州大学洛杉矶分校的研究团队已经从滴答声阶段毕业，但脑电波研究仍在继续。它已经揭示了一些关于太空飞行期间大脑行为的惊人见解。它显示出应用于解决地球上的社会和家庭问题，甚至改善人类学习的前景。

The chimpanzee and the research team at the University of California at Los Angeles have graduated from the ticktacktoe stage, but the work with brain waves is continuing. It has already revealed some surprising insights to the brain’s behavior during space flight. It shows promise of application to social and domestic problems on earth and even to improvements in human learning.

好的。我很难要求这项研究得到更广泛的应用：空间、人类问题和认知过程。但这是孤立的努力吗？确实没有。

Good. I could hardly ask for a broader application of the research: space, human problems and the cognitive process. But is it an isolated effort? No indeed.

它是美国和国外实验室正在进行的现代大脑研究大动荡的一部分。涉及的生物种类繁多，从人和猴子到老鼠、金鱼、扁虫和日本鹌鹑。

It is part of the large ferment of modern brain research in progress in laboratories throughout the United States and abroad. Involved are all manner of creatures from men and monkeys to rats and mice, goldfish, flatworms and Japanese quail.

我开始看到整个背景。但目的是什么？

I begin to see the total context. But what is the purpose?

最终目标是了解人类的大脑——令人难以置信的三磅重组织包，它可以想象宇宙最远的范围和原子的最终核心，但无法理解其自身的功能。每个研究项目都从一个巨大的谜题中解出一小块。

The ultimate goal is to understand the human brain—that incredible three-pound package of tissue that can imagine the farthest reaches of the universe and the ultimate core of the atom but cannot fathom its own functioning. Each research project bites off a little piece of an immense puzzle.

所以现在我知道了加州大学洛杉矶分校的黑猩猩在国际科学领域中的位置。知道了这一点，我准备好更多地了解他的特殊贡献。

So now I know where the chimp at U.C.L.A. fits into the spectrum of international science. Knowing this, I’m ready to learn more about his particular contribution.

在黑猩猩被教玩滴答游戏的情况下，即使是训练有素的眼睛也看不到在纸上描绘的代表动物大脑电波的波浪线以外的任何东西。但是通过计算机分析，可以分辨出哪些痕迹表明动物将要做出正确的动作，哪些是错误的。

In the case of the chimpanzee being taught to play ticktacktoe, even the trained eye could see nothing beyond the ordinary in the wavy lines being traced on paper to represent electrical waves from an animal’s brain. But through analysis by computer it was possible to tell which traces showed that the animal was about to make the right move and which preceded a mistake.

一个重要的关键是主要由约翰汉利博士开发的计算机分析系统。总是预示着正确答案的心态可以被描述为训练有素的注意力。如果没有计算机分析记录的脑电波的巨大复杂性的能力，就不可能检测到这种状态的“特征”。

An important key was the system of computer analysis developed largely by Dr. John Hanley. The state of mind that always foreshadowed a correct answer was one that might be described as trained attentiveness. Without the computer’s ability to analyze the huge complexities of the recorded brain waves, the “signatures” of such states could not have been detected.

这篇文章分为四个专栏来描述这项研究的潜在用途——测量家庭紧张的原因，减少司机在高峰时间的压力——最后它触及了许多医学和心理学领域正在进行的工作。但它始于一只黑猩猩玩滴答声。

The article goes on for four columns to describe potential uses of the research—measuring causes of domestic tension, reducing drivers’ rush-hour stress—and eventually it touches on work being done in many pockets of medicine and psychology. But it started with one chimpanzee playing ticktacktoe.

你可以通过帮助读者认同正在进行的科学工作来消除科学写作中的大部分神秘感。同样，这意味着要寻找人为因素——如果你必须满足于黑猩猩，至少它是达尔文阶梯上第二高的梯级。

You can take much of the mystery out of science writing by helping the reader to identify with the scientific work being done. Again, this means looking for the human element—and if you have to settle for a chimpanzee, at least that’s the next-highest rung on the Darwinian ladder.

人为因素之一就是你自己。使用您自己的经验将读者与某种也触及他的生活的机制联系起来。在下面关于记忆的文章中，请注意作者 Will Bradbury 如何为我们提供一个个人的方法来抓住一个复杂的主题：

One human element is yourself. Use your own experience to connect the reader to some mechanism that also touches his life. In the following article on memory, notice how the writer, Will Bradbury, gives us a personal handle with which to grab a complex subject:

即使是现在，我也能在沙子击中我的眼睛之前看到乌云，听到我父亲平静的声音催促我哭掉毒刺，我感到愤怒和屈辱在我胸中燃烧。自从一个玩伴为我的玩具救护车而战，将一把沙子扔到我脸上的那一刻起，已经过去了 30 多年。然而，沙子和救护车的样子、父亲的声音以及我受伤的感情的悸动，今天都依然清晰。它们是我最早能记住的东西，是镶嵌在马赛克中的第一批视觉、语言和情感玻璃，我通过大脑最基本的功能——记忆来认识我。

Even now I see the dark cloud of sand before it hits my eyes, hear my father’s calm voice urging me to cry the sting away, and feel anger and humiliation burn in my chest. More than 30 years have passed since that moment when a playmate, fighting for my toy ambulance, tossed a handful of sand in my face. Yet the look of the sand and ambulance, the sound of my father’s voice and the throb of my bruised feelings all remain sharp and clear today. They are the very first things I can remember, the first bits of visual, verbal and emotional glass imbedded in the mosaic I have come to know as me by what is certainly the brain’s most essential function—memory.

如果没有这种使我们能够存储和回忆信息的神奇功能，大脑负责清醒和睡眠、表达我们对事物的感受以及执行复杂行为的关键系统只能对当下的感官输入摸索。人也不会有真正的自我感觉，因为他没有过去的画廊可以检查、学习、享受并在必要时躲藏起来。然而，经过数千年的理论化、阅读和误读，他自己的行为怪癖，人类才刚刚开始对允许他打破和存储流逝的时间点滴的神秘过程有所了解。

Without this miracle function that enables us to store and recall information, the brain’s crucial systems for waking and sleeping, for expressing how we feel about things and for performing complicated acts could do little more than fumble with sensory inputs of the moment. Nor would man have a real feeling of self, for he would have no gallery of the past to examine, learn from, enjoy and, when necessary, hide away in. Yet after thousands of years of theorizing, of reading and misreading his own behavioral quirks, man is just beginning to have some understanding of the mysterious process that permits him to break and store bits of passing time.

一个问题是决定什么是记忆，什么东西有记忆。例如，亚麻籽油具有一种记忆力。一旦暴露在光线下，即使只是短暂的曝光，它也会在第二次曝光时改变稠度和速度。它会“记住”它与光的第一次相遇。电子和流体电路也有记忆，是一种更复杂的记忆。它们内置于计算机中，能够存储和检索大量信息。而人体至少有四种记忆....

One problem has been to decide what memory is and what things have it. Linseed oil, for example, has a kind of memory. Once exposed to light, even if only briefly, it will change consistency and speed the second time it is exposed. It will “remember” its first encounter with the light. Electronic and fluidic circuits also have memory, of a more sophisticated kind. Built into computers, they are able to store and retrieve extraordinary amounts of information. And the human body has at least four kinds of memory....

这是一个很好的线索。谁不拥有一些可以从难以想象的童年回忆起的生动形象？读者渴望了解这种存储和检索的壮举是如何完成的。亚麻籽油的例子就够刺激的，让我们想知道“记忆”到底是什么，然后作者又回到了人类的参照系，因为是人建造了计算机电路，自己有四种记忆.

That’s a fine lead. Who doesn’t possess some cluster of vivid images that can be recalled from an inconceivably early age? The reader is eager to learn how such a feat of storage and retrieval is accomplished. The example of the linseed oil is just piquant enough to make us wonder what “memory” really is, and then the writer reverts to the human frame of reference, for it is man who has built the computer circuits and has four kinds of memory himself.

另一种个人方法是围绕其他人编织一个科学故事。这就是 Berton Roueché 多年来在《纽约客》上撰写的名为“医学年鉴”的文章的吸引力。它们是侦探故事，几乎总是涉及一个受害者——一些患有神秘疾病的普通人——以及一个执着于寻找恶棍的刑警。以下是其中一个是如何开始的：

Another personal method is to weave a scientific story around someone else. That was the appeal of the articles called “Annals of Medicine” that Berton Roueché wrote for many years in The New Yorker. They are detective stories, almost always involving a victim—some ordinary person struck by a mystifying ailment—and a gumshoe obsessed with finding the villain. Here’s how one of them begins:

1944 年 9 月 25 日星期一早上 8 点左右，一位衣衫褴褛、漫无目的的 82 岁老人倒在哈德逊码头附近戴伊街的人行道上。一定有无数人注意到了他，但他独自躺在那儿几分钟，头晕目眩，腹部绞痛，并且极度呕吐。这时，一名警察走了过来。直到警察俯身看向老人之前，他可能以为他只是手上喝了醉酒；清晨，喝醉的流浪者在镇上的那个地方很常见。这不是他可以长期持有的意见。老人的鼻子、嘴唇、耳朵和手指都是天蓝色的。

At about 8 o’clock on Monday morning, Sept. 25, 1944, a ragged, aimless old man of 82 collapsed on the sidewalk on Dey Street, near the Hudson Terminal. Innumerable people must have noticed him, but he lay there alone for several minutes, dazed, doubled up with abdominal cramps, and in an agony of retching. Then a policeman came along. Until the policeman bent over the old man he may have supposed that he had just a sick drunk on his hands; wanderers dropped by drink are common in that part of town in the early morning. It was not an opinion that he could have held for long. The old man’s nose, lips, ears and fingers were sky-blue.

到中午，已有 11 名蓝衣男子被送往附近的医院。但不要害怕：现场流行病学家 Ottavio Pellitteri 博士正在现场并打电话给可预防疾病局的 Morris Greenberg 博士。慢慢地，这两个人拼凑出似乎与医学史相悖的证据碎片，直到案件被确定，恶棍被确定为一种非常罕见的中毒，以至于许多毒理学标准文本甚至都没有提到它。Roueché 的秘密与讲故事的艺术一样古老。我们正在追逐和神秘。但他并没有从中毒的病史开始，也没有谈论毒理学的标准文本。他给了我们一个人——不仅是一个人，而且是一个蓝色的人。

By noon, eleven blue men have been admitted to nearby hospitals. But never fear: Dr. Ottavio Pellitteri, field epidemiologist, is on the scene and telephoning Dr. Morris Greenberg at the Bureau of Preventable Diseases. Slowly the two men piece together fragments of evidence that seem to defy medical history until the case is nailed down and the villain identified as a type of poisoning so rare that many standard texts on toxicology don’t even mention it. Roueché’s secret is as old as the art of storytelling. We are in on a chase and a mystery. But he doesn’t start with the medical history of poisoning, or talk about standard texts on toxicology. He gives us a man—and not only a man but a blue one.

帮助读者理解不熟悉的事实的另一种方法是将它们与他们熟悉的景象联系起来。将抽象原理简化为他们可以想象的图像。摩西·萨夫迪 (Moshe Safdie) 是 67 年蒙特利尔世博会创新住宅综合体 Habitat 的构思者，他在他的《Beyond Habitat 》一书中解释说，如果人类花时间看看大自然是如何工作的，他会建造得更好，因为“大自然创造形式，而形式是进化的副产品”：

Another way to help your readers understand unfamiliar facts is to relate them to sights they are familiar with. Reduce the abstract principle to an image they can visualize. Moshe Safdie, the architect who conceived Habitat, the innovative housing complex at Montreal’s Expo ’67, explains in his book Beyond Habitat that man would build better than he does if he took the time to see how nature does the job, since “nature makes form, and form is a by-product of evolution”:

人们可以研究植物和动物的生命、岩石和水晶的构造，并发现它们特殊形式的原因。鹦鹉螺已经进化到当它的壳长大时，它的头不会卡在开口处。这被称为 gnomonic 增长；它导致螺旋形成。从数学上讲，这是它增长的唯一途径。

One can study plant and animal life, rock and crystal formations, and discover the reasons for their particular form. The nautilus has evolved so that when its shell grows, its head will not get stuck in the opening. This is known as gnomonic growth; it results in the spiral formation. It is, mathematically, the only way it can grow.

使用特定材料实现强度也是如此。看看秃鹰的翅膀，看看它的骨骼构造。一种最复杂的三维几何图案已经形成，一种空间框架，具有非常薄的骨骼，在末端变得更厚。秃鹰的主要生存问题是在不增加重量的情况下发展翅膀的力量（当鸟类飞行时，它会承受巨大的弯曲运动），因为这会限制它的活动能力。通过进化，秃鹰拥有了人们所能想象到的最有效的结构——骨骼中的空间框架。

The same is true of achieving strength with a particular material. Look at the wings of a vulture, at its bone formation. A most intricate three-dimensional geometric pattern has evolved, a kind of space frame, with very thin bones that get thicker at the ends. The main survival problem for the vulture is to develop strength in the wing (which is under tremendous bending movement when the bird is flying) without building up weight, as that would limit its mobility. Through evolution the vulture has the most efficient structure one can imagine—a space frame in bone.

“对于生活的各个方面，都有形式的反应，”萨夫迪写道，并指出枫树和榆树的叶子很宽，可以吸收最大量的阳光，以便在温带气候下生存，而橄榄树的叶子会旋转，因为它必须保持水分并且不能吸收热量，仙人掌会垂直于光线旋转。我们都可以想象一片枫叶和一株仙人掌。对于每一个严格的原则，Safdie 都给了我们一个简单的例子：

“For each aspect of life there are responses of form,” Safdie writes, noting that the maple and the elm have wide leaves to absorb the maximum amount of sun for survival in a temperate climate, whereas the olive tree has a leaf that rotates because it must preserve moisture and can’t absorb heat, and the cactus turns itself perpendicular to light. We can all picture a maple leaf and a cactus plant. With every hard principle, Safdie gives us a simple illustration:

经济和生存是自然界的两个关键词。断章取义，长颈鹿的脖子似乎长得不合算，但考虑到长颈鹿的大部分食物都在树上，这是合算的。我们所理解的美，以及我们在自然界中欣赏的美，从来都不是随意的。

Economy and survival are the two key words in nature. Examined out of context, the neck of the giraffe seems uneconomically long, but it is economical in view of the fact that most of the giraffe’s food is high on the tree. Beauty as we understand it, and as we admire it in nature, is never arbitrary.

或者阅读黛安·阿克曼 (Diane Ackerman) 撰写的这篇关于蝙蝠的文章。我们大多数人只知道关于蝙蝠的三个事实：它们是哺乳动物，我们不喜欢它们，它们有某种雷达，可以让它们在夜间飞行而不会撞到东西。显然，任何写蝙蝠文章的人都必须很快开始解释“回声定位”机制是如何工作的。在下面的段落中，阿克曼向我们提供了如此精确的细节——并且如此容易与我们所知道的联系起来——以至于这个过程成为一种阅读的乐趣：

Or take this article about bats, by Diane Ackerman. Most of us know only three facts about bats: they’re mammals, we don’t like them, and they’ve got some kind of radar that enables them to fly at night without bumping into things. Obviously anyone writing about bats must soon get around to explaining how that mechanism of “echo-location” works. In the following passage Ackerman gives us details so precise—and so easy to relate to what we know—that the process becomes a pleasure to read about:

如果你把蝙蝠想象成用高频声音呼唤或吹口哨来呼唤它们的猎物，那么就不难理解回声定位。我们大多数人都听不到这些。以我们最年轻、最敏锐的耳朵，我们可能会检测到每秒振动 20,000 次的声音，但蝙蝠可以发出高达 200,000 次的声音。他们不是源源不断地这样做，而是每隔一段时间——每秒 20 或 30 次。蝙蝠会聆听返回给它的声音，当回声开始变得越来越快、越来越响时，它就知道它跟踪的昆虫已经飞得更近了。通过判断回声之间的时间间隔，蝙蝠可以判断猎物移动的速度和方向。有些蝙蝠足够灵敏，可以注意到一只甲虫在沙滩上行走，有些蝙蝠可以检测到飞蛾在树叶上展开翅膀的动作。

It’s not hard to understand echo-location if you picture bats as calling or whistling to their prey with high-frequency sounds. Most of us can’t hear these. At our youngest and keenest of ear, we might detect sounds of 20,000 vibrations a second, but bats can vocalize at up to 200,000. They do it not in a steady stream but at intervals—20 or 30 times a second. A bat listens for the sounds to return to it, and when the echoes start coming faster and louder it knows that the insect it’s stalking has flown nearer. By judging the time between echoes, a bat can tell how fast the prey is moving and in which direction. Some bats are sensitive enough to register a beetle walking on sand, and some can detect the movement of a moth flexing its wings as it sits on a leaf.

那是我对敏感的看法；我不能要求作家给我两个更精彩的例子。但令我钦佩的不仅仅是感激。我也想知道：她收集了多少其他蝙蝠敏感的例子——几十个？数百？——能够选择这两个？总是从太多的材料开始。然后给你的读者足够的。

That’s my idea of sensitive; I couldn’t ask a writer to give me two more wonderful examples. But there’s more to my admiration than gratitude. I also wonder: how many other examples of bat sensitivity did she collect—dozens? hundreds?—to be able to choose those two? Always start with too much material. Then give your reader just enough.

当蝙蝠靠近时，它可能会叫得更快，以确定它的猎物。从砖墙上反射出的稳定、坚实的回声与从摇曳的花朵发出的轻盈、流畅的回声之间存在质的区别。通过向世界大喊大叫并聆听回声，蝙蝠可以描绘出它们的风景和其中的物体，其中包括纹理、密度、运动、距离、大小和可能还有其他特征。大多数蝙蝠真的很厉害；我们只是听不到他们的声音。当一个人站在满是蝙蝠的寂静树林中时，这是一个令人毛骨悚然的想法。他们终其一生都在大喊大叫。他们对亲人吼叫，对敌人吼叫，对晚餐吼叫，对繁华的大世界吼叫。有的叫得更快，有的更慢，有的大声，有的小声。长耳蝙蝠不需要叫喊；

As the bat closes in, it may shout faster, to pinpoint its prey. And there’s a qualitative difference between a steady, solid echo bouncing off a brick wall and the light, fluid echo from a swaying flower. By shouting at the world and listening to the echoes, bats can compose a picture of their landscape and the objects in it which includes texture, density, motion, distance, size and probably other features, too. Most bats really belt it out; we just don’t hear them. This is an eerie thought when one stands in a silent grove filled with bats. They spend their whole lives yelling. They yell at their loved ones, they yell at their enemies, they yell at their dinner, they yell at the big, bustling world. Some yell faster, some slower, some louder, some softer. Long-eared bats don’t need to yell; they can hear their echoes perfectly well if they whisper.

使科学易于理解的另一种方法是像人而不是科学家那样写作。这是做你自己的老问题。仅仅因为你正在处理一门通常以枯燥迂腐的方式报道的学术学科，你就没有理由不应该用新鲜的英语写作。洛伦·艾斯利 (Loren Eiseley) 是一位博物学家，他拒绝被大自然吓倒，因为他在《浩瀚的旅程》中向我们传授了他的知识和热情：

Another way of making science accessible is to write like a person and not like a scientist. It’s the same old question of being yourself. Just because you’re dealing with a scholarly discipline that’s usually reported in a style of dry pedantry is no reason why you shouldn’t write in good fresh English. Loren Eiseley was a naturalist who refused to be cowed by nature as he passed on to us, in The Immense Journey, not only his knowledge but his enthusiasms:

我一直是章鱼的崇拜者。头足类动物非常古老，它们已经滑落，千变万化，变成了许多形状。它们是软体动物中最聪明的，我一直觉得它们从不上岸对我们来说同样好，但是——还有其他的东西上岸了。

I have long been an admirer of the octopus. The cephalopods are very old, and they have slipped, protean, through many shapes. They are the wisest of the mollusks, and I have always felt it to be just as well for us that they never came ashore, but—there are other things that have.

没有必要害怕。确实有些生物很奇怪，但我发现这种情况比其他情况更令人振奋。看到大自然仍然忙于实验，仍然充满活力，而不是因为一条泥盆纪的鱼成功地变成了一个戴着草帽的两条腿的角色而没有通过或满足，这给人一种自信的感觉。大洋缸里还有其他的东西在酝酿和生长。知道这一点是值得的。知道未来和过去一样多是值得的。唯一不值得的是确定人自己在其中的作用。

There is no need to be frightened. It is true that some of the creatures are odd, but I find the situation rather heartening than otherwise. It gives one a feeling of confidence to see nature still busy with experiments, still dynamic, and not through or satisfied because a Devonian fish managed to end as a two-legged character with a straw hat. There are other things brewing and growing in the oceanic vat. It pays to know this. It pays to know there is just as much future as past. The only thing that doesn’t pay is to be sure of man’s own part in it.

Eiseley 的天赋在于他帮助我们感受成为一名科学家的感觉。他写作的核心是博物学家对自然的热爱，就像刘易斯·托马斯的写作是细胞生物学家对细胞的热爱一样。“看电视，”托马斯博士在他优雅的《细胞的生命》一书中写道，“你会认为我们生活在海湾，处于完全危险之中，四面八方被人类寻找的细菌包围，只有通过一种化学技术才能防止感染和死亡，使我们能够不断杀死它们。我们将混合了除臭剂的气溶胶云喷入我们的鼻子、嘴巴、腋下、特权缝隙——甚至进入我们电话的私密内部。” 但即使在我们最偏执的时候，他说，“在广阔的微生物世界中，我们一直都是一个相对次要的利益。感染脑膜炎球菌的人的生命危险要小得多，即使没有化疗，也比不幸感染人的脑膜炎球菌要小得多。”

Eiseley’s gift is that he helps us to feel what it’s like to be a scientist. The central transaction in his writing is the naturalist’s love affair with nature, just as in Lewis Thomas’s writing it’s the cell biologist’s love of the cell. “Watching television,” Dr. Thomas wrote in his elegant book Lives of a Cell, “you’d think we lived at bay, in total jeopardy, surrounded on all sides by human-seeking germs, shielded against infection and death only by a chemical technology that enables us to keep killing them off. We explode clouds of aerosol, mixed for good luck with deodorants, into our noses, mouths, underarms, privileged crannies—even into the intimate insides of our telephones.” But even at our most paranoid, he says, “we have always been a relatively minor interest of the vast microbial world. The man who catches a meningococcus is in considerably less danger for his life, even without chemotherapy, than the meningococci with the bad luck to catch a man.”

刘易斯·托马斯 (Lewis Thomas) 是科学家可以像其他人一样写作的科学证据。不一定要成为“作家”才能写得好。我们认为雷切尔卡森是一位作家，因为她用一本书《寂静的春天》发起了环保运动。但是卡森不是作家；她是一位文笔很好的海洋生物学家。她写得很好，因为她思想清晰，对自己的学科充满热情。查尔斯·达尔文的小猎犬号航行不仅是自然历史的经典；这是一部文学经典，它的句子大步向前，生动而有力。如果您是一名爱好科学或技术的学生，请不要认为英语系垄断了“文学”。每个科学学科都有自己的优秀文献。阅读在您感兴趣的领域写得很好的科学家——例如，Primo Levi （元素周期表）、Peter Medawar （冥王星共和国）、Oliver Sacks （把妻子误认为帽子的男人）、Stephen Jay Gould （熊猫的Thumb）、SM Ulam （数学家历险记）、Paul Davies （上帝与新物理学）、Freeman Dyson （武器与希望）- 并将它们用作您自己写作的模型。模仿他们的线性风格，他们避免使用技术术语，他们不断地将神秘的过程与任何读者可以想象的事物联系起来。

Lewis Thomas was scientific proof that scientists can write as well as anybody else. It’s not necessary to be a “writer” to write well. We think of Rachel Carson as a writer because she launched the environmental movement with a book, Silent Spring. But Carson wasn’t a writer; she was a marine biologist who wrote well. She wrote well because she was a clear thinker and had a passion for her subject. Charles Darwin’s The Voyage of the Beagle is not only a classic of natural history; it’s a classic of literature, its sentences striding forward with vividness and vigor. If you’re a student with a bent for science or technology, don’t assume that the English department has a monopoly on “literature.” Every scientific discipline has a fine literature of its own. Read the scientists who write well in fields that interest you—for example, Primo Levi (The Periodic Table), Peter Medawar (Pluto’s Republic), Oliver Sacks (The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat), Stephen Jay Gould (The Panda’s Thumb), S. M. Ulam (Adventures of a Mathematician), Paul Davies (God and the New Physics), Freeman Dyson (Weapons and Hope)—and use them as models for your own writing. Imitate their linear style, their avoidance of technical jargon, their constant relating of an arcane process to something any reader can visualize.

这是一篇名为“晶体管的未来”的文章，作者是 Robert W. Keyes，他拥有物理学博士学位，是半导体和信息处理系统方面的专家。大约 98% 的拥有物理学博士学位的人无法从培养皿中写出来，但这并不是因为他们不会。这是因为他们不会。他们不会屈尊学习使用英语的简单工具——与物理实验室中使用的任何仪器一样精致的精密仪器。这是凯斯的领导：

Here’s an article called “The Future of the Transistor,” in Scientific American, by Robert W. Keyes, who holds a doctorate in physics and is a specialist in semiconductors and information-processing systems. About 98 percent of people who hold a doctorate in physics can’t write their way out of a petri dish, but that’s not because they can’t. It’s because they won’t. They won’t deign to learn to use the simple tools of the English language—precision instruments as refined as any that are used in a physics lab. This is Keyes’s lead:

我在一台包含大约 1000 万个晶体管的计算机上写这篇文章，一个人拥有的制造品数量惊人。然而，它们的成本低于硬盘、键盘、显示器和机柜。相比之下，一千万根订书钉的成本与整台电脑差不多。晶体管之所以变得如此便宜，是因为在过去 40 年中，工程师们学会了在单个硅晶片上蚀刻更多的晶体管。因此，给定制造步骤的成本可以分摊到越来越多的单元上。

I am writing this article on a computer that contains some 10 million transistors, an astounding number of manufactured items for one person to own. Yet they cost less than the hard disk, the keyboard, the display and the cabinet. Ten million staples, in contrast, would cost about as much as the entire computer. Transistors have become this cheap because during the past 40 years engineers have learned to etch ever more of them on a single wafer of silicon. The cost of a given manufacturing step can thus be spread over a growing number of units.

这种趋势还能持续多久？学者和行业专家过去曾多次宣称存在一些物理极限，小型化无法超越。他们被事实搞糊涂的次数相同。可以在硅上制造的晶体管数量没有这样的限制，自晶体管发明以来的 46 年里，晶体管的数量已经增加了八个数量级。

How much longer can this trend continue? Scholars and industry experts have declared many times in the past that some physical limit exists beyond which miniaturization could not go. An equal number of times they have been confounded by the facts. No such limit can be discerned in the quantity of transistors that can be fabricated on silicon, which has proceeded through eight orders of magnitude in the 46 years since the transistor was invented.

再看一看顺序样式。你会看到一位科学家沿着他要讲的故事的路径，一步一步地带领你，一句接一句。他自己也很享受，因此写作也很愉快。

Take one more look at the sequential style. You’ll see a scientist leading you in logical steps, one sentence after another, along the path of the story he set out to tell. He is also enjoying himself and therefore writing enjoyably.

我引用了很多作家的话，写了很多关于物理世界的方方面面，以表明他们首先是作为人出现的：男人和女人在他们自己、他们的专业和他们的读者之间找到了人性的共同点。无论您的主题是什么，您都可以获得相同的融洽关系。顺序写作的原则适用于必须陪同读者穿越困难的新领域的每个领域。想想生物学和化学与政治、经济、伦理和宗教交织在一起的所有领域：艾滋病、堕胎、石棉、药物、基因剪接、老年病学、全球变暖、医疗保健、核能、污染、有毒废物、类固醇、克隆、代孕和其他几十种。只有通过专家的清晰写作，我们其他人才能在这些我们很少或没有受过教育的地区作为公民做出有根据的选择。

I’ve quoted from so many writers, writing about so many facets of the physical world, to show that they all come across first as people: men and women finding a common thread of humanity between themselves and their specialty and their readers. You can achieve the same rapport, whatever your subject. The principle of sequential writing applies to every field where the reader must be escorted over difficult new terrain. Think of all the areas where biology and chemistry are intertwined with politics, economics, ethics and religion: AIDS, abortion, asbestos, drugs, gene splicing, geriatrics, global warming, health care, nuclear energy, pollution, toxic waste, steroids, cloning, surrogate motherhood and dozens of others. Only through clear writing by experts can the rest of us make educated choices as citizens in these areas where we have little or no education.

我将以一个总结本章所有内容的示例作为结束。在阅读有关 1993 年国家杂志奖的早报时，我看到一本名为IEEE Spectrum的杂志获得了高度评价的报道类别，它击败了《大西洋月刊》、《新闻周刊》、《纽约客》和《名利场》等重量级人物。，这是我从未听说过的。它原来是电气和电子工程师协会的旗舰杂志，该协会是一个拥有 320,000 名会员的专业协会。据其编辑唐纳德·克里斯蒂安森 (Donald Christiansen) 称，该杂志曾经充斥着完整的符号和首字母缩略词，其文章甚至连其他工程师也常常难以理解。“在 IEEE 中有 37 个不同的可识别学科，”他说。“如果你不能用语言来描述某件事，我们自己的人就无法相互理解。”

I’ll close with an example that sums up everything this chapter has been about. Reading in my morning paper about the National Magazine Awards for 1993, I saw that the winner in the highly prized category of reporting, edging out such heavyweights as The Atlantic Monthly, Newsweek, The New Yorker and Vanity Fair, was a magazine called I.E.E.E. Spectrum, which I had never heard of. It turned out to be the flagship magazine of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, a professional association with 320,000 members. According to its editor, Donald Christiansen, the magazine was once full of integral signs and acronyms, its articles often unfathomable even to other engineers. “There are 37 different identifiable disciplines within I.E.E.E.,” he said. “If you can’t describe something in words, our own people can’t understand each other.”

在让 320,000 名工程师接触到他的杂志的同时，克里斯蒂安森也让普通读者也能接触到它，正如我在查找格伦佐佩特 (Glenn Zorpette) 的获奖文章“伊拉克如何逆向设计炸弹”时所发现的那样。这是我读过的最好的调查报告——最好的非小说类作品，服务于知情的公众知识。

In making his magazine accessible to 320,000 engineers, Christiansen also made it accessible to the general reader, as I found when I tracked down the award-winning article, “How Iraq Reverse-Engineered the Bomb,” by Glenn Zorpette. It’s as good a piece of investigative reporting as I’ve read—the best kind of nonfiction writing in the service of informed public knowledge.

它像侦探小说一样构建，描述了国际原子能机构 (IAEA) 为监控伊拉克人差点制造出原子弹的秘密计划所做的努力，并解释了他们为何如此接近原子弹。因此，这篇文章既是科学史著作，也是政治文件，仍然很热门，因为伊拉克的研究是在违反国际原子能机构的披露规则的情况下进行的——并且大概一直持续到萨达姆·侯赛因垮台；许多制造炸弹的材料是从包括美国在内的各个工业国家非法获得的。Spectrum文章重点介绍了一种称为 EMIS（电磁同位素分离）的技术，该技术正在巴格达南部一个名为 Al Tuwaitha 的研究中心进行：

Constructed like a detective story, it describes the efforts of the International Atomic Energy Agency (I.A.E.A.) to monitor the secret program whereby the Iraqis almost built an atomic bomb and to explain how they came so close. Thus the article was both a work of science history and a political document, one that was still hot, for Iraqi research was conducted—and presumably continued until the fall of Saddam Hussein—in violation of the I.A.E.A.’s disclosure rules; much of the bomb-making material was illicitly acquired from various industrial nations, including the United States. The Spectrum article focuses on a technique known as E.M.I.S. (electromagnetic isotope separation), which was being carried out at a research complex south of Baghdad called Al Tuwaitha:

EMIS 计划不仅让国际原子能机构感到惊讶，也让西方情报机构感到惊讶。使用这种技术，铀离子流在真空室中被电磁体偏转。该腔室及其相关设备称为 calutron。较重的 U-238 离子偏转小于 U-235 离子，这种微小的差异用于分离易裂变的 U-235。然而，“理论上非常有效的程序在实践中却是非常、非常混乱的事情，”最近退休的国际原子能机构行动小组现场活动经理莱斯利·索恩说。一些 U-238 离子始终与 U-235 混合，离子流很难控制。

The EMIS program surprised not only the IAEA, but the Western intelligence agencies. With this technique a stream of uranium ions is deflected by electromagnets in a vacuum chamber. The chamber and its associated equipment are called a calutron. The heavier U–238 ions are deflected less than the U–235 ions, and this slight difference is used to separate out the fissile U–235. However, “what in theory is a very efficient procedure is in practice a very, very messy affair,” said Leslie Thorne, who recently retired as field activities manager on the IAEA action team. Invariably, some U–238 ions remain mixed with the U–235, and ion streams can be hard to control.

好的，这很清楚。但是为什么流程这么乱？为什么离子流难以控制？作者有义务。他永远不会忘记他在上一段中将读者留在哪里以及他们接下来想知道什么。

O.K. That’s very clear. But why is the process so messy? Why are the ion streams hard to control? The writer obliges. He never forgets where he left his readers in the previous paragraph and what they want to know next.

这两种不同的同位素材料聚集在杯形石墨容器中。但是，它们在两个容器中的积累可能会因电磁铁的功率和温度的微小变化而被疯狂地甩掉。因此在实践中，材料往往会飞溅到整个真空室内部，必须在每运行几十小时后清洁一次。

The two different isotopic materials accumulate in cup-shaped graphite containers. But their accumulation in the two containers can be thrown off wildly by small variations in the power to, and temperature of, the electromagnets. Thus in practice the materials tend to spatter all over the inside of the vacuum chamber, which must be cleaned after every few dozen hours of operation.

这是任何人对凌乱的看法。然而，这个过程是否奏效过？

That’s anybody’s idea of messy. But has this process, nevertheless, ever worked?

需要数百个磁铁和数千万瓦。例如，在曼哈顿计划期间，位于田纳西州橡树岭的 Y-12 EMIS 设施使用的电力超过加拿大，加上美国的全部白银库存；后者用于缠绕所需的许多电磁铁（战争中其他地方需要铜）。主要是因为这些问题，美国科学家认为没有哪个国家会求助于 EMIS 来生产原子武器所需的相对大量的浓缩材料……

Hundreds of magnets and tens of millions of watts are needed. During the Manhattan Project, for example, the Y–12 EMIS facility at Oak Ridge in Tennessee used more power than Canada, plus the entire U.S. stockpile of silver; the latter was used to wind the many electromagnets required (copper was needed elsewhere in the war effort). Mainly because of such problems, U.S. scientists believed that no country would ever turn to EMIS to produce the relatively large amounts of enriched material needed for atomic weapons....

伊拉克 EMIS 计划的发现有很多好间谍小说的戏剧性。第一条线索显然来自伊拉克军队在图瓦萨扣押的美国人质的衣服。人质获释后，情报专家对他们的衣服进行了分析，他们发现了极小的核材料样本，其同位素浓度只能在 calutron 中生产……

The discovery of the Iraqi EMIS program had much of the drama of a good spy novel. The first clue apparently came in the clothing of U.S. hostages held by Iraqi forces at Tuwaitha. After the hostages were released, their clothes were analyzed by intelligence experts, who found infinitesimal samples of nuclear materials with isotopic concentrations producible only in a calutron....

“我们突然发现了一只活恐龙，”国际原子能机构伊拉克行动小组副组长德米特里奥斯·佩里科斯说。

“Suddenly we found a live dinosaur,” said Demetrios Perricos, deputy head of the IAEA’s Iraq action team.

即使在如此高科技的环境中，作家也从未失去人性的成分。这不是关于“科学”的故事；这是一个关于从事科学研究的人的故事——一群秘密炸弹制造者和一群高科技警察。关于恐龙的名言是纯金的，这是一个我们都能理解的比喻。连小孩子都知道恐龙已经不在了。

Even in the midst of such high technology the writer never loses the human ingredient. This isn’t a story about “science”; it’s a story about people doing science—a gang of clandestine bomb-makers and a team of high-tech cops. The quote about the dinosaur is pure gold, a metaphor we can all understand. Even a child knows that dinosaurs aren’t around anymore.

由于良好的侦探工作是不可避免的，这篇文章建立了调查的全部重点的结果：发现伊拉克“不仅限于生产武器级材料，同时还在努力围绕材料，一项被称为武器化的艰巨任务。” 首先，我们被告知任何尝试该任务的人都有哪些选择：

With the inevitability of good detective work, the article builds to the outcome that has been the whole point of the investigation: the discovery that Iraq, “not limiting itself to producing weapons-grade materials, was concurrently struggling to build a deliverable weapon around the material, a daunting task known as weaponization.” First we are told what options exist for anyone attempting that task:

原子弹的两种基本类型是枪式装置和内爆武器。后者的设计和建造要困难得多，但对于给定数量的裂变材料，爆炸当量更高。国际原子能机构调查人员没有发现伊拉克正在积极寻找枪支装置的证据；他们说，很明显，他们将资金和资源集中在内爆装置上，甚至已经开始研究相当先进的内爆设计。

The two basic types of atomic bombs are gun devices and implosion weapons. The latter are much more difficult to design and build, but provide higher explosive yields for a given amount of fissile material. IAEA investigators have found no evidence that Iraq was actively pursuing a gun device; it is clear, they say, that they concentrated their money and resources on an implosion device, and had even started work on fairly advanced implosion designs.

什么是内爆装置？继续阅读：

What’s an implosion device? Read on:

在内爆装置中，裂变材料被传统炸药产生的冲击波力物理压缩。然后，在恰到好处的瞬间，中子被释放，引发超快裂变链式反应——原子爆炸。因此，内爆装置的主要元件是点火系统、炸药组件和核心。点火系统包括基于真空管的高能放电装置，称为氪，能够释放足够的能量来引爆常规炸药。爆炸组件包括“透镜”，可将球形内爆冲击波精确聚焦在裂变核心上，裂变核心内装有中子引发剂。国际原子能机构已经收集了充分的证据表明伊拉克人在这些领域中的每一个领域都取得了进展。

In an implosion device the fissile material is physically compressed by the force of a shock wave created with conventional explosives. Then, at just the right instant, neutrons are released, initiating the ultrafast fission chain reaction—an atomic blast. Thus the main elements of an implosion device are a firing system, an explosive assembly, and the core. The firing system includes vacuum-tube-based, high-energy discharge devices called krytons that are capable of releasing enough energy to detonate the conventional explosive. The explosive assembly includes “lenses” that precisely focus the spherical, imploding shock wave on the fissile core, within which is a neutronic initiator. The IAEA had amassed ample evidence that the Iraqis had made progress in each of these areas.

说到压缩，那段是紧凑的线性写作的瑰宝，依次解释了内爆装置及其三个主要元素。但是（我们现在想知道）IAEA 的证据是如何收集的？

Speaking of compression, that paragraph is a gem of tight linear writing, successively explaining the implosion device and its three main elements. But how (we now want to know) was the I.A.E.A.’s evidence amassed?

1990 年 3 月，伊拉克试图从加利福尼亚州圣马科斯的 CSI Technologies, Inc. 进口氪元素成为新闻，当时两名伊拉克人在美国和英国海关进行了为期 18 个月的“诱捕”行动后在伦敦希思罗机场被捕。然而，在此之前的几年，伊拉克确实设法从其他美国公司那里获得了武器品质的电容器，并且还生产了自己的电容器……

Iraq’s attempts to import krytons from CSI Technologies, Inc., San Marcos, Calif., made news in March 1990, when two Iraqis were arrested at London’s Heathrow airport after an 18-month “sting” operation involving U.S. and British Customs. Several years before that, however, Iraq did manage to get weapons-quality capacitors from other U.S. concerns, and also produced its own capacitors....

我把我的案子搁置——或者，更确切地说，我让Spectrum帮我搁置它。如果一个如此复杂的科学主题可以用流利的英语表达得如此清晰和强大，只需要几个技术词汇，就可以快速解释（kryton）或可以快速查找（裂变），那么任何主题都可以变得清晰和被所有认为自己害怕科学的作家和所有认为自己害怕写作的科学家所支持。

I rest my case—or, rather, I let Spectrum rest it for me. If a scientific subject of that complexity can be made that clear and robust, in good English, with only a few technical words, which are quickly explained (kryton) or can be quickly looked up (fissile), any subject can be made clear and robust by all you writers who think you’re afraid of science and all you scientists who think you’re afraid of writing.

16

16

商业写作

Business Writing

在你的工作中写作

Writing in Your Job

如果您在工作中必须进行任何写作，本章适合您。就像在科学写作中一样，焦虑是问题的重要组成部分，人性和清晰的思维是解决方案的重要组成部分。

If you have to do any writing in your job, this chapter is for you. Just as in science writing, anxiety is a big part of the problem and humanity and clear thinking are a big part of the solution.

虽然这是一本关于写作的书，但它不只是写给作家的。它的原则适用于任何需要在日常工作中进行写作的人。备忘录、商业信函、行政报告、财务分析、营销计划书、给老板的便条、传真、电子邮件、便利贴——每天在你办公室流通的所有纸张是写作形式。认真对待他们。无数职业生涯的兴衰取决于员工陈述一组事实、总结会议或连贯地提出想法的能力或无能力。

Although this is a book about writing, it’s not just for writers. Its principles apply to everyone who is expected to do some writing as part of his or her daily employment. The memo, the business letter, the administrative report, the financial analysis, the marketing proposal, the note to the boss, the fax, the e-mail, the Post-it—all the pieces of paper that circulate through your office every day are forms of writing. Take them seriously. Countless careers rise or fall on the ability or the inability of employees to state a set of facts, summarize a meeting or present an idea coherently.

大多数人为机构工作：企业、银行、保险公司、律师事务所、政府机构、学校系统、非营利组织和其他实体。其中许多人都是经理，他们的作品向公众公开：总裁向股东发表讲话，银行家解释程序的变化，校长给家长写一封时事通讯。无论他们是谁，他们往往非常害怕写作，以至于他们的句子缺乏人性化——他们的机构也是如此。很难想象这些是真正的男人和女人每天早上来上班的真实地方。

Most people work for institutions: businesses, banks, insurance firms, law firms, government agencies, school systems, non-profit organizations and other entities. Many of those people are managers whose writing goes out to the public: the president addressing the stockholders, the banker explaining a change in procedure, the school principal writing a newsletter to parents. Whoever they are, they tend to be so afraid of writing that their sentences lack all humanity—and so do their institutions. It’s hard to imagine that these are real places where real men and women come to work every morning.

但仅仅因为人们为一个机构工作，他们就不必像一个机构那样写作。机构可以预热。管理员可以变成人。可以清楚地传达信息，而不会浮夸。你只需要记住，读者认同的是人，而不是像“盈利能力”这样的抽象概念，或者像“利用”和“实施”这样的拉丁名词，或者是惰性的结构，在这些结构中，没有人可以形象化地做某事：“预可行性研究”正处于文书工作阶段。”

But just because people work for an institution, they don’t have to write like one. Institutions can be warmed up. Administrators can be turned into human beings. Information can be imparted clearly and without pomposity. You only have to remember that readers identify with people, not with abstractions like “profitability,” or with Latinate nouns like “utilization” and “implementation,” or with inert constructions in which nobody can be visualized doing something: “pre-feasibility studies are in the paperwork stage.”

没有人比乔治·奥威尔更能说明这一点，他将传道书中的这首著名诗句翻译成现代官僚主义的模糊文字：

Nobody has made the point better than George Orwell in his translation into modern bureaucratic fuzz of this famous verse from Ecclesiastes:

我转身又见日光之下，跑得快的未必得跑，勇者未必争战，聪明的未必得粮，聪明的未必致富，聪明的未必得宠。但时间和机会都发生在他们身上。

I returned and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favor to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all.

奥威尔的版本是这样的：

Orwell’s version goes:

对当代现象的客观考虑得出这样的结论，即竞争活动中的成败与先天能力不相称，但必须始终考虑相当大的不可预测因素。

Objective consideration of contemporary phenomena compels the conclusion that success or failure in competitive activities exhibits no tendency to be commensurate with innate capacity, but that a considerable element of the unpredictable must invariably be taken into account.

首先注意这两个段落的外观。顶部的第一个邀请我们阅读它。词短而有气；它们传达了人类语言的节奏。第二个是长词。它立即告诉我们，笨重的头脑在起作用。我们不想带着用这种令人窒息的语言表达自己的思想去任何地方。我们甚至没有开始阅读。

First notice how the two passages look. The first one at the top invites us to read it. The words are short and have air around them; they convey the rhythms of human speech. The second one is clotted with long words. It tells us instantly that a ponderous mind is at work. We don’t want to go anywhere with a mind that expresses itself in such suffocating language. We don’t even start to read.

还要注意这两段经文所说的内容。从第二个开始，日常生活中的简短词语和生动形象——种族和战争、面包和财富——取而代之的是摇摇晃晃的长而松弛的具有普遍意义的名词。对于一个人做了什么（“我回来了”）或他意识到（“看到”了）关于生命的核心奥秘之一：命运的反复无常的任何感觉都一去不复返了。

Also notice what the two passages say. Gone from the second one are the short words and vivid images of everyday life—the race and the battle, the bread and the riches—and in their place have waddled the long and flabby nouns of generalized meaning. Gone is any sense of what one person did (“I returned”) or what he realized (“saw”) about one of life’s central mysteries: the capriciousness of fate.

让我来说明这种疾病如何影响大多数人在工作中所做的写作。我将以学校校长作为我的第一个例子，不是因为他们是最严重的违规者（他们不是），而是因为我碰巧有这样的例子。然而，我的观点是针对在所有组织中工作的所有男男女女，在这些组织中，语言已经失去了人性，没有人知道负责人在说什么。

Let me illustrate how this disease infects the writing that most people do in their jobs. I’ll use school principals as my first example, not because they are the worst offenders (they aren’t) but because I happen to have such an example. My points, however, are intended for all the men and women who work in all the organizations where language has lost its humanity and nobody knows what the people in charge are talking about.

当我接到康涅狄格州格林威治学校负责人欧内斯特·B·弗莱什曼 (Ernest B. Fleishman) 的电话时，我开始与校长会面。“我们希望你能来'dejargonize'我们，”他说。“我们不认为我们可以教学生写作，除非我们所有处于学校系统顶端的人都清理我们自己的写作。” 他说他会寄给我一些系统内产生的典型材料。他的想法是让我分析写作，然后举办一个研讨会。

My encounter with the principals began when I got a call from Ernest B. Fleishman, superintendent of schools in Greenwich, Connecticut. “We’d like you to come and ‘dejargonize’ us,” he said. “We don’t think we can teach students to write unless all of us at the top of the school system clean up our own writing.” He said he would send me some typical materials that had originated within the system. His idea was for me to analyze the writing and then conduct a workshop.

吸引我的是弗莱什曼博士和他的同事愿意让自己变得脆弱；脆弱性有其自身的力量。我们决定了约会，很快就收到了一个大信封。它包含从镇上 16 所小学、初中和高中邮寄给家长的各种内部备忘录和油印通讯。

What appealed to me was the willingness of Dr. Fleishman and his colleagues to make themselves vulnerable; vulnerability has a strength of its own. We decided on a date, and soon a fat envelope arrived. It contained various internal memos and mimeographed newsletters that had been mailed to parents from the town’s 16 elementary, junior and senior high schools.

这些时事通讯看起来愉快而随意。显然，系统正在努力与家人进行热情的沟通。但即使乍一看，某些冷淡的短语也引起了我的注意（“优先评估程序”、“修改后的部门化时间表”），一位校长承诺他的学校将提供“增强的积极学习环境”。很明显，系统没有像它想象的那样热情地交流。

The newsletters had a cheery and informal look. Obviously the system was making an effort to communicate warmly with its families. But even at first glance certain chilly phrases caught my eye (“prioritized evaluative procedures,” “modified departmentalized schedule”), and one principal promised that his school would provide “enhanced positive learning environments.” Just as obviously the system wasn’t communicating as warmly as it thought it was.

我研究了校长的材料并将其分为好的和坏的例子。在格林威治指定的早晨，我发现 40 名校长和课程协调员齐聚一堂，他们渴望学习。我告诉他们，我只能为他们屈服于一个如此威胁他们身份的过程而鼓掌。在全国范围内关于为什么约翰尼不能写作的喧嚣中，弗莱什曼博士是我经历过的第一个承认年轻人不能垄断口头污泥的成年人。

I studied the principals’ material and divided it into good and bad examples. On the appointed morning in Greenwich I found 40 principals and curriculum coordinators assembled and eager to learn. I told them I could only applaud them for submitting to a process that so threatened their identity. In the national clamor over why Johnny can’t write, Dr. Fleishman was the first adult in my experience who admitted that youth has no monopoly on verbal sludge.

我告诉校长们，我们要将经营我们孩子学校的男男女女视为与我们相似的人。我们怀疑自命不凡，怀疑社会科学家为了避免让普通凡人清楚自己而创造的所有时尚词汇。我敦促他们要自然。我们如何写作和如何说话就是我们如何定义自己。

I told the principals that we want to think of the men and women who run our children’s schools as people not unlike ourselves. We are suspicious of pretentiousness, of all the fad words that the social scientists have coined to avoid making themselves clear to ordinary mortals. I urged them to be natural. How we write and how we talk is how we define ourselves.

我让他们听听他们是如何向社区定义自己的。我复制了某些不好的例子，更改了学校和校长的名称。我解释说我会大声朗读一些例子。稍后我们会看看他们是否可以将他们所写的内容变成简单的英语。这是我的第一个例子：

I asked them to listen to how they were defining themselves to the community. I had made copies of certain bad examples, changing the names of the schools and the principals. I explained that I would read some of the examples aloud. Later we would see if they could turn what they had written into plain English. This was my first example:

亲爱的家长：

Dear Parent:

我们建立了一个特殊的电话通讯系统，为家长提供更多的机会。今年我们将更加重视沟通的目标，并利用多种方式来实现这一目标。作为家长，您的意见将帮助我们规划和实施满足您孩子需求的教育计划。家长和老师之间的公开对话、反馈和信息共享将使我们能够以最有效的方式与您的孩子一起工作。

We have established a special phone communication system to provide additional opportunities for parent input. During this year we will give added emphasis to the goal of communication and utilize a variety of means to accomplish this goal. Your inputs, from the unique position as a parent, will help us to plan and implement an educational plan that meets the needs of your child. An open dialogue, feedback and sharing of information between parents and teachers will enable us to work with your child in the most effective manner.

博士_ _ G EORGE B. J ONES

校长

DR. GEORGE B. JONES

Principal

这是我不想接受的那种交流，虽然我的父母输入可能是独一无二的。我想知道学校将让我更容易给老师打电话，他们希望我经常打电话讨论我的孩子们相处得怎么样。相反，父母得到了垃圾：“特殊的电话通信系统”，“强调通信目标”，“计划和实施教育计划”。至于“公开对话、反馈和信息共享”，这是同一个东西的三种表达方式。

That’s the kind of communication I don’t want to receive, unique though my parent inputs might be. I want to be told that the school is going to make it easier for me to telephone the teachers and that they hope I’ll call often to discuss how my children are getting along. Instead the parent gets junk: “special phone communication system,” “added emphasis to the goal of communication,” “plan and implement an educational plan.” As for “open dialogue, feedback and sharing of information,” they are three ways of saying the same thing.

琼斯博士显然是一个善意的人，他的计划是我们所有人都想要的：尽管上周二在操场上发生了不幸的事件，但仍有机会拿起电话告诉校长约翰尼是一个多么棒的孩子。但琼斯博士听起来不像是我想称呼的人。事实上，他听起来不像一个人。他的信息可能已经被电脑窃听了。他正在浪费一种丰富的资源：他自己。

Dr. Jones is clearly a man who means well, and his plan is one we all want: a chance to pick up the phone and tell the principal what a great kid Johnny is despite that unfortunate incident in the playground last Tuesday. But Dr. Jones doesn’t sound like a person I want to call. In fact, he doesn’t sound like a person. His message could have been tapped out by a computer. He is squandering a rich resource: himself.

我选择的另一个例子是在学年开始时发送给家长的“校长问候语”。它由两个截然不同的段落组成：

Another example I chose was a “Principal’s Greeting” sent to parents at the start of the school year. It consisted of two paragraphs that were very different:

从根本上说，福斯特是一所好学校。在某些科目或学习技能领域需要帮助的学生会受到特别关注。在未来的学年，我们力求提供更好的积极学习环境。儿童和工作人员必须在有利于学习的氛围中工作。需要各种各样的教学材料。需要仔细注意个人能力和学习方式。学校和家庭之间的合作对学习过程极其重要。我们所有人都应该了解每个孩子期望的教育目标。

Fundamentally, Foster is a good school. Pupils who require help in certain subjects or study skills areas are receiving special attention. In the school year ahead we seek to provide enhanced positive learning environments. Children, and staff, must work in an atmosphere that is conducive to learning. Wide varieties of instructional materials are needed. Careful attention to individual abilities and learning styles is required. Cooperation between school and home is extremely important to the learning process. All of us should be aware of desired educational objectives for every child.

随时了解今年为我们的孩子制定的计划，让我们知道您自己的问题以及您孩子可能有的任何特殊需求。在最初的几周里，我遇到了很多人。请继续停下来自我介绍或谈论福斯特。我期待着我们所有人都能收获丰硕的一年。

Keep informed about what is planned for our children this year and let us know about your own questions and about any special needs your child may have. I have met many of you in the first few weeks. Please continue to stop in to introduce yourself or to talk about Foster. I look forward to a very productive year for all of us.

博士_ _ R AY B. D AWSON

校长

DR. RAY B. DAWSON

Principal

在第二段中，有人向我打招呼；首先，我收到一位教育家的来信。我喜欢第 2 段中真正的道森博士。他用温暖舒适的措辞说话：“随时了解情况”、“让我们知道”、“我见过”、“请继续”、“我期待着”。

In the second paragraph I’m being greeted by a person; in the first I’m hearing from an educator. I like the real Dr. Dawson of Paragraph 2. He talks in warm and comfortable phrases: “Keep informed,” “let us know,” “I have met,” “Please continue,” “I look forward.”

相比之下，第 1 段的教育家道森从不使用“我”，甚至没有暗示“我”的含义。他又回到了他的专业术语，在那里他感到安全，没有停下来注意到他真的没有告诉父母任何事情。什么是“学习技能领域”，它们与“学科”有何不同？什么是“增强的积极学习环境”，它们与“有利于学习的氛围”有何不同？什么是“种类繁多的教学材料”：铅笔、教科书、胶卷？究竟什么是“学习风格”？“期望”的“教育目标”是什么？

By contrast, Educator Dawson of Paragraph 1 never uses “I” or even suggests a sense of “I.” He falls back on the jargon of his profession, where he feels safe, not stopping to notice that he really isn’t telling the parent anything. What are “study skills areas,” and how do they differ from “subjects”? What are “enhanced positive learning environments,” and how do they differ from “an atmosphere that is conducive to learning”? What are “wide varieties of instructional materials”: pencils, textbooks, filmstrips? What exactly are “learning styles”? What “educational objectives” are “desired”?

第二段，简而言之，温暖而有个性；另一个是迂腐和含糊。这是我反复发现的模式。每当校长写信通知家长一些人为细节时，他们都充满人情味地写道：

The second paragraph, in short, is warm and personal; the other is pedantic and vague. That was a pattern I found repeatedly. Whenever the principals wrote to notify the parents of some human detail, they wrote with humanity:

学校门前似乎又开始堵车了。如果可能的话，请在一天结束时到学校后方接您的孩子。

It seems that traffic is beginning to pile up again in front of the school. If you can possibly do so, please come to the rear of the school for your child at the end of the day.

如果您能与您的孩子谈谈他们在自助餐厅的行为，我将不胜感激。如果你能在孩子吃饭时观察他们的举止，你们中的许多人会非常沮丧。偶尔检查一下他们是否欠午餐钱。有时孩子还款很慢。

I would appreciate it if you would speak with your children about their behavior in the cafeteria. Many of you would be totally dismayed if you could observe the manners of your children while they are eating. Check occasionally to see if they owe money for lunch. Sometimes children are very slow in repaying.

但是，当教育工作者写信解释他们打算如何进行教育时，他们消失得无影无踪：

But when the educators wrote to explain how they proposed to do their educating, they vanished without a trace:

在本文档中，您将找到已确定并确定优先级的计划目标和目的。还根据可接受的标准制定了目标评估程序。

In this document you will find the program goals and objectives that have been identified and prioritized. Evaluative procedures for the objectives were also established based on acceptable criteria.

在实施上述做法之前，学生很少接触多项选择题。人们认为，使用与学生目前正在学习的单元相关的练习题已经产生了极其积极的效果，正如考试成绩所证实的那样。

Prior to the implementation of the above practice, students were given very little exposure to multiple choice questions. It is felt that the use of practice questions correlated to the unit that a student is presently studying has had an extremely positive effect as the test scores confirm.

在我阅读了各种好的和坏的例子之后，校长们开始听到他们真实的自我和他们的教育者自我之间的区别。问题是如何缩小差距。我背诵了我的四条信条：清晰、简单、简洁和人道。我解释了如何使用主动动词并避免使用“概念名词”。我告诉他们不要将教育的特殊词汇用作拐杖；几乎任何主题都可以用流利的英语进行访问。

After I had read various good and bad examples, the principals began to hear the difference between their true selves and their educator selves. The problem was how to close the gap. I recited my four articles of faith: clarity, simplicity, brevity and humanity. I explained about using active verbs and avoiding “concept nouns.” I told them not to use the special vocabulary of education as a crutch; almost any subject can be made accessible in good English.

这些都是基本原则，但校长们把它们记了下来，就好像他们以前从未听过一样——也许他们没有，或者至少很多年没有听过。也许这就是为什么官僚散文变得如此浮夸，无论官僚机构如何。一旦管理者上升到一定水平，就再也没有人向他指出简单陈述句的美妙之处，或向他展示他的文章如何因浮夸的概括而变得肿胀。

These were all basic tenets, but the principals wrote them down as if they had never heard them before—and maybe they hadn’t, or at least not for many years. Perhaps that’s why bureaucratic prose becomes so turgid, whatever the bureaucracy. Once an administrator rises to a certain level, nobody ever points out to him again the beauty of a simple declarative sentence, or shows him how his writing has become swollen with pompous generalizations.

终于，我们的车间开始工作了。我分发了我的副本，并要求校长重写更棘手的句子。这是一个严峻的时刻。他们还是第一次遇到敌人。他们在便笺本上乱涂乱画，然后把乱涂乱画的东西刮掉。有些什么都没写。有些人把纸弄皱了。他们开始看起来像作家。房间里笼罩着可怕的寂静，只有划掉的句子和皱巴巴的纸打破了房间。他们开始听起来像作家。

Finally our workshop got down to work. I distributed my copies and asked the principals to rewrite the more knotty sentences. It was a grim moment. They had met the enemy for the first time. They scribbled on their pads and scratched out what they had scribbled. Some didn’t write anything. Some crumpled their paper. They began to look like writers. An awful silence hung over the room, broken only by the crossing out of sentences and the crumpling of paper. They began to sound like writers.

随着日子一天天过去，他们慢慢放松了下来。他们开始以第一人称写作并使用主动动词。有一段时间，他们仍然无法摆脱对冗长单词和模糊名词的控制（“家长沟通回应”）。但渐渐地，他们的判决变得人性化了。当我要求他们解决“目标的评估程序也根据可接受的标准建立”时，其中一位写道：“在年底，我们将评估我们的进展。” 另一位写道：“我们将看到我们取得了多大的成功。”

As the day went on, they slowly relaxed. They began to write in the first person and to use active verbs. For a while they still couldn’t loose their grip on long words and vague nouns (“parent communication response”). But gradually their sentences became human. When I asked them to tackle “Evaluative procedures for the objectives were also established based on acceptable criteria,” one of them wrote: “At the end of the year we will evaluate our progress.” Another wrote: “We will see how well we have succeeded.”

这是父母想要的那种直白的谈话。这也是股东希望从他们的公司得到什么，客户希望从他们的银行得到什么，寡妇希望从处理她的社会保障的机构得到什么。对人际交往有着深深的向往，对夸夸其谈有怨恨。最近，我收到了满足我的计算机需求的公司的一封“尊敬的客户”信。它开始：“从 3 月 30 日起，我们将把我们的最终用户订单输入和供应推荐处理迁移到一个新的电话营销中心。” 我终于弄清楚他们有一个新的 800 号码，最终用户是我。任何不愿在文字上既清晰又个性化的组织都会失去朋友、客户和金钱。让我为企业高管换一种说法：预期盈利能力将出现不足。

That’s the kind of plain talk a parent wants. It’s also what stockholders want from their corporation, what customers want from their bank, what the widow wants from the agency that’s handling her social security. There is a deep yearning for human contact and a resentment of bombast. Recently I got a “Dear Customer” letter from the company that supplies my computer needs. It began: “Effective March 30 we will be migrating our end user order entry and supplies referral processing to a new telemarketing center.” I finally figured out that they had a new 800 number and that the end user was me. Any organization that won’t take the trouble to be both clear and personal in its writing will lose friends, customers and money. Let me put it another way for business executives: a shortfall will be experienced in anticipated profitability.

这是一个公司如何用自命不凡的语言抛弃人性的例子。这是一家大公司分发的“客户公告”。客户公告的唯一目的是向客户提供有用的信息。这个开始：“公司越来越多地转向容量规划技术来确定未来的处理负载何时会超过处理能力。” 那句话对客户没有好处；它与诸如“能力”和“能力”之类的奥威尔式名词结合在一起，传达出客户无法想象的任何程序。什么是容量规划技术？谁的容量正在规划中？通过谁？第二句话说：“容量规划增加了决策过程的客观性。” 更多死名词。第三句说：“管理层在信息系统资源的关键领域得到加强的决策参与。”

Here’s an example of how companies throw away their humanity with pretentious language. It’s a “customer bulletin” distributed by a major corporation. The sole purpose of a customer bulletin is to give helpful information to a customer. This one begins: “Companies are increasingly turning to capacity planning techniques to determine when future processing loads will exceed processing capabilities.” That sentence is no favor to the customer; it’s congealed with Orwellian nouns like “capacity” and “capabilities” that convey no procedures that a customer can picture. What are capacity planning techniques? Whose capacity is being planned? By whom? The second sentence says: “Capacity planning adds objectivity to the decision-making process.” More dead nouns. The third sentence says: “Management is given enhanced decision participation in key areas of information system resources.”

客户必须在每一句话之后停下来翻译。公告也可能是匈牙利语。他从第一句话开始——关于容量规划技术的那句话。翻译过来，这意味着“它有助于了解您何时为计算机提供了超出其处理能力的内容。” 第二句话——“容量规划增加了决策过程的客观性”——意味着你应该在做出决定之前了解事实。第三句话——关于增强决策参与——的意思是“你对你的系统了解得越多，它就会工作得越好。” 它也可能意味着其他几件事。

The customer has to stop after every sentence and translate it. The bulletin might as well be in Hungarian. He starts with the first sentence—the one about capacity planning techniques. Translated, that means “It helps to know when you’re giving your computer more than it can handle.” The second sentence—“Capacity planning adds objectivity to the decision-making process”—means you should know the facts before you decide. The third sentence—the one about enhanced decision participation—means “The more you know about your system, the better it will work.” It could also mean several other things.

但客户不会继续翻译。很快，他将寻找另一家公司。他想，“如果这些人这么聪明，为什么他们不能告诉我他们做了什么？也许他们并不那么聪明。” 该公告继续说，“为了避免未来的成本，生产率得到了提高。” 这似乎意味着该产品将是免费的——所有成本都被避免了。接下来，公告向客户保证“系统已交付功能”。这意味着它有效。我希望如此。

But the customer isn’t going to keep translating. Soon he’s going to look for another company. He thinks, “If these guys are so smart, why can’t they tell me what they do? Maybe they’re not so smart.” The bulletin goes on to say that “for future cost avoidance, productivity has been enhanced.” That seems to mean the product will be free—all costs have been avoided. Next the bulletin assures the customer that “the system is delivered with functionality.” That means it works. I would hope so.

最后，在最后，我们得到了一丝人性。公告的作者询问一位满意的客户为什么选择这个系统。该男子说他选择它是因为该公司的服务声誉。他说：“计算机就像一支精密的铅笔。你不关心它是如何工作的，但如果它坏了，你会希望有人来修理它。” 注意这句话在它前面的所有垃圾之后是多么令人耳目一新：在它的语言（舒适的词）中，在我们可以想象的细节（铅笔）中，在它的人性中。作者通过将其与我们都熟悉的经历联系起来，消除了技术过程中的冷漠：当东西坏了时等待修理工。我想起了我在纽约地铁看到的一个标志，它证明即使是一个庞大的市政官僚机构也可以人道地与其选民交谈：“如果你经常乘坐地铁，你可能会看到指示你去之前从未听说过的火车的标志。这些只是非常熟悉的火车的新名称。”

Finally, at the end, we get a glimmer of humanity. The writer of the bulletin asks a satisfied customer why he chose this system. The man says he chose it because of the company’s reputation for service. He says: “A computer is like a sophisticated pencil. You don’t care how it works, but if it breaks you want someone there to fix it.” Notice how refreshing that sentence is after all the garbage that preceded it: in its language (comfortable words), in its details that we can visualize (the pencil), and in its humanity. The writer has taken the coldness out of a technical process by relating it to an experience we’re all familiar with: waiting for the repairman when something breaks. I’m reminded of a sign I saw in the New York subway that proves that even a huge municipal bureaucracy can talk to its constituents humanely: “If you ride the subway regularly you may have seen signs directing you to trains you’ve never heard of before. These are only new names for very familiar trains.”

尽管如此，在美国企业界，坦诚相待并不容易。虚荣心太多就行了。每个级别的经理都深信简单的风格反映简单的想法。其实简单的风格是努力工作和思考的结果；糊涂的风格反映了一个糊涂的思想家或一个人太傲慢，太愚蠢，或者懒得组织他的思想。请记住，您所写的内容通常是您向需要您的业务、金钱或善意的人展示自己的唯一机会。如果你写的东西华丽、浮夸或模糊，人们就会这样看待你。读者别无选择。

Still, plain talk will not be easily achieved in corporate America. Too much vanity is on the line. Managers at every level are prisoners of the notion that a simple style reflects a simple mind. Actually a simple style is the result of hard work and hard thinking; a muddled style reflects a muddled thinker or a person too arrogant, or too dumb, or too lazy to organize his thoughts. Remember that what you write is often the only chance you’ll get to present yourself to someone whose business or money or good will you need. If what you write is ornate, or pompous, or fuzzy, that’s how you’ll be perceived. The reader has no other choice.

在格林威治之后，我通过冒险进入美国来了解美国公司，为一些大公司举办研讨会，这些公司也被要求去除术语。“我们甚至不再理解我们自己的备忘录了，”他们告诉我。我与撰写这些公司为内部和外部消费而产生的大量材料的男男女女一起工作。内部材料包括内部管风琴和时事通讯，其目的是告诉员工在他们的“工厂”发生的事情，并给他们一种归属感。外部材料包括发给股东的精美杂志和年度报告、高管发表的演讲、发给媒体的新闻稿，以及解释产品工作原理的消费者手册。我发现几乎所有的东西都缺乏人体汁液，而且大部分都难以穿透。

I learned about corporate America by venturing out into it, after Greenwich, to conduct workshops for some major corporations, which also asked to be dejargonized. “We don’t even understand our own memos anymore,” they told me. I worked with the men and women who write the vast amounts of material these companies generate for internal and external consumption. The internal material consists of house organs and newsletters whose purpose is to tell employees what’s happening at their “facility” and to give them a sense of belonging. The external material includes the glossy magazines and annual reports that go to stockholders, the speeches delivered by executives, the releases sent to the press, and the consumer manuals that explain how the product works. I found almost all of it lacking in human juices and much of it impenetrable.

时事通讯中的典型句子是：

Typical of the sentences in the newsletters was this one:

与上述增强功能同时宣布的是对系统支持计划的更改，该计划是与 NCP 一起运行的程序产品。额外的功能增强包括动态重新配置和系统间通信。

Announced concurrently with the above enhancements were changes to the System Support Program, a program product which operates in conjunction with the NCP. Among the additional functional enhancements are dynamic reconfiguration and inter-systems communications.

作者在这样的作品中没有乐趣，读者当然也没有。这是《星际迷航》中的语言，如果我是一名员工，我不会因这些提高士气的努力而感到高兴或被告知。我会停止阅读它们。我告诉企业撰稿人，他们必须找到所描述的卓越成就背后的人。“去找构思新系统的工程师，”我说，“或者去找设计它的设计师，或者去找组装它的技术​​人员，让他们用自己的话告诉你这个想法是怎么来的，或者他们如何将其组合在一起，或者现实世界中的真人将如何使用它。” 为任何机构预热的方法是找到丢失的“我”。请记住：“我”是任何故事中最有趣的元素。

There’s no joy for the writer in such work, and certainly none for the reader. It’s language out of Star Trek, and if I were an employee I wouldn’t be cheered—or informed—by these efforts to raise my morale. I would stop reading them.
