I told the corporate writers they had to find the people behind the fine achievements being described. “Go to the engineer who conceived the new system,” I said, “or to the designer who designed it, or to the technician who assembled it, and get them to tell you in their own words how the idea came to them, or how they put it together, or how it will be used by real people in the real world.” The way to warm up any institution is to locate the missing “I.” Remember: “I” is the most interesting element in any story.

编剧们解释说，他们确实经常采访这位工程师，但无法让他说英语。他们给我看了一些典型的引语。工程师们用一种晦涩难懂的语言说话，其中还夹杂着首字母缩略词（“子系统支持仅适用于 VSAG 或 TNA”）。我说编剧们必须不断地回到工程师那里，直到他终于让自己可以被理解为止。他们说工程师不想变得易于理解：如果他说得太简单，在同龄人看来他就是个混蛋。我说他们的责任是对事实和读者负责，而不是对工程师的虚荣心负责。我敦促他们相信自己是作家，不要放弃控制权。他们回答说，在等级森严的公司中，这说起来容易做起来难，在这种情况下，书面报告需要获得更高级别的连续批准。我感觉到一股恐惧的暗流：按照公司的方式做事，不要冒着工作风险试图让公司变得人性化。

The writers explained that they often did interview the engineer but couldn’t get him to talk English. They showed me some typical quotes. The engineers spoke in an arcane language studded with acronyms (“Sub-system support is available only with VSAG or TNA”). I said that the writers had to keep going back to the engineer until he finally made himself intelligible. They said the engineer didn’t want to be made intelligible: if he spoke too simply he would look like a jerk to his peers. I said that their responsibility was to the facts and to the reader, not to the vanity of the engineer. I urged them to believe in themselves as writers and not to relinquish control. They replied that this was easier said than done in hierarchical corporations, where approval of written reports is required at a succession of higher levels. I sensed an undercurrent of fear: do things the company way and don’t risk your job trying to make the company human.

高级管理人员同样因为想表现得重要而成为受害者。一家公司有一份每月通讯，使“管理层”能够与中层管理人员和基层员工分享其关注的问题。在每一期中，突出的是部门副总裁的劝告信息，我称他为托马斯贝尔。从他每月的信息来看，他是个自大的混蛋，什么都不说，而且用夸张的措辞说出来。

High executives were equally victimized by wanting to sound important. One corporation had a monthly newsletter to enable “management” to share its concerns with middle managers and lower employees. Prominent in every issue was a message of exhortation from the division vice-president, whom I’ll call Thomas Bell. Judging by his monthly message, he was a pompous ass, saying nothing and saying it in inflated verbiage.

当我提到这一点时，编剧们说托马斯·贝尔实际上是一个内向的人，也是一位优秀的管理者。他们指出信息不是他自己写的，而是他自己写的。这是为他写的。我说贝尔先生受到了伤害——编剧们应该每个月去找他（必要时带上录音机）并待在那里，直到他用回到家时使用的语言谈论他的担忧并与贝尔夫人交谈。

When I mentioned this, the writers said that Thomas Bell was actually a diffident man and a good executive. They pointed out that he doesn’t write the message himself; it’s written for him. I said that Mr. Bell was being done a disservice—that the writers should go to him every month (with a tape recorder, if necessary) and stay there until he talked about his concerns in the same language he would use when he got home and talked to Mrs. Bell.

我意识到，大多数美国高管不会写下他们签名上出现的内容或他们在演讲中所说的话。他们放弃了使他们独一无二的品质。如果他们和他们的机构看起来很冷淡，那是因为他们默许了被抽干的过程。他们全神贯注于高科技，忘记了他们拥有的一些最强大的工具——无论好坏——都是文字。

What I realized was that most executives in America don’t write what appears over their signature or what they say in their speeches. They have surrendered the qualities that make them unique. If they and their institutions seem cold, it’s because they acquiesce in the process of being pumped up and dried out. Preoccupied with their high technology, they forget that some of the most powerful tools they possess—for good and for bad—are words.

如果你在一个机构工作，无论你的工作是什么，无论你的水平是什么，当你写作的时候做你自己。你会在机器人中脱颖而出，你的榜样甚至可能说服托马斯贝尔写他自己的东西。

If you work for an institution, whatever your job, whatever your level, be yourself when you write. You will stand out as a real person among the robots, and your example might even persuade Thomas Bell to write his own stuff.

17

17

运动的

Sports

作为我童年时代的体育版迷，我在了解电路之前就了解了电路影响力。我了解到当他脚趾板时面朝左的投掷者（或旋转者）是左撇子或左撇子。Southpaws 总是瘦长的，左撇子总是矮胖的，虽然我从来没有听说过除了花生酱（以区别于“奶油”）之外的任何其他东西使用“矮胖”，而且我不知道矮胖的人会是什么样子。当投掷者发射旧马皮时，击球手会尝试解决他们的倾斜问题。如果他成功了，他可能会在外场用尖锐的短发说唱，为主队赢得一场胜利，或者至少打结计数。否则，他可能会卷入一场双杀，扼杀一场反弹，并让他的团队在争夺旗帜时的希望黯淡。

As an addict of the sports pages in my boyhood, I learned about the circuit clout before I learned about the electrical circuit. I learned that a hurler (or twirler) who faces left when he toes the slab is a southpaw or a portsider. Southpaws were always lanky, portsiders always chunky, though I’ve never heard “chunky” applied to anything else except peanut butter (to distinguish it from “creamy”), and I have no idea what a chunky person would look like. When hurlers fired the old horsehide, a batsman would try to solve their slants. If he succeeded he might rap a sharp bingle to the outfield, garnering a win for the home contingent, or at least knotting the count. If not, he might bounce into a twin killing, snuffing out a rally and dimming his team’s hopes in the flag scramble.

我可以继续，挖掘每项运动的行话，并从母语中提取各种在母语中找不到的单词。我可以写出 hoopsters 和 pucksters、grapplers 和 matmen、捆扎的划桨手和 gridiron 伟人。我可以狂热地赞美旧猪皮——比任何养猪户都更热情——并描述疯狂的看台上的人们沉浸在秋季经典的兴奋中。简而言之，我可以写体育英语而不是好的英语，就好像它们是两种不同的语言一样。他们不是。就像写科学或任何其他领域的文章一样，最好的东西是无可替代的。

I could go on, mining every sport for its lingo and extracting from the mother lode a variety of words found nowhere else in the mother tongue. I could write of hoopsters and pucksters, grapplers and matmen, strapping oarsmen and gridiron greats. I could rhapsodize about the old pigskin—more passionately than any pig farmer—and describe the frenzied bleacherites caught up in the excitement of the autumn classic. I could, in short, write sports English instead of good English, as if they were two different languages. They’re not. Just as in writing about science or any other field, there’s no substitute for the best.

你可能会问，“左撇子”有什么问题？难道我们不应该为如此如画的词而感恩吗？为什么拥有旋转器和电路影响力而不是相同的旧投手和本垒打不是一种解脱？答案是，这些文字已经成为比它们原本要取代的硬币更便宜的货币。他们自动地从每个记者席的每个抄写员（体育记者）的打字机里涌出来。

What, you might ask, is wrong with “southpaw”? Shouldn’t we be grateful for a word so picturesque? Why isn’t it a relief to have twirlers and circuit clouts instead of the same old pitchers and home runs? The answer is that these words have become even cheaper currency than the coins they were meant to replace. They come flooding automatically out of the typewriter of every scribe (sportswriter) in every press box.

第一个想到“左撇子”的人有权感到高兴。我喜欢认为他让自己微微一笑，这是任何发明新奇事物的人都应有的微笑。但那是多久以前的事了？“左撇子”为语言增添的色彩随着数十年的重复以及构成日常体育写作结构的数百种其他习语而黯然失色。他们令人厌倦。我们阅读文章是为了找出谁赢了，但我们并没有享受阅读它们。

The man who first thought of “southpaw” had a right to be pleased. I like to think he allowed himself the small smile that is the due of anyone who invents a good novelty. But how long ago was that? The color that “southpaw” added to the language has paled with decades of repetition, along with the hundreds of other idioms that form the fabric of daily sportswriting. There is a weariness about them. We read the articles to find out who won, but we don’t read them with enjoyment.

最好的体育记者知道这一点。他们避免用尽的同义词，并在句子的其他地方力求新鲜。你可以搜索 Red Smith 的专栏，永远找不到击球手跳进双胞胎杀戮；史密斯并不害怕让击球手打成双打。但是你会发现数百个不寻常的单词——好的英语单词——被精确地选择并适合其他体育记者不会使用它们的情况。他们让我们高兴，因为作者关心以新闻形式使用新鲜图像，而他的竞争对手则选择相同的旧内容。这就是为什么 Red Smith 在写作半个世纪后仍然是他所在领域的王者，也是为什么他的竞争对手早就被送去——正如他们会第一个说的那样——去淋浴。

The best sportswriters know this. They avoid the exhausted synonyms and strive for freshness elsewhere in their sentences. You can search the columns of Red Smith and never find a batsman bouncing into a twin killing; Smith wasn’t afraid to let a batter hit into a double play. But you will find hundreds of unusual words—good English words—chosen with precision and fitted into situations where no other sportswriter would put them. They please us because the writer cared about using fresh imagery in a journalistic form where his competitors settled for the same old stuff. That’s why Red Smith was still king of his field after half a century of writing, and why his competitors had long since been sent—as they would be the first to say—to the showers.

我仍然记得 Red Smith 专栏中的许多短语，它们的幽默和独创性让我大吃一惊。史密斯是一个虔诚的垂钓者，很高兴看到他用鱼钩上钩，钓上来那条滑溜溜的鱼，一位体育专员，喘着粗气。“在大多数职业体育运动中，最底层的人几乎已经退出沙皇行业，”他写道，并指出球队老板的贪婪往往会超过这项运动监督员的勇气。“第一个也是最强硬的 [棒球] 霸主是 Kenesaw Mountain Landis，他于 1920 年上台并以严厉的手段统治直到 1944 年去世。但是，如果棒球始于小凯撒，那么它将以未准备好的埃塞尔雷德结束。 ” 雷德史密斯是我们观点的日常守护者，一位让我们保持诚实的作家。但这主要是因为他的英语写得很好。他的风格不仅优雅；它足够强大，可以承载坚定的信念。

I can still remember many phrases in Red Smith’s columns that took me by surprise with their humor and originality. Smith was a devout angler, and it was a pleasure to watch him bait his hook and come up with that slippery fish, a sports commissioner, gasping for air. “In most professional sports the bottom has just about dropped out of the czar business,” he wrote, noting that the cupidity of team owners has a tendency to outrun the courage of the sport’s monitors. “The first and toughest of the [baseball] overlords was Kenesaw Mountain Landis, who came to power in 1920 and ruled with a heavy hand until his death in 1944. But if baseball started with Little Caesar, it wound up with Ethelred the Unready.” Red Smith was the daily guardian of our perspective, a writer who kept us honest. But that was largely because he was writing good English. His style was not only graceful; it was strong enough to carry strong convictions.

阻止大多数体育记者写出好英语的原因是他们误以为他们不应该尝试这样做。他们在如此多的陈词滥调中长大，以至于他们认为自己是交易所需的工具。他们还害怕重复读者最容易想象的词——击球手、跑步者、高尔夫球手、拳击手——如果可以找到同义词的话。通常，通过努力，它可以。大学报纸的这段摘录很典型：

What keeps most sportswriters from writing good English is the misapprehension that they shouldn’t be trying to. They have been reared on so many clichés that they assume they are the required tools of the trade. They also have a dread of repeating the word that’s easiest for the reader to visualize—batter, runner, golfer, boxer—if a synonym can be found. And usually, with exertion, it can. This excerpt from a college newspaper is typical:

Bob Hornsby 昨天以 6-4、6-2 击败达特茅斯学院的 Jerry Smithers 扩大了他的实力，带领网民战胜了一个出人意料的强敌。瘦长的小辈很好地利用了他的发球，使格林队长失去了平衡。这位孟菲斯本地人在前四场比赛中表现出色，在前四场比赛中两次打破了印第安人的发球局。这位埃克塞特大学的毕业生步履蹒跚，而汉诺威的中流砥柱在三场比赛中重振旗鼓。但是球拍王牌并没有被拒绝，当洋基队在第 6 个平分点被跨场凌空抽射超越时，洋基队试图将第一节打成 4-4 的尝试失败了。红发实在是太坚决了，而且……

Bob Hornsby extended his skein yesterday by toppling Dartmouth’s Jerry Smithers, 6–4, 6–2, to lead the netmen to victory over a surprisingly strong foe. The gangling junior put his big serve to good use in keeping the Green captain off balance. The Memphis native was in top form as he racked up the first four games, breaking the Indian’s service twice in the first four games. The Exeter graduate faltered and the Hanover mainstay rallied to cop three games. But the racquet ace was not to be denied, and the Yankee’s attempt to knot the first stanza at 4–4 failed when he was passed by a cross-court volley on the sixth deuce point. The redhead was simply too determined, and …

鲍勃·霍恩斯比后来怎么样了？还是杰瑞史密瑟斯？霍恩斯比在一段话中变身为瘦长的少年、孟菲斯本地人、埃克塞特毕业生、球拍王牌和红发女郎，而史密瑟斯则成为绿队队长、印第安人、汉诺威中流砥柱和洋基队。读者不会以这些不同的伪装认识他们——或关心他们。他们只想最清楚地了解发生的事情。永远不要害怕重复玩家的名字并保持细节简单。不必为了避免冗余而将一组或一局循环到节或框架中。治疗比疾病更糟糕。

What ever became of Bob Hornsby? Or Jerry Smithers? Hornsby has been metamorphosed within one paragraph into the gangling junior, the Memphis native, the Exeter graduate, the racquet ace and the redhead, and Smithers turns up as the Green captain, the Indian, the Hanover mainstay and the Yankee. Readers don’t know them in these various disguises—or care. They only want the clearest picture of what happened. Never be afraid to repeat the player’s name and to keep the details simple. A set or an inning doesn’t have to be recycled into a stanza or a frame just to avoid redundancy. The cure is worse than the ailment.

另一个痴迷是数字。每个运动迷都生活在满脑子的统计数据中，交叉归档以供随时访问，许多在学校不及格简单算术的棒球迷可以在球场上进行即时计算。不过，有些统计数据比其他统计数据更重要。如果一个投手赢得了他的第 20 场比赛，如果一个高尔夫球手打出 61 杆，如果一个跑步者在 3:48 跑完一英里，请提及。但不要得意忘形：

Another obsession is with numbers. Every sports addict lives with a head full of statistics, cross-filed for ready access, and many a baseball fan who flunked simple arithmetic in school can perform prodigies of instant calculation in the ballpark. Still, some statistics are more important than others. If a pitcher wins his 20th game, if a golfer shoots a 61, if a runner runs the mile in 3:48, please mention it. But don’t get carried away:

阿拉巴马州乌本，11 月 1 日（UPI）——奥本大学二年级四分卫帕特沙利文今天两次达阵并传球两次，佛罗里达队以 38-12 失利，这是排名第九的鳄鱼队本赛季的第一场失利。

AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 1 (UPI)—Pat Sullivan, Auburn’s sophomore quarterback, scored two touchdowns and passed for two today to hand Florida a 38–12 defeat, the first of the season for the ninth-ranked Gators.

佛罗里达州的 John Reaves 打破了两项东南联盟的记录并追平了一项。这位来自佛罗里达州坦帕市的高大二年级学生获得了 369 码的传球码数，使他的六场比赛赛季总数达到 2,115 码。这打破了 1966 年海斯曼奖杯获得者在 10 场比赛中创下的 2,012 场 SEC 赛季纪录。

John Reaves of Florida broke two Southeastern Conference records and tied another. The tall sophomore from Tampa, Fla., gained 369 yards passing, pushing his six-game season total to 2,115. That broke the S.E.C. season record of 2,012 set by the 1966 Heisman trophy winner, in 10 games.

Reaves 尝试了 66 次传球——这是 SEC 的记录——并追平了今年秋天由密西西比州的 Archie Manning 创下的 33 次传球纪录。

Reaves attempted 66 passes—an S.E.C. record—and tied the record of 33 completions set this fall by Mississippi’s Archie Manning.

对 Auburn 来说幸运的是，Reaves 的 9 次传球被拦截——打破了 1951 年佐治亚州 Zeke Bratkowski 对阵佐治亚理工学院时 8 次拦截的 SEC 记录。

Fortunately for Auburn, nine of Reaves’s passes were intercepted—breaking the S.E.C. record of eight interceptions suffered by Georgia’s Zeke Bratkowski against Georgia Tech in 1951.

里维斯的表现让他距离美国证券交易委员会赛季总进攻记录 2,187 仅差几码，该记录由佐治亚州的弗兰克辛克维奇在 1942 年的 11 场比赛中创下。他在对阵奥本的比赛中两次达阵传球让他只比美国证券交易委员会赛季记录 23 次达阵传球少了一次。由肯塔基州的 Babe Parilli 设定于 1950 年……

Reaves’s performance left him only a few yards short of the S.E.C. season total offense record of 2,187 set by Georgia’s Frank Sinkwich in 11 games in 1942. And his two touchdown passes against Auburn left him only one touchdown pass short of the S.E.C. season record of 23 set in 1950 by Kentucky’s Babe Parilli …

这是一篇六段故事的前五段，该故事刊登在我的纽约报纸上，距离奥本很远。它有一种越来越大的欢闹——一个对打字机发狂的人物形象。但是有人能读懂吗？有人关心吗？只有 Zeke Bratkowski——终于摆脱了困境。

Those are the first five paragraphs of a six-paragraph story that was prominently displayed in my New York newspaper, a long way from Auburn. It has a certain mounting hilarity—a figure freak amok at his typewriter. But can anybody read it? And does anybody care? Only Zeke Bratkowski—finally off the hook.

体育是现在对非虚构作家开放的最富有的领域之一。许多以“严肃”书籍而闻名的作家作为竞技比赛的观察员完成了一些最扎实的工作。John McPhee 的游戏水平，George Plimpton 的纸狮子和 George F. Will 的工作人员——关于网球、职业橄榄球和棒球的书籍——带我们深入了解球员的生活。就细节而言，他们有足够的信息让任何粉丝开心。但让他们与众不同的是他们的人性。这只奇怪的鸟是谁，获胜的运动员，是什么引擎让他继续前进？棒球文学中的经典之作之一是“Hub Fans Bid Kid Adieu”，这是约翰·厄普代克 (John Updike) 对泰德·威廉姆斯 (Ted Williams) 在 1960 年 9 月 28 日的最后一场比赛的记述，当时这位 42 岁的“小子”最后一次出场在芬威球场击球时，击中一球翻墙。但在此之前，厄普代克已经提炼出“这个易怒且脾气暴躁的球员”的精髓：

Sports is one of the richest fields now open to the nonfiction writer. Many authors better known for “serious” books have done some of their most solid work as observers of athletic combat. John McPhee’s Levels of the Game, George Plimpton’s Paper Lion and George F. Will’s Men at Work—books about tennis, pro football and baseball—take us deeply into the lives of the players. In mere detail they have enough information to keep any fan happy. But what makes them special is their humanity. Who is this strange bird, the winning athlete, and what engines keep him going? One of the classics in the literature of baseball is “Hub Fans Bid Kid Adieu,” John Updike’s account of Ted Williams’s final game, on September 28, 1960, when the 42-year-old “Kid,” coming up for his last time at bat in Fenway Park, hit one over the wall. But before that Updike has distilled the essence of “this brittle and temperamental player”:

……在所有团队运动中，棒球以其优雅的间歇动作、广阔而宁静的场地稀疏地安置着泰然自若的白衣人、冷静的数学，在我看来最适合容纳孤独者并由其装饰。它本质上是一个孤独的游戏。在我们这一代人中，没有其他球员能如此专注于这项运动的精髓，如此孜孜不倦地提高他的自然技能，如此不断地把那种强度的能力带到盘子里，让喜悦塞满喉咙。

… of all team sports, baseball, with its graceful intermittences of action, its immense and tranquil field sparsely settled with poised men in white, its dispassionate mathematics, seems to me best suited to accommodate, and be ornamented by, a loner. It is essentially a lonely game. No other player visible to my generation has concentrated within himself so much of the sport’s poignance, has so assiduously refined his natural skills, has so constantly brought to the plate that intensity of competence that crowds the throat with joy.

这篇文章之所以有深度，是因为它是作家的作品，而不是体育记者的作品。厄普代克知道威廉姆斯在本垒板的无与伦比的能力没有太多可说的了：著名的挥杆，可以看到以每小时 90 英里的速度到达的球上缝线的眼睛。但这个人的谜团仍未解开，即使在他职业生涯的最后一天，这也是厄普代克引起我们注意的地方，暗示棒球适合这样一个隐居的明星，因为它是一项孤独的运动。棒球寂寞？我们伟大的美国部落仪式？想想看，厄普代克说。

What gives the article its depth is that it’s the work of a writer, not a sportswriter. Updike knows there’s not much more to say about Williams’s matchless ability at the plate: the famous swing, the eyes that could see the stitches on a ball arriving at 90 miles an hour. But the mystery of the man is still unsolved, even on the final day of his career, and that’s where Updike steers our attention, suggesting that baseball was suited to such a reclusive star because it’s a lonely game. Baseball lonely? Our great American tribal rite? Think about it, Updike says.

厄普代克身上的某些东西与威廉姆斯身上的某些东西发生了联系：两个孤独的工匠在人群的注视下劳作。寻找这种人际关系。请记住，运动员是男人和女人，他们在赛季中成为我们生活的一部分，实现我们的梦想或满足我们的其他需求，我们希望这种联系得到尊重。保持炒作，给我们可信的英雄。

Something in Updike made contact with something in Williams: two solitary craftsmen laboring in the glare of the crowd. Look for this human bond. Remember that athletes are men and women who become part of our lives during the season, acting out our dreams or filling some other need for us, and we want that bond to be honored. Hold the hype and give us heroes who are believable.

在罗伯特·克里默 (Robert Creamer) 的精彩传记《宝贝》中，甚至贝比·鲁斯 (Babe Ruth) 也被从奥林匹斯山经过消毒的斜坡上带下来，变成了一个真实的人，胃口和他的腰围一样大。同样的品质将出现在克里默后来的书《斯坦格尔》中。在那之前，读者心甘情愿地接受 Casey Stengel 的标准版本作为一个年迈的马裤，他破坏了语言并以某种方式赢得了 10 个锦旗。克里默的斯坦格尔更有趣：一个复杂的人，谁也不是傻子，他的故事很像棒球本身的故事，可以追溯到 19 世纪的美国农村。

Even Babe Ruth was ushered down from the sanitized slopes of Olympus and converted into a real person, with appetites as big as his girth, in Robert Creamer’s fine biography Babe. The same qualities would go into Creamer’s later book, Stengel. Until then readers willingly settled for the standard version of Casey Stengel as an aging pantaloon who mangled the language and somehow managed to win 10 pennants. Creamer’s Stengel is far more interesting: a complex man who was nobody’s fool and whose story is very much the story of baseball itself, stretching back to 19th-century rural America.

在曾经的童话世界中，真实的肖像画只是众多新现实中的一个。体育现在是社会变革的主要前沿，一些国家最棘手的问题——药物滥用和类固醇、人群暴力、妇女权利、管理层中的少数群体、电视合同——正在我们的体育场、看台和更衣室上演。如果你想写关于美国的文章，这是一个你可以搭帐篷的地方。仔细看看学校和大学运动员的财务诱惑等故事。这不仅仅是一个体育故事。这是关于我们的价值观和我们在孩子教育方面的优先事项的故事。King Football 和 King Basketball 稳坐宝座。有多少教练的薪水超过大学校长、校长和教师？

Honest portraiture is only one of many new realities in what used to be a fairy-tale world. Sport is now a major frontier of social change, and some of the nation’s most vexing issues—drug abuse and steroids, crowd violence, women’s rights, minorities in management, television contracts—are being played out in our stadiums, grandstands and locker rooms. If you want to write about America, this is one place to pitch your tent. Take a hard look at such stories as the financial seduction of school and college athletes. It’s far more than a sports story. It’s the story of our values and our priorities in the education of our children. King Football and King Basketball sit secure on their throne. How many coaches get paid more than the college president, the school principal and the teachers?

金钱是美国体育中若隐若现的怪物，它的阴影无处不在。高得离谱的薪水在体育版块中穿梭，现在它包含的财经新闻几乎与金融版块一样多。在比分之前，故事的开头会提到一名球员因赢得高尔夫球或网球比赛而赚了多少钱。大笔的钱也带来了很大的感情麻烦。今天的大部分体育报道与体育无关。首先，我们必须被告知谁的感情受到了伤害，因为他被球迷嘘声，他们认为一个 1200 万美元的球员应该击球高于 0.225 并且在飞球击中他的方向后跑。在网球运动中，金罐是巨大的，球员们就像他们的高科技球拍一样紧紧地系在一起——百万富翁们很快就会发牢骚，咒骂裁判和边裁。

Money is the looming monster in American sport, its dark shadow everywhere. Salaries of obscene magnitude swim through the sports section, which now contains almost as much financial news as the financial section. How much money a player earned for winning a golf or tennis tournament is mentioned in the lead of the story, ahead of the score. Big money has also brought big emotional trouble. Much of today’s sports reporting has nothing to do with sport. First we have to be told whose feelings are hurt because he’s being booed by fans who think a $12 million player ought to bat higher than .225 and run after fly balls hit in his direction. In tennis the pot of gold is huge and the players are strung as tightly as their high-tech racquets—millionaires quick to whine and to swear at the referee and the linesmen. In football and basketball the pay is sky-high, and so are the sulks.

现代运动员的自我意识反过来影响了现代体育记者。我对现在有多少体育记者认为他们是故事，他们的想法比他们被派去报道的游戏更有趣。我怀念那些记者可以谦虚地直截了当地说谁赢了的日子。今天，这个消息可能要等很长时间才能到达。一半的体育记者认为他们是居伊·德·莫泊桑 (Guy de Maupassant)，精通延迟领先。其他人则认为他们是西格蒙德弗洛伊德，知道运动员的心理需求和受伤的情感。有些人还在一边练习整形外科和关节镜手术，比队医更快地评估磁共振成像扫描显示或未显示投手肩袖撕裂或未撕裂的内容。“他的情况是日常的，”他们总结道。谁的条件不是？

The ego of the modern athlete has in turn rubbed off on the modern sportswriter. I’m struck by how many sportswriters now think they are the story, their thoughts more interesting than the game they were sent to cover. I miss the days when reporters had the modesty to come right out and say who won. Today that news can be a long time in arriving. Half the sportswriters think they are Guy de Maupassant, masters of the exquisitely delayed lead. The rest think they are Sigmund Freud, privy to the athlete’s psychic needs and wounded sensibilities. Some also practice orthopedics and arthroscopic surgery on the side, quicker than the team physician to assess what the magnetic resonance imaging scan revealed or didn’t reveal about the pitcher’s torn or perhaps not torn rotator cuff. “His condition is day-to-day,” they conclude. Whose condition isn’t?

想成为莫泊桑的人专注于更早发生的情节，他们通过在俱乐部会所闲逛以寻找“色彩”来收集这些情节。如果它能融入那座巴洛克式的大厦，领导者，那么任何金块都不会太琐碎或太无聊。下面的例子是我发明的，但每个粉丝都会认出这种类型：

The would-be Maupassants specialize in episodes that took place earlier, which they gleaned by hanging around the clubhouse in search of “color.” No nugget is too trivial or too boring if it can be cemented into that baroque edifice, the lead. The following example is one that I’ll invent, but every fan will recognize the genre:

两周前亚历克斯罗德里格斯的祖母做了一个梦。她告诉他，她梦见他和他的一些洋基队队友去中国餐馆吃饭。到了甜点时间，罗德里格斯让服务员给他拿来一块幸运饼干。“有时候这些事情真的可以直接告诉你，”他的祖母说他告诉德里克杰特。拆开信纸，只见上面写着：“你很快就会做一件震慑敌人的大事。”

Two weeks ago Alex Rodriguez’s grandmother had a dream. She told him she dreamed he and some of his Yankee teammates went to a Chinese restaurant for dinner. When it came time for dessert, Rodriguez asked the waiter to bring him a fortune cookie. “Sometimes those things can really tell it to you straight,” his grandmother said he told Derek Jeter. Unwrapping the paper message, he saw the words: “You will soon do something powerful to confound your enemies.”

也许 A-Rod 昨晚在洋基体育场走上本垒板面对红袜队的王牌 Curt Schilling 时正在想着他祖母的梦想。2004 年，他在对阵席林的比赛中 27 投 3 中，陷入了本赛季最长的低迷期。没有人必须告诉他粉丝们支持他；他听到了嘘声。这将是迷惑他的敌人的最佳时机。这是第八局的底部，两名男子上场，红袜队以 3-1 领先。时间不多了。

Maybe A-Rod was thinking of his grandmother’s dream last night at Yankee Stadium when he stepped to the plate to face Red Sox ace Curt Schilling. He was 3-for-27 against Schilling in 2004 and was mired in his longest slump of the season. Nobody had to tell him the fans were on his case; he had heard the boos. This would be the perfect moment to confound his enemies. It was the bottom of the eighth, two men were on, and the Sox were leading, 3–1. Time was running out.

数完之后，Rodriguez 从 Schilling 那里得到了一个齐腰高的滑球，然后把它咬碎了。球以高弧度上升，你只要看 A-Rod 就知道他认为球可能会传到左外野的座位上。一股强风吹进了体育场，但幸运饼干的“强大力量”不容否认，当马里亚诺里维拉在第九局上半场击败红袜队时，记分牌显示洋基队 4 分，波士顿 3 分。谢谢，奶奶.

Working the count full, Rodriguez got a waist-high slider from Schilling and crunched it. The ball rose in a high arc, and you knew just by watching A-Rod that he thought the ball might carry to the left-field seats. A strong wind was swirling into the Stadium, but the fortune cookie’s “something powerful” was not to be denied, and when Mariano Rivera shut down the Sox in the top of the ninth, the scoreboard said Yankees 4, Boston 3. Thanks, Granny.

想要成为弗洛伊德主义者的人同样渴望在安定下来之前大摇大摆。“在安德烈·阿加西 (André Agassiz) 昨天出庭对抗比他小 20 岁的敌人之前，应该有人告诉他他否认死亡，”他们写道，人类动机方面的专家，使用了诸如“可预测的徒劳”之类的词——这在记者的词汇中并不合适- 以显示他们对劣势运动员的优势。“昨晚大都会队上场，决心找到另一种荒谬的输球方式，”为我当地报纸报道那支球队的记者不断告诉我，通常是在最近的一个淡季，用讽刺而不是事实。大都会队没有这样做；没有运动员打算输。如果你想写体育，请记住你所写的男人和女人正在做着极其困难的事情，他们有自己的骄傲。你也是，正在做一份有其荣誉准则的工作。其中之一是你不是故事。

The would-be Freuds are no less eager to swagger before settling down. “Somebody should have told André Agassiz he was into mortality denial before he took the court yesterday against a foe 20 years his junior,” they write, experts in human motivation, using words like “predictably futile”—no proper part of a reporter’s vocabulary—to show their superiority over an athlete having an inferior day. “Last night the Mets took the field determined to find another ridiculous way to lose,” the reporter covering that team for my local paper kept telling me, typically, during a recent lean season, using sarcasm instead of fact. The Mets did no such thing; no athlete sets out to lose. If you want to write about sports, remember that the men and women you’re writing about are doing something immensely difficult, and they have their pride. You, too, are doing a job that has its codes of honor. One of them is that you are not the story.

Red Smith 对自我重要的体育写作没有耐心。他说，记住棒球是小男孩玩的游戏总是有帮助的。这也适用于足球、篮球、曲棍球、网球和大多数其他比赛。曾经玩过这些游戏的小男孩和小女孩长大后成为体育版的读者，在他们的想象中，他们还年轻，还在球场上、球场上和溜冰场上，还在玩那些游戏。他们翻开报纸想知道的是球员们打得怎么样，比赛结果如何。请告诉我们。

Red Smith had no patience with self-important sportswriting. He said it was always helpful to remember that baseball is a game that little boys play. That also goes for football and basketball and hockey and tennis and most other games. The little boys—and girls—who once played those games grow up to be readers of the sports pages, and in their imagination they are still young, still on the field and the court and the rink, still playing those games. What they want to know when they open their newspaper is how the players played and how the game came out. Please tell us.

体育记者的一个新角色是让我们知道实际进行一项运动的感觉：成为马拉松运动员或足球守门员、滑雪者或高尔夫球手或体操运动员。时机已经成熟——人们对身体能被推到多远的兴趣空前高涨。美国人正在健身，在健身器材上保持健康，校准体重增加和减轻、肺摄入量和心脏压力的每一个细微差别。对于非小说类作家来说，这些周末勇士提供了全新的读者群：既是休闲运动员又是体育迷，渴望被放在运动员的头上。

One new role for the sportswriter is to let us know what it feels like to actually perform a sport: to be a marathon runner or a soccer goalie, a skier or a golfer or a gymnast. The moment is ripe—popular interest in how far the body can be pushed has never been higher. Americans are on a health kick, keeping fit on fitness machines, calibrating every nuance of weight gain and weight loss, pulmonary intake and cardiac stress. For a nonfiction writer these weekend warriors provide a whole new readership: sports fans who are also recreational sportsmen, eager to be put inside the head of athletes at the top of their form.

高速是许多运动的核心快感，是普通凡人只能尝试想象的典型感觉。作为经常以每小时 65 英里的速度摇晃的汽车的车主，我从来没有接近了解驾驶赛车的感觉。我需要一位作家莱斯利·黑兹尔顿 (Lesley Hazleton) 将我绑在一级方程式赛车的座位上。“每当我开快车时，”她写道，“我就会意识到我违反了自然法则，开得比我的身体设计的速度还快。” 这种意识并没有真正开始，Hazleton 说，直到驾驶员体验到 g 力，一种“以如此大的压力作用于你的外部力量，似乎你的身体先移动，你的内心紧随其后”：

High speed, a central thrill of many sports, is typical of the sensations that ordinary mortals can only try to imagine. As the owner of cars that tend to shake at 65 miles per hour, I’ve never come close to knowing how it feels to drive a racing car. I needed a writer, Lesley Hazleton, to strap me into the seat of a Formula One vehicle. “Whenever I drive fast,” she writes, “there is an awareness that I am in transgression of the laws of nature, moving faster than my body was designed to move.” This awareness doesn’t truly begin, Hazleton says, until a driver experiences the g-force, an outside force that “works on you with such pressure that it seems as though your body is moved first and your insides follow after”:

赛车手要应对巨大的重力，以至于他们要承受三到四倍于正常重力的重力。从静止起步，一级方程式赛车将在不到三秒的时间内达到每小时一百英里。就在那一秒里，司机的头被猛烈地向后推，他的脸都肿了起来，露出了一个鬼魅般的微笑。

Race drivers contend with g-forces so great that they are subject to three or four times the normal force of gravity. From a standing start, a Formula One car will reach a hundred miles an hour in just under three seconds. And in that first second the driver’s head is pushed back so violently that his face distends, giving him a ghostly smile.

一秒钟之内，他换了两次档，每次换档，加速力都会把他重新撞回座位。三秒钟后，从每小时一百英里加速到两百英里，他的周边视线完全模糊了。他只能直视前方。800 马力的发动机发出 130 分贝的尖叫声，每个活塞每分钟完成 4 个燃烧循环 10,000 次，这意味着他感受到的震动就是那个频率。

Within another second he has changed gears twice, and each time he does so, the acceleration force smashes him back into the seat again. After three seconds, accelerating upward from a hundred miles an hour toward two hundred, his peripheral vision is completely blurred. He can only see straight ahead. The 800-horsepower engine is screaming at 130 decibels, and each piston completes four combustion cycles 10,000 times a minute, which means that the vibration he feels is at that rate.

他的颈部和肩部肌肉承受着巨大的压力，当重力将他的头从角落里的一侧推到另一侧时，他试图保持眼睛水平。强烈的加速度使血液在他的腿部积聚，从而减少输送到心脏的血液，这意味着心输出量减少，迫使脉搏加快。一级方程式车手的脉搏通常高达 180，甚至 200，并且他们几乎在两小时的比赛的整个过程中都保持在最大值的 85%。

His neck and shoulder muscles are under immense strain, trying to keep his eyes level as the g-force pushes his head from side to side in the corners. The strong acceleration makes blood pool in his legs so that less is delivered to the heart, which means that there’s less cardiac output, forcing the pulse rate up. Formula One drivers’ pulses are often up to 180, even 200, and they stay at 85 percent of that maximum for almost the entire length of a two-hour race.

当肌肉需要更多的血液时呼吸会加快——速度真的会让你喘不过气来——整个身体进入紧急状态。两个小时的紧急情况。每次心跳正常时，汽车都会行驶一个足球场那么长，口干舌燥，眼睛睁大。大脑以惊人的速度处理信息，因为速度越高，反应时间就越短。反应不仅要快，而且要非常精确，无论身体承受多大的压力。瞬间可能只是时间的碎片，但它们也是比赛输赢或进入和避免撞车之间的区别。

Breathing quickens as the muscles call for more blood—speed literally takes your breath away—and the whole body goes into emergency stance. A two-hour emergency. The mouth goes dry, the eyes dilate as the car travels the length of a football field for every normal heartbeat. The brain processes information at an astonishingly rapid rate, since the higher the speed, the less the reaction time. Reactions have to be not only quick but also extraordinarily precise, no matter how great the physical strain. Split seconds may be mere slivers of time, but they are also the difference between winning and losing a race, or between entering and avoiding a crash.

简而言之，一级方程式赛车手必须在承受最大身体压力的情况下保持近乎超自然的警觉。显然，肾上腺素在飙升……但除了顶级运动员的身体素质，他还需要棋手的头脑，吸收遥测数据，计算超车点，执行赛车策略。所有这些就是为什么速度对我们大多数人来说如此危险：我们根本没有体力和精神耐力来应对它。

In short, a Formula One driver has to be almost preternaturally alert under conditions of maximum physical pressure. Obviously, the adrenaline is pumping.... But in addition to the physical fitness of top athletes, he needs that chess player’s mind as he assimilates telemetry data, calculates overtaking points, and executes a racing strategy. All of which is why speed is so dangerous for most of us: we simply have neither the physical nor the mental stamina to handle it.

从心理上讲，比赛中发生的事情更加复杂。肌肉、大脑化学物质、物理定律、振动、比赛条件——所有这些结合在一起，在身体中产生高度的兴奋和紧张，让车手感到绝对清醒和警觉。而且高。

Psychologically, what happens in a race is still more complex. The muscles, the brain chemicals, the laws of physics, the vibration, the conditions of the race—all these combine to generate a high level of excitement and tension in the body, making the driver feel absolutely clearheaded and alert. And high.

尽管 Hazleton 一直使用“他的”——他的肌肉、他的眼睛、他的腿——她文章的代词应该是“她”。在当今体育和体育新闻业的所有侵蚀中，她代表了一个巨大的收获：女性成为优秀的运动员，通常在以前由男性垄断的草坪上，作为记者可以平等地进入男性更衣室和新闻业的其他常规权利. 考虑一下其中一位作家 Janice Kaplan 在以下文章中所体现的多种进步——无论是在表现上还是在态度上：

Although Hazleton keeps using “his”—his muscles, his eyes, his legs—the pronoun for her article should be “her.” Amid all the erosions in sports and sports journalism today, she represents one huge gain: the emergence of women as fine athletes, often on turf previously monopolized by men, and as reporters with equal access to male locker rooms and the other routine rights of journalism. Consider the many kinds of progress—both in performance and in attitude—embodied in the following piece by one of those writers, Janice Kaplan:

要了解女性在体育运动中的表现如何，你必须了解她们在十年前有多糟糕。在 70 年代初期，争论的焦点不是女性在运动方面能做多少，而是一个普通女性是否应该参加运动。

To understand how good women have become in sports, you have to understand how bad they were just a decade ago. In the early ’70s the debate wasn’t how much women could do athletically, but whether a normal woman should be athletic at all.

例如，据说马拉松对儿童、老人和妇女不利。令人生畏的波士顿马拉松赛直到 1972 年才正式对女性关闭。那一年，尼娜·库西克 (Nina Kuscsik) 与性别歧视和中途腹泻作斗争，成为女子组的第一位冠军。我们这些知道这件事的人感到一阵骄傲，夹杂着一丝尴尬。骄傲，因为 Kuscsik 的胜利证明女性毕竟可以跑 26 英里。尴尬，因为她三个小时十分钟的时间，比最好的男人的时间还慢了五十多分钟。五十分钟。这是赛车行话中的永恒。显而易见的解释是，女性以前很少跑过马拉松，而且缺乏训练和经验。一个显而易见的解释——但谁真的相信呢？

Marathoning, for example, was said to be bad for children, for the elderly and for women. The formidable Boston Marathon was officially closed to women until 1972. That year Nina Kuscsik battled sexism and a mid-race bout with diarrhea to become the first winner of the women’s division. Those of us who knew about it felt a surge of pride, mixed with a tinge of embarrassment. Pride, because Kuscsik’s victory proved that women could run 26 miles after all. Embarrassment, because her time of three hours and ten minutes was more than 50 minutes slower than the best men’s times. Fifty minutes. That’s an eternity in racing lingo. The obvious explanation was that women had rarely run marathons before and lacked training and experience. An obvious explanation—but who really believed it?

快闪到今年。女子马拉松将首次成为奥运会比赛项目。Joan Benoit 可能是最大的竞争对手之一，她目前保持着女子世界纪录——2 小时 22 分钟。自第一位女子在波士顿参加比赛以来的十几年里，女子最佳成绩提高了大约 50 分钟。另一个永恒。

Flash ahead to this year. For the first time, the women’s marathon will be an Olympic event. One of the top competitors is likely to be Joan Benoit, who holds the current women’s world record—two hours and 22 minutes. In the dozen years since the first woman raced in Boston, the best women’s times have improved by about 50 minutes. Another eternity.

男子在马拉松比赛中的成绩同时只提高了几分钟，所以这一显着的进步应该开始回答训练与荷尔蒙的问题：女性比男性慢和虚弱是因为内在的生物学差异——还是因为文化偏见以及我们没有机会证明我们能做什么的事实？......男女之间的差距是否会完全消失似乎几乎无关紧要。重要的是，女性正在做她们做梦也想不到的事情——认真对待自己和自己的身体。

Men’s times in the marathon have meanwhile improved by only a few minutes, so this dramatic progress should begin to answer the question of training vs. hormones: Are women slower and weaker than men because of built-in biological differences—or because of cultural bias and the fact that we haven’t been given a chance to prove what we can do? … Whether the gap between men and women will ever be totally closed seems almost beside the point. What matters is that women are doing what they never dreamed they could do—taking themselves and their bodies seriously.

这场改变意识的革命中的一个关键事件是 20 世纪 70 年代中期比利简金和鲍比里格斯之间的网球比赛。“它被标榜为两性之战，”卡普兰在另一篇文章中回忆道，“事实确实如此。”

A pivotal event in this revolution of altered consciousness was the mid-1970s tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs. “It was billed as the battle of the sexes,” Kaplan recalls in another article, “and it was.”

可能从未有过一项体育赛事与体育无关，而与社会问题有关。这场比赛的大问题是女性：我们属于哪里，我们能做什么。忘记最高法院的判决和 ERA 投票；我们指望两位运动员以真正重要的方式解决女性平等问题。在体育运动中，一切都是明确而具体的。有赢家也有输家；没有辩论。

There has probably never been a sporting event that was less about sports and more about social issues. The big issue in this match was women: where we belonged and what we could do. Forget Supreme Court decisions and ERA votes; we looked to two athletes to settle the issues of equality for women in a way that really mattered. In sports, all is writ large and writ in concrete. There is a winner and a loser; there is no debate.

对于许多女性来说，比利·简的胜利让她们有一种个人的胜利感。它似乎释放了全国女性的能量。年轻女性要求——也得到了——在大学体育中发挥更大的作用。许多职业运动中女性的奖金飙升。小女孩们开始玩少年棒球联盟，加入男队，证明男女之间的生理差异并没有想象中那么大。

For many women there was a sense of personal triumph in Billie Jean’s victory. It seemed to release an energy in women all over the country. Young women demanded—and got—a greater role in college sports. Prize money for women in many professional sports soared. Little girls began playing Little League, joining boys’ teams, proving that the physiological differences between males and females aren’t as great as they were once imagined.

美国体育一直与社会历史交织在一起，最好的作家是建立这种联系的男人和女人。“让篮球成为避税演艺圈不是我的主意，”比尔布拉德利在Life on the Run中写道，这是他在纽约尼克斯队的赛季编年史。前参议员布拉德利的书是现代体育写作的一个很好的例子，因为它思考了一些正在改变美国体育的破坏性力量——老板的贪婪、对明星的崇拜、无法接受失败：

American sport has always been interwoven with social history, and the best writers are men and women who make the connection. “It wasn’t my idea for basketball to become tax-shelter show biz,” Bill Bradley writes in Life on the Run, a chronicle of his seasons with the New York Knicks. Ex-Senator Bradley’s book is a good example of modern sportswriting because it ponders some of the destructive forces that are altering American sport—the greed of owners, the worship of stars, the inability to accept defeat:

范离开后，我意识到，无论老板们多么友善、友好和真诚，大多数球员对他们来说最终不过是贬值资产。

After Van’s departure I realized that no matter how kind, friendly and genuinely interested the owners may be, in the end most players are little more than depreciable assets to them.

自我定义来自外部资源，而不是来自内部。当他们的身体技能持续存在时，职业运动员就是名人——被爱抚和原谅，被赞扬和相信。只有在他们职业生涯的末期，明星们才意识到他们的认同感是不够的。

Self-definition comes from external sources, not from within. While their physical skill lasts, professional athletes are celebrities—fondled and excused, praised and believed. Only toward the end of their careers do the stars realize that their sense of identity is insufficient.

获胜的球队就像征服者的军队一样，夺取了前进道路上的一切，似乎在说只有胜利才是最重要的。然而，胜利的意义非常狭隘，可以成为一种破坏性的力量。失败的滋味本身就是一种丰富的体验。

The winning team, like the conquering army, claims everything in its path and seems to say that only winning is important. Yet victory has very narrow meanings and can become a destructive force. The taste of defeat has a richness of experience all its own.

布拉德利的书也是一本出色的旅行日记，捕捉了职业运动员游牧生活的疲劳和孤独——无数的夜间航班和公共汽车，沉闷的日子以及在汽车旅馆房间和航站楼无休止的等待：“在已经成为我们通勤者的机场在车站，我们看到太多戏剧性的个人时刻，以至于我们都变得老茧了。对某些人来说，我们过着浪漫的生活。对我来说，每一天都在努力与生活的微妙之处保持联系。”

Bradley’s book is also an excellent travel journal, catching the fatigue and loneliness of the professional athlete’s nomadic life—the countless night flights and bus rides, the dreary days and endless waits in motel rooms and terminals: “In the airports that have become our commuter stations we see so many dramatic personal moments that we are callused. To some, we live romantic lives. To me, every day is a struggle to stay in touch with life’s subtleties.”

这些是您在撰写体育文章时要寻找的价值观：人物和地点、时间和过渡。这是一份令人愉快的清单，列出了每项运动都配备了什么样的人。它来自 GFT Ryall 的讣告，他以笔名 Audax Minor 为《纽约客》报道了纯种赛车，半个多世纪以来，直到他 92 岁去世前几个月。讣告说 Ryall“开始知道每个与赛马有关的人——马主、饲养员、管家、裁判、计时员、穆图尔职员、平克顿、驯马师、厨师、马夫、障碍赛手、热行者、发令员、音乐家、骑师和他们的代理人、兜售者、豪赌客和锡喇叭。 ”

Those are the values to look for when you write about sport: people and places, time and transition. Here’s an enjoyable list of the kind of people every sport comes furnished with. It’s from the obituary of G. F. T. Ryall, who covered thoroughbred racing for The New Yorker, under the pen name Audax Minor, for more than half a century, until a few months before he died at 92. The obituary said that Ryall “came to know everyone connected with racing—owners, breeders, stewards, judges, timers, mutuel clerks, Pinkertons, trainers, cooks, grooms, handicappers, hot-walkers, starters, musicians, jockeys and their agents, touts, high-rolling gamblers and tinhorns.”

在跑道和马厩、体育场和溜冰场周围闲逛。仔细观察。深度访谈。听老前辈的。思考变化。写得好。

Hang around the track and the stable, the stadium and the rink. Observe closely. Interview in depth. Listen to old-timers. Ponder the changes. Write well.

18

18

写艺术

Writing About the Arts

评论家和专栏作家

Critics and Columnists

艺术无处不在，每天都在丰富我们的生活，无论是我们自己表演——表演、舞蹈、绘画、写诗、演奏乐器——还是去音乐厅、剧院、博物馆和画廊寻找它们。我们还想阅读有关艺术的书籍：无论艺术在哪里创作，都能与当今的文化潮流保持联系。

The arts are all around us, a daily enrichment of our lives, whether we perform them ourselves—acting, dancing, painting, writing poetry, playing an instrument—or seek them out in concert halls and theaters and museums and galleries. We also want to read about the arts: to be kept in touch with the cultural currents of the day, wherever art is being made.

完成这项工作的一些写作是新闻性的——采访新的交响乐团指挥，与建筑师或策展人一起参观新博物馆——它需要与本书讨论的其他形式相同的方法。写新博物馆是如何设计、融资和建造的，在原则上与解释伊拉克人是如何差点制造出原子弹没有什么不同。

Some of the writing that accomplishes that job is journalistic—the interview with the new symphony orchestra conductor, the tour of the new museum with its architect or its curator—and it calls for the same methods as the other forms discussed in this book. Writing about how the new museum got designed and financed and built is no different in principle from explaining how the Iraqis almost built an atomic bomb.

但要从内部写艺术——评价一部新作品，评估一场表演，辨别什么是好什么是坏——需要一套特殊的技能和特殊的知识体系。简而言之，成为一名批评家是必要的——几乎每个作家在其职业生涯的某个阶段都想成为一名批评家。Smalltown 的记者梦想着他们的编辑会召集他们报道已被预订到当地礼堂的钢琴家或芭蕾舞团或剧团的那一刻。他们会大肆宣扬大学教育中来之不易的词汇——“直觉”、“感性”和“卡夫卡式”——并向整个县城展示他们会从entrechat滑音。他们会在易卜生身上辨别出比易卜生想象的更多的象征意义。

But to write about the arts from the inside—to appraise a new work, to evaluate a performance, to recognize what’s good and what’s bad—calls for a special set of skills and a special body of knowledge. It’s necessary, in short, to be a critic—which, at some point in his or her career, almost every writer wants to be. Smalltown reporters dream of the moment when their editor will summon them to cover the pianist or the ballet troupe or the repertory company that has been booked into the local auditorium. They will trot out the hard-won words of their college education—“intuit” and “sensibility” and “Kafkaesque”—and show the whole county that they know a glissando from an entrechat. They will discern more symbolism in Ibsen than Ibsen thought of.

这是冲动的一部分。批评是记者大展拳脚的舞台。这也是智慧名声诞生的地方。美国白话中充满了由多萝西·帕克 (Dorothy Parker) 和乔治·考夫曼 (George S. Kaufman) 等人创作的警句（“她的情感范围从 A 到 B一些无能的火腿的费用对除了最圣洁的人以外的所有人来说都太高了。我特别喜欢考夫曼的暗示，即伊利诺伊州安倍林肯的雷蒙德梅西夸大了主角的角色：“梅西只有被暗杀才会满意。”

This is part of the urge. Criticism is the stage on which journalists do their fanciest strutting. It’s also where reputations for wit are born. The American vernacular is rich in epigrams (“She ran the gamut of emotions from A to B”) minted by people like Dorothy Parker and George S. Kaufman, who became famous partly by minting them, and the temptation to make a name at the expense of some talentless ham is too strong for all but the most saintly. I particularly like Kaufman’s hint that Raymond Massey in Abe Lincoln in Illinois was overplaying the title role: “Massey won’t be satisfied until he’s assassinated.”

然而，真正的机智是罕见的，每飞一次，就有一千支带倒刺的箭落在弓箭手的脚下。如果你想写严肃的批评，这种方法也太容易了，因为唯一幸存下来的警句是残酷的。埋葬凯撒比赞美他容易得多——埃及艳后也是如此。但是，用听起来不老套的语言说出您为什么认为一部剧很好看，是这个行业中最困难的工作之一。

True wit, however, is rare, and a thousand barbed arrows fall at the feet of the archer for every one that flies. It’s also too facile an approach if you want to write serious criticism, for the only epigrams that have survived are cruel ones. It’s far easier to bury Caesar than to praise him—and that goes for Cleopatra, too. But to say why you think a play is good, in words that don’t sound banal, is one of the hardest chores in the business.

所以不要误以为批评是通往荣耀的捷径。这项工作也没有人们普遍认为的那么强大。可能只有《纽约时报》的日常剧评才能成就或破坏产品。音乐评论家几乎没有权力，写了一堆消失在空气中的声音，再也不会以同样的方式被听到，文学评论家也没有阻止畅销书排行榜成为像这样的作家的巢穴丹妮尔·斯蒂尔 (Danielle Steel)，他们不了解她的敏感度。

So don’t be deluded that criticism is an easy route to glory. Nor does the job carry as much power as is widely supposed. Probably only the daily drama critic of the New York Times can make or break the product. Music critics have almost no power, writing about a cluster of sounds that have vanished into the air and will never be heard in the same way again, and literary critics haven’t kept the best-seller list from becoming a nesting ground for authors like Danielle Steel, whose sensibility they don’t intuit.

因此，应该区分“评论家”和“评论家”。评论家为报纸或流行杂志撰稿，他们所涵盖的主要是一个行业——例如，电视行业、电影行业的产品，以及越来越多的出版行业的食谱、健康书籍、指南书、“按照说明”书、“礼品书”和其他此类商品。作为审稿人，您的工作更多的是报告而不是做出审美判断。你是普通男人或女人的代表，他们想知道：“新电视剧讲的是什么？” “这部电影对孩子们来说太脏了吗？” “这本书真的会改善我的性生活，还是会告诉我如何制作巧克力慕斯？” 想想你想知道什么，如果你电影费、保姆费和约定已久的好饭店晚餐费都得花。显然，与评判契诃夫的新作品相比，你的评测会更平实、更简单。

A distinction should therefore be made between a “critic” and a “reviewer.” Reviewers write for a newspaper or a popular magazine, and what they cover is primarily an industry—the output of, for instance, the television industry, the motion-picture industry and, increasingly, the publishing industry in its flood of cookbooks, health books, how-to books, “as told to” books, “gift books” and other such items of merchandise. As a reviewer your job is more to report than to make an aesthetic judgment. You are the deputy for the average man or woman who wants to know: “What is the new TV series about?” “Is the movie too dirty for the kids?” “Will the book really improve my sex life or tell me how to make a chocolate mousse?” Think what you would want to know if you had to spend the money for the movie, the baby-sitter and the long-promised dinner at a good restaurant. Obviously you will make your review plainer and less sophisticated than if you were judging a new production of Chekhov.

然而，我提出了几个适用于良好评论和良好批评的条件。

Yet I suggest several conditions that apply to both good reviewing and good criticism.

一是评论家应该喜欢——或者更好的是，热爱——他们正在评论的媒体。如果您认为电影很愚蠢，请不要写电影。读者应该得到一个电影迷，他会带来知识、激情和偏见的宝库。评论家没有必要喜欢每一部电影；批评只是一个人的意见。但他应该去看每部想要喜欢的电影。如果他失望的次数多于高兴的次数，那是因为这部电影未能达到最佳效果。这与以憎恶一切为荣的批评家大相径庭。他变得厌倦的速度比你说“卡夫卡式”还要快。

One is that critics should like—or, better still, love—the medium they are reviewing. If you think movies are dumb, don’t write about them. The reader deserves a movie buff who will bring along a reservoir of knowledge, passion and prejudice. It’s not necessary for the critic to like every film; criticism is only one person’s opinion. But he should go to every movie wanting to like it. If he is more often disappointed than pleased, it’s because the film has failed to live up to its best possibilities. This is far different from the critic who prides himself on hating everything. He becomes tiresome faster than you can say “Kafkaesque.”

另一条规则是：不要泄露太多情节。告诉读者足够多，让他们决定这是否是他们喜欢的故事，但不要太多以至于你会扼杀他们的乐趣。一句话往往就能解决问题。“这是关于一位异想天开的爱尔兰牧师的照片，他在三个打扮成小妖精的孤儿的帮助下，在一个卑鄙的寡妇藏了一大桶金子的村庄里出没。” 我不能被吓到去看那部电影——我已经在舞台和银幕上看到了“小人物”。但也有许多人不同意我的想法，他们会涌向这部电影。不要通过揭示故事的每一个转折来破坏他们的乐趣，尤其是关于桥下巨魔的有趣部分。

Another rule is: don’t give away too much of the plot. Tell readers just enough to let them decide whether it’s the kind of story they tend to enjoy, but not so much that you’ll kill their enjoyment. One sentence will often do the trick. “This is a picture about a whimsical Irish priest who enlists the help of three orphan boys dressed as leprechauns to haunt a village where a mean widow has hidden a crock of gold.” I couldn’t be flailed into seeing that movie—I’ve had my fill of “the little people” on stage and screen. But there are legions who don’t share that crotchet of mine and would flock to the film. Don’t spoil their pleasure by revealing every twist of the narrative, especially the funny part about the troll under the bridge.

第三个原则是使用具体的细节。这避免了泛泛而谈，泛泛而谈毫无意义。“戏总是引人入胜”是一句典型的评论家的话。但是如何很吸引人吗？你对迷人的看法与其他人不同。举几个例子，让你的读者用他们自己的魅力等级来衡量它们。以下是对约瑟夫·洛西 (Joseph Losey) 执导的电影的两篇影评节选。(1) “在试图变得文明和克制的过程中，它否认了粗俗的可能性，并把冷漠误认为是品味。” 这句话含糊不清，让我们感受到了电影的气氛，但没有我们可以想象的形象。(2) “Losey 追求的风格是在灯罩中寻找预兆，在餐桌布置中寻找意义。” 这句话很准确——我们知道这是一种什么样的艺术电影制作。我们几乎可以看到相机在家庭水晶上缓慢地徘徊。

A third principle is to use specific detail. This avoids dealing in generalities, which, being generalities, mean nothing. “The play is always fascinating” is a typical critic’s sentence. But how is it fascinating? Your idea of fascinating is different from someone else’s. Cite a few examples and let your readers weigh them on their own fascination scale. Here are excerpts from two reviews of a film directed by Joseph Losey. (1) “In its attempts to be civilized and restrained it denies its possibilities for vulgarity and mistakes bloodlessness for taste.” The sentence is vague, giving us a whiff of the movie’s mood but no image we can visualize. (2) “Losey pursues a style that finds portents in lampshades and meanings in table settings.” The sentence is precise—we know just what kind of arty filmmaking this is. We can almost see the camera lingering with studied sluggishness over the family crystal.

在书评中，这意味着允许作者的话做他们自己的文档。别说Tom Wolfe的作风花哨不一般。引用他的一些花里胡哨的奇葩句子，让读者看看它们有多么古怪。在评论一出戏时，不要只告诉我们这个场景“引人注目”。描述它的不同层次，或者它是如何被巧妙地照亮的，或者它如何帮助演员进入和退出，而传统的场景不会。让你的读者坐在你的剧院座位上。帮助他们看到你所看到的。

In book reviewing this means allowing the author’s words to do their own documentation. Don’t say that Tom Wolfe’s style is gaudy and unusual. Quote a few of his gaudy and unusual sentences and let the reader see how quirky they are. In reviewing a play, don’t just tell us that the set is “striking.” Describe its various levels, or how it is ingeniously lit, or how it helps the actors to make their entrances and exits as a conventional set would not. Put your readers in your theater seat. Help them to see what you saw.

最后要注意的是，要避免在每个评论家的箭袋中占据如此不成比例的空间的狂喜形容词——像“迷人”和“发光”这样的词。好的批评需要一种精干而生动的风格来表达你所观察到的和你所想的。华丽的形容词带有气喘吁吁的散文气息，Vogue喜欢用它来披露其最新的 chichi 发现：“我们刚刚听说科苏梅尔最迷人的小海滩！”

A final caution is to avoid the ecstatic adjectives that occupy such disproportionate space in every critic’s quiver—words like “enthralling” and “luminous.” Good criticism needs a lean and vivid style to express what you observed and what you think. Florid adjectives smack of the panting prose with which Vogue likes to disclose its latest chichi discovery: “We’ve just heard about the most utterly enchanting little beach at Cozumel!”

这么多复习和更简单的游戏规则。什么是批评？

So much for reviewing and the simpler rules of the game. What is criticism?

批评是一种严肃的智力行为。它试图评估严肃的艺术作品，并将它们置于该媒介或该艺术家之前所做的事情的背景下。这并不意味着评论家必须将自己限制在目标远大的工作中；他们可能会选择一些商业产品，如《法律与秩序》来表达对美国社会和价值观的看法。但总的来说，他们不想把时间浪费在小贩身上。他们将自己视为学者，他们感兴趣的是思想在他们领域中的作用。

Criticism is a serious intellectual act. It tries to evaluate serious works of art and to place them in the context of what has been done before in that medium or by that artist. This doesn’t mean that critics must limit themselves to work that aims high; they may select some commercial product like Law & Order to make a point about American society and values. But on the whole they don’t want to waste their time on peddlers. They see themselves as scholars, and what interests them is the play of ideas in their field.

因此，如果你想成为一名评论家，请沉浸在你希望成为自己专业的媒体的文学作品中。如果你想成为一名戏剧评论家，就去看看每部可能的戏剧——好的和坏的，新的和旧的。通过阅读经典或在复兴中看到它们来追赶过去。了解莎士比亚和萧伯纳、契诃夫和莫里哀、亚瑟·米勒和田纳西·威廉姆斯，了解他们如何开拓新天地。了解伟大的演员和导演以及他们的方法有何不同。了解美国音乐剧的历史：杰罗姆·克恩 (Jerome Kern) 和格什温兄弟以及科尔·波特 (Cole Porter)、罗杰斯 (Rodgers) 和哈特 (Hart) 以及汉默斯坦 (Hammerstein)、弗兰克·洛瑟 (Frank Loesser) 和斯蒂芬·桑德海姆 (Stephen Sondheim)、艾格尼丝·德米勒 (Agnes de Mille) 和杰罗姆·罗宾斯 (Jerome Robbins) 的特殊贡献。

Therefore if you want to be a critic, steep yourself in the literature of the medium you hope to make your specialty. If you want to be a theater critic, see every possible play—the good and the bad, the old and the new. Catch up on the past by reading the classics or seeing them in revival. Know your Shakespeare and Shaw, your Chekhov and Molière, your Arthur Miller and Tennessee Williams, and know how they broke new ground. Learn about the great actors and directors and how their methods differed. Know the history of the American musical: the particular contribution of Jerome Kern and the Gershwin brothers and Cole Porter, of Rodgers and Hart and Hammerstein, of Frank Loesser and Stephen Sondheim, of Agnes de Mille and Jerome Robbins. Only then can you place every new play or musical within an older tradition and tell the pioneer from the imitator.

我可以为每一种艺术列出同样的清单。一个电影评论家在没有看过奥特曼早期电影的情况下评论一部新的罗伯特奥特曼电影对严肃的影迷没有多大帮助。音乐评论家不仅应该了解他的巴赫和帕莱斯特里纳、他的莫扎特和贝多芬，还应该了解他的勋伯格、艾夫斯和菲利普·格拉斯——理论家、特立独行者和实验家。

I could make the same kind of list for every art. A film critic who reviews a new Robert Altman picture without having seen Altman’s earlier films isn’t much help to the serious moviegoer. A music critic should know not only his Bach and Palestrina, his Mozart and Beethoven, but his Schoenberg and Ives and Philip Glass—the theoreticians and mavericks and experimenters.

显然，我现在假设读者群体更加温文尔雅。作为评论家，您可以预设与您所写作的男性和女性共享某些知识领域。你不必告诉他们威廉福克纳是一位南方小说家。如果您正在评估一位南方作家的第一部小说并权衡福克纳的影响力，您必须做的是产生一个具有挑衅性的想法并将其放到页面上，让您的读者可以细细品味。他们可能不同意你的观点——这是他们智力乐趣的一部分。但他们很享受你的思想转变和让你得出结论的旅程。我们喜欢优秀的评论家，因为他们的个性和他们的观点一样。

Obviously I’m now assuming a more urbane body of readers. As a critic you can presuppose certain shared areas of knowledge with the men and women you are writing for. You don’t have to tell them that William Faulkner was a Southern novelist. What you do have to do, if you are assessing the first novel of a Southern author and weighing Faulkner’s influence, is to generate a provocative idea and throw it onto the page, where your readers can savor it. They may disagree with your point—that’s part of their intellectual fun. But they have enjoyed the turn of your mind and the journey that took you to your conclusion. We like good critics as much for their personality as for their opinions.

没有像电影这样的媒介可以让我们享受与优秀评论家一起旅行的乐趣。共同的领土是如此广阔。电影与我们的日常生活和态度、我们的记忆和神话交织在一起——来自《卡萨布兰卡》的四句不同的台词已经成为巴特利特熟悉的语录——我们指望影评人为我们建立这些联系。影评人提供的一项典型服务是短暂地冻结一部电影又一部电影穿过屏幕的星星，以供我们检查，有时这些星星来自观星者以前不为人知的星系。莫莉·哈斯克尔 (Molly Haskell)，评论《黑暗中的哭泣》梅丽尔·斯特里普 (Meryl Streep) 在其中扮演一名在野营旅行中杀害婴儿的澳大利亚妇女，思考着斯特里普“伪装的乐趣——奇异的假发、非正统的打扮和外国口音——以及扮演观众通常不会同情的女性。 ” 将其置于历史背景下，就像优秀的评论家应该做的那样，她写道：

There’s no medium like the movies to give us the pleasure of traveling with a good critic. The shared territory is so vast. Movies are intertwined with our daily lives and attitudes, our memories and myths—four different lines from Casablanca have made it into Bartlett’s Familiar Quotations—and we count on the critic to make those connections for us. A typical service that the critic provides is to freeze briefly for our inspection the stars who shoot across the screen in film after film, sometimes arriving from a galaxy previously unknown to stargazers. Molly Haskell, reviewing A Cry in the Dark, in which Meryl Streep plays an Australian woman convicted of killing her baby on a camping trip, ponders Streep’s “delight in disguise—in bizarre wigs, unorthodox getups and foreign accents—and in playing women who are outside the normal range of audience sympathy.” Putting this in a historical context, as good critics should, she writes:

老明星的光环散发出一种自我意识，一种核心身份投射到每一个角色中。无论贝蒂·戴维斯、凯瑟琳·赫本或玛格丽特·苏拉文的表演各不相同，我们总觉得自己处在某种可知、熟悉、不变的事物面前。他们有可辨认的声音、读台词的方式，甚至某些在电影之间保持不变的表达方式。漫画可以模仿它们，你要么毫不含糊地回应它们，要么不回应。斯特里普，像变色龙一样，通过从不在一个地方停留足够长的时间来削弱这种反应，以至于你无法修复她。

The aura of the old stars radiated out of a sense of self, a core identity projected into every role. However varied the performances of Bette Davis, or Katharine Hepburn, or Margaret Sullavan, we always felt we were in the presence of something knowable, familiar, constant. They had recognizable voices, ways of reading a line, even certain expressions that remained constant from film to film. Comics could do imitations of them, and you either responded to them, unambivalently, or you didn’t. Streep, chameleon-like, undercuts this response by never staying in one place long enough for you to get a fix on her.

贝蒂·戴维斯 (Bette Davis) 突破了类型的界限，开始尝试古装（《处女女王》）和古装（《老处女》），但她始终是贝蒂·戴维斯，否则没有人会想要它。像斯特里普一样，她甚至敢于扮演不讨人喜欢、道德模棱两可的女主角，她最伟大的角色是《信》中种植园主的妻子冷血杀害了她背信弃义的情人，然后拒绝悔改。不同的是，戴维斯融入了这个角色，倾注了自己的热情和热情。她的女主人公像美狄亚一样冰冷而骄傲和无情——这可能就是为什么学院的成员拒绝了她应得的奥斯卡奖，转而支持更甜美、更温顺的金杰罗杰斯饰演凯蒂福伊尔——但戴维斯让我们对内心的火焰做出反应。很难想象像斯特里普这样与自己的角色保持安全距离的女演员，会上升到如此高度……或跌落到如此深度。

Bette Davis, stretching the bounds of type, went in for costume (The Virgin Queen) and period (The Old Maid), but she was always Bette Davis, and no one would have thought to want it otherwise. Like Streep, she even dared to play unlikable, morally ambiguous heroines, her greatest being the wife of the plantation owner in The Letter who murders her treacherous lover in cold blood, then refuses to repent. The difference is that Davis fused with the role, poured her own passion and intensity into it. Her heroine is as icily proud and implacable as Medea—which may be why members of the Academy denied her the Oscar she deserved in favor of sweeter and tamer Ginger Rogers for Kitty Foyle—but Davis makes us respond to the fire within. It’s hard to imagine an actress like Streep, who remains at a safe distance from her roles, rising to such heights … or falling to such depths.

这段话巧妙地将好莱坞的过去和好莱坞的现在联系起来，让我们了解梅丽尔斯特里普的后现代风格，同时也告诉我们我们需要了解的关于贝蒂戴维斯的一切。推而广之，它向我们讲述了与戴维斯一起统治恒星系统黄金时代的整整一代巨龙——比如琼·克劳馥和芭芭拉·斯坦威克——只要他们还在银幕上，他们就不介意被人讨厌在票房上很受欢迎。

The passage deftly connects Hollywood past and Hollywood present, leaving us to fathom the postmodern cool of Meryl Streep but also telling us everything we need to know about Bette Davis. By extension it tells us about a whole generation of grand dragons who reigned with Davis in the golden age of the star system—the likes of Joan Crawford and Barbara Stanwyck—and who didn’t mind being hated on the screen as long as they were loved at the box office.

转向另一种媒体，这里是迈克尔·J·阿伦 (Michael J. Arlen) 的《客厅战争》( Living-Room War )的节选，这是阿伦在 1960 年代中期撰写的一系列电视批评专栏。

Turning to another medium, here’s an excerpt from Living-Room War, by Michael J. Arlen, a collection of columns of television criticism that Arlen wrote in the mid-1960s.

越南通常被称为“电视战争”，因为这是第一次主要由电视带给人们的战争。人们确实在看电视。他们真的看着它。他们看着 Dick Van Dyke 并成为他的朋友。他们看着深思熟虑的切特亨特利，觉得他很有思想，看着机智的大卫布林克利，觉得他很机智。他们看着越南。他们看越南，好像一个孩子跪在走廊里，眼睛盯着钥匙孔，看着两个大人在锁着的房间里争论——钥匙孔的孔径很小；人物影影绰绰，大多看不见；声音模糊不清，孤立无意义的威胁；孤立的一瞥，肘部的一部分，男人的夹克（男人是谁？），脸的一部分，女人的脸。啊，她在哭。一见即泪。（声音模糊地继续。) 一数眼泪。两滴眼泪。三泪。两次轰炸。四个寻找和摧毁任务。六项行政声明。这么好看的女人 一个大人四处寻找，可是，啊，钥匙孔太小了，怎么也看不到他。看！有 Ky 将军。看！有部分飞机安全返航提康德罗加。我想知道（有时）那些经营电视的人对战争的看法是什么，因为他们给了我们这种锁孔视角；我们已经给了他们电波，现在，在这个关键时刻，他们还给了我们这个锁孔视图——我想知道他们是否真的认为那些孤立的肘部、面部、裙子漩涡的瞥见（那个另一个是谁？人呢？）我们这些孩子能看到房间里发生的一切。

Vietnam is often referred to as “television’s war,” in the sense that this is the first war that has been brought to the people preponderantly by television. People indeed look at television. They really look at it. They look at Dick Van Dyke and become his friend. They look at thoughtful Chet Huntley and find him thoughtful, and at witty David Brinkley and find him witty. They look at Vietnam. They look at Vietnam, it seems, as a child kneeling in the corridor, his eye to the keyhole, looks at two grownups arguing in a locked room—the aperture of the keyhole small; the figures shadowy, mostly out of sight; the voices indistinct, isolated threats without meaning; isolated glimpses, part of an elbow, a man’s jacket (who is the man?), part of a face, a woman’s face. Ah, she is crying. One sees the tears. (The voices continue indistinctly.) One counts the tears. Two tears. Three tears. Two bombing raids. Four seek-and-destroy missions. Six administration pronouncements. Such a fine-looking woman. One searches in vain for the other grownup, but, ah, the keyhole is so small, he is somehow never in the line of sight. Look! There is General Ky. Look! There are some planes returning safely to the Ticonderoga. I wonder (sometimes) what it is that the people who run television think about the war, because they have given us this keyhole view; we have given them the airwaves, and now, at this crucial time, they have given back to us this keyhole view—and I wonder if they truly think that those isolated glimpses of elbow, face, a swirl of dress (who is that other person anyway?) are all that we children can stand to see of what is going on inside the room.

这是最好的批评：时尚、暗示、令人不安。它扰乱了我们——正如批评通常应该发生的那样——因为它激起一系列信念并迫使我们重新审视它们。引起我们注意的是钥匙孔的比喻，它既准确又神秘。但仍然存在一个基本问题，即该国最强大的媒体如何向人们讲述他们正在打的战争——以及不断升级的战争。该专栏于 1966 年开播，当时大多数美国人仍然支持越南战争。如果电视扩大了钥匙孔，不仅向我们展示了“裙子的漩涡”，还向我们展示了被砍断的头颅和燃烧的孩子，他们会不会更快地反对它？现在知道也晚了。但至少有一位评论家在关注。当我们认为不言而喻的真理不再真实时，批评家应该是第一个通知我们的人。

This is criticism at its best: stylish, allusive, disturbing. It disturbs us—as criticism often should—because it jogs a set of beliefs and forces us to reexamine them. What holds our attention is the metaphor of the keyhole, so exact and yet so mysterious. But what remains is a fundamental question about how the country’s most powerful medium told the people about the war they were fighting—and escalating. The column ran in 1966, when most Americans still supported the Vietnam war. Would they have turned against it sooner if TV had widened the keyhole, had shown us not only the “swirl of dress” but the severed head and the burning child? It’s too late now to know. But at least one critic was keeping watch. Critics should be among the first to notify us when the truths we hold to be self-evident cease to be true.

有些艺术比其他艺术更难印刷。一种是舞蹈，由动作组成。一个作家如何能冻结所有优雅的跳跃和旋转？另一个是音乐。这是一种我们通过耳朵接收到的艺术，但作家们却坚持用我们将要看到的文字来描述它。充其量他们只能部分成功，许多音乐评论家通过躲在意大利技术术语的对冲中建立了长期的职业生涯。他会在钢琴家身上发现太多的节奏，在女高音的音域中发现一丝尖锐。

Some arts are harder to catch in print than others. One is dance, which consists of movement. How can a writer freeze all the graceful leaps and pirouettes? Another is music. It’s an art that we receive through our ears, yet writers are stuck with describing it in words we will see. At best they can only partly succeed, and many a music critic has built a long career by hiding behind a hedge of Italian technical terms. He will find just a shade too much rubato in a pianist, a tinge of shrillness in a soprano’s tessitura.

但即使在这个转瞬即逝的世界里，一个好的评论家也可以通过写出好的英语来理解发生的事情。1940年至1954年任纽约先驱论坛报的乐评人维吉尔·汤姆森是一位优雅的实践者。他本人是一位作曲家，博学而有教养，他从未忘记他的读者是真实的人，他以一种席卷他们的热情写作，他的风格充满惊喜。他也无所畏惧。在他任职期间，没有圣牛可以安全地吃草。他从未忘记音乐家是真实的人，他毫不犹豫地将巨人缩小到人的尺度：

But even in this world of evanescent notes a good critic can make sense of what happened by writing good English. Virgil Thomson, the music critic of the New York Herald Tribune from 1940 to 1954, was an elegant practitioner. A composer himself, an erudite and cultivated man, he never forgot that his readers were real people, and he wrote with a zest that swept them along, his style alive with pleasant surprises. He was also fearless; during his tenure no sacred cow could safely graze. He never forgot that musicians are real people, and he didn’t hesitate to shrink the giants to human scale:

令人惊奇的是，很少有音乐家在他们之间讨论托斯卡尼尼关于速度和节奏以及音调舒适性的正确或错误。像其他音乐家一样，他经常在这些方面表现得很好，但也经常犯错误。似乎更重要的是他不变的拼图能力。他很厚颜无耻地加快节奏，牺牲清晰度，忽略了基本的节奏，只是让音乐像他的指挥棒一样，一圈又一圈地旋转，如果他发现听众的注意力开始动摇的话。没有一块必须有任何具体的含义；每件作品都必须激起听众自发的接受票。这就是我所说的“哇技术”。

It is extraordinary how little musicians discuss among themselves Toscanini’s rightness or wrongness about matters of speed and rhythm and the tonal amenities. Like other musicians, he is frequently apt about these and as frequently in error. What seems to be more important is his unvarying ability to put over a piece. He quite shamelessly whips up the tempo and sacrifices clarity and ignores a basic rhythm, just making the music, like his baton, go round and round, if he finds his audience’s attention tending to waver. No piece has to mean anything specific; every piece has to provoke from its hearers a spontaneous vote of acceptance. This is what I call the “wow technique.”

那里没有rubatos或tessituras，也没有盲目的英雄崇拜。然而，这段话抓住了使托斯卡尼尼伟大的本质：对演艺界的额外帮助。如果他的粉丝认为精华中含有如此粗糙的成分而受到冒犯，他们可以继续欣赏大师的“抒情色彩”或“管弦乐曲目”。我会同意 Thomson 的诊断，我怀疑 Maestro 也会如此。

No rubatos or tessituras there, and no blind hero worship. Yet the paragraph catches the essence of what made Toscanini great: an extra helping of show biz. If his fans are offended to think that the essence contained so coarse an ingredient, they can continue to admire the Maestro for his “lyrical colorations” or “orchestral tuttis.” I’ll go along with Thomson’s diagnosis, and so, I suspect, would the Maestro.

批评中的一种润滑剂是幽默。它允许评论家以一种间接的方式来看待一部作品，并写出一部本身就是一种娱乐的作品。但该专栏应该是一篇有机的文章，而不仅仅是一些机智的兔子拳。詹姆斯·米切纳 (James Michener) 的书长期以来一直无视评论家对它们的批评。凭着他们的诚恳，他们是无懈可击的。然而，在回顾《盟约》时，约翰·伦纳德用隐喻的迂回路线伏击了米切纳：

One lubricant in criticism is humor. It allows the critic to come at a work obliquely and to write a piece that is itself an entertainment. But the column should be an organic piece of writing, not just a few rabbit punches of wit. James Michener’s books have long defied reviewers to say anything bad about them; by their earnestness they are unassailable. Reviewing The Covenant, however, John Leonard ambushed Michener by the roundabout route of metaphor:

对于 James A. Michener 必须要说的是，他让你疲惫不堪。他麻木你默许。一页又一页的平淡无奇的散文行军，就像一支失败的军队，穿过视神经束。这是一次从陈词滥调到虔诚的伟大旅程。耳朵之间的思想也可能是 Mzilikazi 或布尔战争期间英国的“焦土”政策造成的破坏之一之后的南非草原。没有鸟儿歌唱，羚羊也渴死了。

What must be said for James A. Michener is that he wears you down. He numbs you into acquiescence. Page after page of pedestrian prose marches, like a defeated army, across the optic tract. It is a Great Trek from platitude to piety. The mind, between the ears, might as well be the South African veld after one of the devastations of Mzilikazi or the “scorched earth” policy of the British during the Boer War. No bird sings and the antelope die of thirst.

然而，米切纳先生像鞋子一样真诚。在《盟约》中，就像在《夏威夷》 、 《百年纪念》和《切萨皮克》中一样，他着眼长远。他从 15,000 年前开始，到 1979 年底结束。无论我们愿不愿意，他都会让我们了解南非。就像荷兰人一样，他的观点常常带有一种冷酷的公平竞争意识，他很固执；他忍受自己的恶劣天气；他驱赶他的事实，直到它们倒下。

And yet Mr. Michener is as sincere as shoes. In The Covenant, as in Hawaii and Centennial and Chesapeake, he takes the long view. He begins 15,000 years ago and he stops at the end of 1979. He is going to make us understand South Africa whether we want to or not. Like the Dutchmen whose point of view he often presents with a grim sense of fair play, he is stubborn; he endures his own bad weather; he drives the cattle of his facts until they drop.

大约 300 页之后，读者——至少是这个读者——叹了口气。当然，如果我们要花一周时间看一本书，那本书应该是普鲁斯特或陀思妥耶夫斯基写的，而不是米切纳先生用文件卡钉在一起的。但是没有回头路可走。这与其说是虚构，不如说是苦差事。我们被骑在我们肩膀上的教师鞭打。也许学习对我们有好处。

After 300 pages or so the reader—this reader anyway—submits with a sigh. Of course, if we are going to spend a week with a book, the book should be written by Proust or Dostoyevsky, not stapled together from file cards by Mr. Michener. But there is no turning back. This is less fiction than it is drudgery; we are lashed on by the pedagogue who rides our shoulders. Maybe learning will be good for us.

学习我们做。米切纳先生不作弊。他个人的盟约不是与上帝，而是与百科全书。如果 15,000 年前在非洲丛林中，桑人使用了毒箭，他会描述这些箭并说出毒药的来源。

Learn we do. Mr. Michener doesn’t cheat. His personal covenant is not with God, but with the encyclopedia. If, 15,000 years ago in the African bush, the San used poison arrows, he will describe those arrows and name the source of the poison.

一篇好的批评应该如何开始？你必须立即努力让你的读者适应他们即将进入的特殊世界。即使他们是受过广泛教育的男女，也需要被告知或提醒他们某些事实。你不能只是把它们扔到水里然后指望它们能轻松游动。水需要加热。

How should a good piece of criticism start? You must make an immediate effort to orient your readers to the special world they are about to enter. Even if they are broadly educated men and women they need to be told or reminded of certain facts. You can’t just throw them in the water and expect them to swim easily. The water needs to be warmed up.

文学批评尤其如此。之前已经发生了很多事情；所有的作家都是一条长流的一部分，无论他们决定顺流而下还是逆流而上。本世纪没有一位诗人比 TS 艾略特更具创新性和影响力。然而，正如辛西娅·奥齐克 (Cynthia Ozick) 在《纽约客》( The New Yorker ) 的一篇评论文章开头指出的那样，他在 1988 年诞辰 100 周年时，公众关注度极低，她指出，如今的大学生几乎不知道这位诗人对她这一代人的“巨大预言性存在” ：“[对我们]来说，在一个类似于永恒的文学时期，TS 艾略特……似乎是纯粹的天顶，一个巨人，不亚于一个永恒的发光体，像太阳和月亮一样固定在天空中。”

This is particularly true of literary criticism. So much has gone before; all writers are part of a long stream, whether they decide to swim with the current or to hurl themselves against it. No poet of this century was more innovative and influential than T. S. Eliot. Yet his 100th birthday in 1988 passed with surprisingly little public attention, as Cynthia Ozick noted at the start of a critical essay in The New Yorker, pointing out that today’s college students have almost no knowledge of the poet’s “mammoth prophetic presence” for her generation: “[To us], in a literary period that resembled eternity, T. S. Eliot … seemed pure zenith, a colossus, nothing less than a permanent luminary, fixed in the firmament like the sun and the moon.”

奥齐克多么巧妙地让水变暖，召唤我们回到她自己大学时代的文学景观，从而理解她对即将展开的近乎遗忘的故事的惊讶。

How adroitly Ozick warms up the waters, beckoning us to return to the literary landscape of her own college years and thereby understand her amazement at the tale of near oblivion she is about to unfold.

艾略特诗歌的大门并不容易打开。他的台词和主题不容易理解。但年轻人却被陌生的魔法所引诱，并被令人愉悦的无聊丝带所束缚，冲进了这些门户。“四月是最残酷的月份”——艾略特的声音带着阴沉的韵律，从学生的留声机中盘旋而出——“从死地培育/丁香花，混合/记忆和欲望。” 那种古板的英国口音——平淡、精确、稳重、不动声色、出人意料的高亢、凄凉的被动——盘绕在令人敬畏的英语系和令人敬畏的宿舍、墙上挂着毕加索画像的房间，以及庞德、艾略特和尤利西斯的房间普鲁斯特在全神贯注的已故青春期胸膛里互相推挤。声音就像诗人本人一样，几乎是圣职的；它是没有人情味的，蜿蜒曲折地穿过这个国家的校园，就像一卷空白的机器人灾难。“Shantih shantih shantih”，“不是砰的一声，而是一声呜咽”，“旱月的老人”，“我要卷起裤脚”：这些是四十年代文人热情的虔诚吟唱和五十年代，他们在自己的第一节诗中虔诚地模仿了艾略特的语气——它的克制、严肃、神秘、侵入性的遥远和固定、脱节的绝望。

The doors to Eliot’s poetry were not easily opened. His lines and themes were not readily understood. But the young flung themselves through those portals, lured by unfamiliar enchantments and bound by pleasurable ribbons of ennui. “April is the cruellest month”—Eliot’s voice, with its sepulchral cadences, came spiraling out of student phonographs—“breeding/Lilacs out of the dead land, mixing/Memory and desire.” That tony British accent—flat, precise, steady, unemotive, surprisingly high-pitched, bleakly passive—coiled through awed English Departments and worshipful dormitories, rooms where the walls had pinup Picassos, and where Pound and Eliot and Ulysses and Proust jostled one another higgledy-piggledy in the rapt late adolescent breast. The voice was, like the poet himself, nearly sacerdotal; it was impersonal, winding and winding across the country’s campuses like a spool of blank robotic woe. “Shantih shantih shantih,” “not with a bang but a whimper,” “an old man in a dry month,” “I shall wear the bottoms of my trousers rolled”: these were the devout chants of the literarily passionate in the forties and fifties, who in their own first verses piously copied Eliot’s tone—its restraint, gravity, mystery, its invasive remoteness and immobilized, disjointed despair.

这一段的精彩之处在于它令人难忘的细节、它的学术严谨性、它让人想起艾略特本人作为美国校园中巨大的实体存在的背影。作为读者，我们仿佛回到了大祭司的至高时刻——为即将到来的下坡做好了完美的准备。许多学者不喜欢奥齐克的文章；他们认为她夸大了诗人名声扫地的情况。但对我来说，这只是验证了她的作品。不激起一些好斗情绪的文学批评几乎不值得写，而且很少有观赏性运动像一场精彩的学术争吵一样令人愉快。

The paragraph is brilliant in its remembered detail, its scholarly fastidiousness, its conjuring back of Eliot himself as a huge physical presence on campuses across America. As readers we are transported back to the high priest’s highest moment—a perfect launch for the descent that lies ahead. Many scholars didn’t like Ozick’s essay; they thought she had exaggerated the poet’s fall from renown. But for me that merely validated her piece. Literary criticism that doesn’t stir a few combative juices is hardly worth writing, and there are few spectator sports as enjoyable as a good academic brawl.

今天，批评在新闻业有许多表亲：报纸或杂志专栏、个人随笔、社论和散文评论，评论家从一本书或一种文化现象离题到一个更大的观点。（戈尔·维达尔 (Gore Vidal) 为这种形式带来了高度的无礼和幽默。）这些专栏中有许多管理良好批评的相同原则。例如，政治专栏作家必须热爱政治及其古老而复杂的线索。

Today, criticism has many first cousins in journalism: the newspaper or magazine column, the personal essay, the editorial, and the essay-review, in which a critic digresses from a book or a cultural phenomenon into a larger point. (Gore Vidal has brought a high impudence and humor to the form.) Many of the same principles that govern good criticism go into these columns. A political columnist, for example, must love politics and its ancient, tangled threads.

但所有表格的共同点是它们包含个人意见。即使是使用“我们”的社论也显然是“我”写的。作为作家，重要的是要坚定地表达自己的观点。不要通过最后一刻的逃避和逃避来抵消它的力量。日报中最无聊的一句话是社论的最后一句话，“现在判断新政策是否有效还为时过早”或“决定的有效性还有待观察”。如果现在说还为时过早，请不要打扰我们，至于还有待观察，一切都还有待观察。坚定你的立场。

But what is common to all the forms is that they consist of personal opinion. Even the editorial that uses “we” was obviously written by an “I.” What is crucial for you as the writer is to express your opinion firmly. Don’t cancel its strength with last-minute evasions and escapes. The most boring sentence in the daily newspaper is the last sentence of the editorial, which says “It is too early to tell whether the new policy will work” or “The effectiveness of the decision remains to be seen.” If it’s too early to tell, don’t bother us with it, and as for what remains to be seen, everything remains to be seen. Take your stand with conviction.

许多年前，当我为《纽约先驱论坛报》撰写社论时，该版的编辑是一位来自得克萨斯州的大个子、脾气暴躁的人，名叫 LL Engelking。我尊重他，因为他没有伪装，并且讨厌围绕一个主题不恰当地兜圈子。每天早上我们都会开会讨论第二天我们想写什么社论以及我们将采取什么立场。我们常常不太确定，尤其是这位拉丁美洲专家的作家。

Many years ago, when I was writing editorials for the New York Herald Tribune, the editor of the page was a huge and choleric man from Texas named L. L. Engelking. I respected him because he had no pretense and hated undue circling around a subject. Every morning we would all meet to discuss what editorials we would like to write for the next day and what position we would take. Frequently we weren’t quite sure, especially the writer who was an expert on Latin America.

“那乌拉圭的政变呢？” 编辑会问。

“What about that coup in Uruguay?” the editor would ask.

“它可能代表经济的进步，”作者会回答，“或者它可能再次破坏整个政治局势的稳定。我想我可以提一下可能的好处，然后——”

“It could represent progress for the economy,” the writer would reply, “or then again it might destabilize the whole political situation. I suppose I could mention the possible benefits and then—”

“好吧，”得克萨斯州的男人会打断他的话，“咱们别往两条腿上撒尿。”

“Well,” the man from Texas would break in, “let’s not go peeing down both legs.”

这是他经常提出的请求，也是我收到的最不雅的建议。但在长期撰写评论和专栏并试图表达我强烈认同的观点的过程中，它也可能是最好的。

It was a plea he made often, and it was the most inelegant advice I ever received. But over a long career of writing reviews and columns and trying to make a point I felt strongly about, it was also probably the best.

19

19

幽默

Humor

幽默是纪实作家的秘密武器。这是秘密，因为很少有作家意识到幽默往往是他们表达重要观点的最佳工具——有时甚至是唯一的工具。

Humor is the secret weapon of the nonfiction writer. It’s secret because so few writers realize that humor is often their best tool—and sometimes their only tool—for making an important point.

如果这让您觉得自相矛盾，那么您并不孤单。幽默作家深知，他们的许多读者并不知道他们想做什么。我记得有位记者打电话问我怎么会写出《生活》中的某个戏仿。最后他说：“我应该称你为幽默家吗？或者你也写过什么严肃的东西吗？

If this strikes you as a paradox, you’re not alone. Writers of humor live with the knowledge that many of their readers don’t know what they are trying to do. I remember a reporter calling to ask how I happened to write a certain parody in Life. At the end he said, “Should I refer to you as a humorist? Or have you also written anything serious?”

答案是，如果你想写幽默，几乎你所做的一切都是严肃的。很少有美国人明白这一点。我们将我们的幽默家视为无足轻重的人，因为他们从未安定下来从事“真正的”工作。普利策奖颁给了像欧内斯特·海明威和威廉·福克纳这样的作家，他们（上帝知道）严肃，因此被公认为文学家。奖品很少授予像乔治·阿德、HL Mencken、Ring Lardner、SJ Perelman、Art Buchwald、Jules Feiffer、Woody Allen 和 Garrison Keillor 这样的人，他们似乎只是在胡闹。

The answer is that if you’re trying to write humor, almost everything you do is serious. Few Americans understand this. We dismiss our humorists as triflers because they never settled down to “real” work. The Pulitzer Prizes go to authors like Ernest Hemingway and William Faulkner, who are (God knows) serious and are therefore certified as men of literature. The prizes seldom go to people like George Ade, H. L. Mencken, Ring Lardner, S. J. Perelman, Art Buchwald, Jules Feiffer, Woody Allen and Garrison Keillor, who seem to be just fooling around.

他们不只是在胡闹。他们的目的和海明威或福克纳一样严肃——这是迫使国家清楚地看待自己的国家资产。对他们来说，幽默是一项紧迫的工作。这是一种尝试以一种特殊的方式来表达重要的事情，而普通作家不会以一种常规的方式来表达——或者即使是这样，它也非常有规律，以至于没有人会读它。

They’re not just fooling around. They are as serious in purpose as Hemingway or Faulkner—a national asset in forcing the country to see itself clearly. Humor, to them, is urgent work. It’s an attempt to say important things in a special way that regular writers aren’t getting said in a regular way—or if they are, it’s so regular that nobody is reading it.

一部强有力的社论漫画抵得上一百篇庄严的社论。加里·特鲁多 (Garry Trudeau) 的一部杜恩斯伯里 ( Doonesbury ) 漫画抵得上千言万语的说教。《第二十二条军规》或《奇爱博士》比所有试图“按原样”展示战争的书籍和电影更强大。对于那些试图警告我们明天可能会把我们所有人都炸毁的军事心态的人来说，这两部漫画发明作品仍然是标准的参考点。约瑟夫·海勒 (Joseph Heller) 和斯坦利·库布里克 (Stanley Kubrick) 将战争的真相提升到足以捕捉到它的疯狂，我们将其视为疯狂。这个笑话不是笑话。

One strong editorial cartoon is worth a hundred solemn editorials. One Doonesbury comic strip by Garry Trudeau is worth a thousand words of moralizing. One Catch–22 or Dr. Strangelove is more powerful than all the books and movies that try to show war “as it is.” Those two works of comic invention are still standard points of reference for anyone trying to warn us about the military mentality that could blow us all up tomorrow. Joseph Heller and Stanley Kubrick heightened the truth about war just enough to catch its lunacy, and we recognize it as lunacy. The joke is no joke.

将一些疯狂的事实夸大——达到一种会被视为疯狂的程度——是严肃幽默家试图做的事情的本质。这是他们如何进行神秘工作的一个例子。

This heightening of some crazy truth—to a level where it will be seen as crazy—is the essence of what serious humorists are trying to do. Here’s one example of how they go about their mysterious work.

1960 年代的一天，我意识到美国有一半的女孩和妇女突然戴上了卷发器。这是一种奇怪的新病症，更令人费解的是，我不明白女人们什么时候把卷发器拿出来的。没有证据表明他们曾经戴过——他们戴着它们去超市、去教堂和约会。那么他们留着漂亮的发型是为了什么精彩的活动呢？

One day in the 1960s I realized that half the girls and women in America were suddenly wearing hair curlers. It was a weird new blight, all the more puzzling because I couldn’t understand when the women took the curlers out. There was no evidence that they ever did—they wore them to the supermarket and to church and on dates. So what was the wonderful event they were saving the wonderful hairdo for?

我花了一年的时间想办法来写这个现象。我本可以说“这太令人愤慨了”或“这些女人没有自尊心吗？” 但那将是一场布道，而布道是幽默的死亡。作家必须找到一些喜剧手段——讽刺、戏仿、讽刺、讽刺、废话——他可以用来掩饰他的严肃观点。很多时候他从来没有找到它，而且重点没有被提出。

I tried for a year to think of a way to write about this phenomenon. I could have said “It’s an outrage” or “Have these women no pride?” But that would have been a sermon, and sermons are the death of humor. The writer must find some comic device—satire, parody, irony, lampoon, nonsense—that he can use to disguise his serious point. Very often he never finds it, and the point doesn’t get made.

幸运的是，我的守夜终于得到了回报。我在报摊浏览时看到四本并排的杂志：Hairdo、Celebrity Hairdo、Combout和Pouf。我把这四款都买了——这让新闻经销商大吃一惊——发现整个新闻界都只关注头发：从脖子开始生活，但不包括大脑。杂志上有精心制作的滚筒位置图和专栏，女孩可以在其中将她的滚筒问题发送给编辑，征求他们的建议。那就是我需要的。我发明了一本名为Haircurl的杂志，并写了一系列模仿信件和回复。这篇文章在生活中播出，它是这样开始的：

Luckily, my vigil was at last rewarded. I was browsing at a newsstand and saw four magazines side by side: Hairdo, Celebrity Hairdo, Combout and Pouf. I bought all four—to the alarm of the newsdealer—and found a whole world of journalism devoted solely to hair: life from the neck up, but not including the brain. The magazines had diagrams of elaborate roller positions and columns in which a girl could send her roller problem to the editors for their advice. That was what I needed. I invented a magazine called Haircurl and wrote a series of parody letters and replies. The piece ran in Life and it began like this:

亲爱的卷发：

Dear Haircurl:

我今年 15 岁，在我的团队中被认为很漂亮。我穿婴儿粉色滚轮，超大号。我和一个男孩稳定相处了 2.5 年，他从来没有见过我没有滚轮。那天晚上我把它们脱掉了，我们吵了一架。“你的头看起来很小，”他告诉我。他叫我侏儒，说我误导了他。我怎样才能赢回他？

I am 15 and am considered pretty in my group. I wear baby pink rollers, jumbo size. I have been going steady with a certain boy for 2½ years and he has never seen me without my rollers. The other night I took them off and we had a terrible fight. “Your head looks small,” he told me. He called me a dwarf and said I had misled him. How can I win him back?

心脏病发作，纽约州斯彭克。

HEARTSICK

Speonk, N.Y.

亲爱的心痛：

Dear Heartsick:

做出如此愚蠢的事情只能怪你自己。最新的“Haircurl”调查显示，现在 94% 的美国女孩每天 21.6 小时、每年 359 天都在头发上卷发。你试图与众不同，却失去了你的伙伴。听从我们的建议，买一些超大号的滚轮（它们也有你最喜欢的粉红色调），你的头会看起来比以往更大，更可爱。永远不要再脱掉它们。

You have only yourself to blame for doing something so stupid. The latest “Haircurl” survey shows that 94% of American girls now wear rollers in their hair 21.6 hours a day and 359 days a year. You tried to be different and you lost your fella. Take our advice and get some super-jumbo rollers (they come in your favorite baby pink shade, too) and your head will look bigger than ever and twice as lovely. Don’t ever take them off again.

亲爱的卷发：

Dear Haircurl:

我男朋友喜欢用手指梳理我的头发。问题是他老是把它们夹在我的滚筒里。前一天晚上，发生了一件非常尴尬的事情。我们在看电影，不知怎么的，我男朋友的两根手指被夹住了（恰好是中型滚轮与卷曲卷发器相交的地方），而且无法将它们取出来。离开剧院时我觉得很显眼，他的手还放在我的头发上，在回家的公共汽车上有几个人向我们投来了“滑稽的目光”。幸运的是，我能够联系到我家里的造型师，他带着他的工具马上过来，把可怜的杰里弄松了。杰里非常生气，说他不会再和我约会，直到我找到一些没有这种特殊习惯的人。我认为他不公平，但他“是认真的”。你能帮助我吗？

My boyfriend likes to run his fingers through my hair. The trouble is he keeps getting them pinched in my rollers. The other night a terribly embarrassing episode happened.
