The poet Allen Ginsberg, another writer who came to Yale to talk to my students, was asked if there was a moment when he consciously decided to become a poet. Ginsberg said, “It wasn’t quite a choice—it was a realization. I was twenty-eight and I had a job as a market researcher. One day I told my psychiatrist that what I really wanted to do was to quit my job and just write poetry. And the psychiatrist said, ‘Why not?’ And I said, ‘What would the American Psychoanalytical Association say?’ And he said, ‘There’s no party line.’ So I did.”

我们永远不会知道这对市场研究领域造成了多大的损失。但这对诗歌来说是一个重要时刻。没有党派路线：对作家的好建议。你可以成为你自己的党派。Red Smith 在一位体育作家同事的葬礼上发表悼词说：“死亡没什么大不了的。活着就是诀窍。” 我钦佩 Red Smith 的原因之一是他以优雅和幽默的方式写了 55 年的体育文章，没有屈服于压力，这是许多体育作家的毁灭，他应该写一些“严肃”的东西。他在体育写作中找到了他想做的事情和他喜欢做的事情，而且因为这对他来说是正确的，所以他说的关于美国价值观的事情比许多写严肃主题的作家都重要——严肃到没人能读懂。

We’ll never know how big a loss that was for the field of market research. But it was a big moment for poetry. There’s no party line: good advice for writers. You can be your own party line. Red Smith, delivering the eulogy at the funeral of a fellow sports-writer, said, “Dying is no big deal. Living is the trick.” One of the reasons I admired Red Smith was that he wrote about sports for 55 years, with grace and humor, without succumbing to the pressure, which was the ruin of many sportswriters, that he ought to be writing about something “serious.” He found in sportswriting what he wanted to do and what he loved doing, and because it was right for him he said more important things about American values than many writers who wrote about serious subjects—so seriously that nobody could read them.

活着就是诀窍。写得有趣的作家往往是让自己保持兴趣的男人和女人。这几乎就是成为作家的全部意义所在。我用写作给自己带来了有趣的生活和继续教育。如果你写的是你认为自己会喜欢了解的主题，那么你的乐趣就会体现在你所写的内容上。学习是一剂补药。

Living is the trick. Writers who write interestingly tend to be men and women who keep themselves interested. That’s almost the whole point of becoming a writer. I’ve used writing to give myself an interesting life and a continuing education. If you write about subjects you think you would enjoy knowing about, your enjoyment will show in what you write. Learning is a tonic.

这并不意味着当你进入不熟悉的地形时你不会紧张。作为非虚构类作家，您会一次又一次地被扔进专门的世界，您会担心自己没有资格将故事带回来。每次我开始一个新项目时，我都会感到焦虑。当我去布雷登顿写我的棒球书《春季训练》时，我就感受到了. 虽然我一生都是棒球迷，但我从未做过任何体育报道，也从未采访过职业运动员。严格来说，我没有证书；我拿着笔记本接触过的任何人——经理、教练、球员、裁判、球探——都可能会问，“关于棒球，你还写过什么？” 但没有人这样做。他们没有问，因为我有另一种凭证：诚意。对那些人来说很明显，我真的很想知道他们是如何工作的。当您进入新领域并需要一点自信时，请记住这一点。你最好的证明就是你自己。

That doesn’t mean you won’t be nervous when you go forth into unfamiliar terrain. As a nonfiction writer you’ll be thrown again and again into specialized worlds, and you’ll worry that you’re not qualified to bring the story back. I feel that anxiety every time I embark on a new project. I felt it when I went to Bradenton to write my baseball book, Spring Training. Although I’ve been a baseball fan all my life, I had never done any sports reporting, never interviewed a professional athlete. Strictly, I had no credentials; any of the men I approached with my notebook—managers, coaches, players, umpires, scouts—could have asked, “What else have you written about baseball?” But nobody did. They didn’t ask because I had another kind of credential: sincerity. It was obvious to those men that I really wanted to know how they did their work. Remember this when you enter new territory and need a shot of confidence. Your best credential is yourself.

还要记住，您的任务可能没有您想象的那么狭窄。通常它会触及你的经历或你的教育中一些意想不到的角落，使你能够利用自己的优势来扩展故事。每一次减少不熟悉都会减少你的恐惧。

Also remember that your assignment may not be as narrow as you think. Often it will turn out to touch some unexpected corner of your experience or your education, enabling you to broaden the story with strengths of your own. Every such reduction of the unfamiliar will reduce your fear.

1992 年，当我接到奥杜邦 ( Audubon ) 的一位编辑打来的电话，询问我是否愿意为该杂志写一篇文章时，这一课让我想起了这一课。我说我不会。我是第四代纽约人，根深蒂固。“那不适合我，不适合你，也不适合奥杜邦，”我告诉编辑。我从来没有接受过我认为自己不适合的任务，而且我很快就会告诉编辑们他们应该找其他人。奥杜邦的编辑回答说——作为优秀的编辑应该做的——他确信我们能想出一些办法，几周后他打电话说该杂志决定是时候发表一篇关于罗杰·托里·彼得森的新文章了，这个人使美国成为观鸟者的国家，他的鸟类野外指南自 1934 年以来的畅销书。我感兴趣吗？我说我对鸟类了解不够。我唯一能确定的是那只鸽子，它是我曼哈顿窗台上的常客。

That lesson was brought home to me in 1992 when I got a call from an editor at Audubon asking if I would write an article for the magazine. I said I wouldn’t. I’m a fourth-generation New Yorker, my roots deep in the cement. “That wouldn’t be right for me, or for you, or for Audubon,” I told the editor. I’ve never accepted an assignment I didn’t think I was suited for, and I’m quick to tell editors that they should look for someone else. The Audubon editor replied—as good editors should—that he was sure we could come up with something, and a few weeks later he called to say that the magazine had decided it was time for a new article on Roger Tory Peterson, the man who made America a nation of birdwatchers, his Field Guide to the Birds a best-seller since 1934. Was I interested? I said I didn’t know enough about birds. The only one I can identify for sure is the pigeon, a frequent caller at my Manhattan windowsill.

我需要与我要写的人建立某种融洽的关系。彼得森的作业不是我发起的，而是我发起的。它来找我了。几乎我写的每一篇简介都是关于我认识并喜爱的人的：像漫画家 Chic Young （Blondie）、词曲作者 Harold Arlen、英国演员 Peter Sellers、钢琴家 Dick Hyman 和英国旅行作家诺曼刘易斯。当我坐下来写作时，我对他们多年来陪伴的乐趣的感激之情成为我的能量源泉。如果你想让你的作品传达快乐，那就写你尊重的人。以破坏和诽谤为目的的写作对作者和主题一样具有破坏性。

I need to feel a certain rapport with the person I’ll be writing about. The Peterson assignment wasn’t one that I originated; it came looking for me. Almost every profile I’ve written has been of someone whose work I knew and had an affection for: such creative souls as the cartoonist Chic Young (Blondie), the songwriter Harold Arlen, the British actor Peter Sellers, the pianist Dick Hyman and the British travel writer Norman Lewis. My gratitude for the pleasure of their company over the years was a source of energy when I sat down to write. If you want your writing to convey enjoyment, write about people you respect. Writing to destroy and to scandalize can be as destructive to the writer as it is to the subject.

但是，发生了一些事情，这改变了我对奥杜邦报价的看法。我碰巧看到了一部名为A Celebration of Birds的 PBS 电视纪录片，它总结了 Roger Tory Peterson 的生活和工作。这部电影太美了，我想更多地了解他。引起我注意的是，彼得森在 84 岁时仍然保持着旺盛的势头——每天画四个小时，并在世界各地的栖息地拍摄鸟类。那确实让我感兴趣。鸟类不是我的主题，但幸存者是：老年人如何继续前进。我记得彼得森住在康涅狄格州的一个小镇，离我们全家夏天去的地方不远。我可以开车过去见他；如果振动不正确，除了一加仑汽油外，什么都不会损失。我告诉奥杜邦编辑 我会尝试一些非正式的——“拜访罗杰·托里·彼得森”，而不是主要人物。

Something came up, however, that changed my mind about the Audubon offer. I happened to see a PBS television documentary called A Celebration of Birds, which summed up Roger Tory Peterson’s life and work. The film had so much beauty that I wanted to know more about him. What caught my attention was that Peterson was still going at full momentum at 84—painting four hours a day and photographing birds in habitats all over the world. That did interest me. Birds aren’t my subject, but survivors are: how old people keep going. I remembered that Peterson lived in a Connecticut town not far from where our family goes in the summer. I could just drive over and meet him; if the vibrations weren’t right, nothing would be lost except a gallon of gas. I told the Audubon editor I would try something informal—“a visit with Roger Tory Peterson,” not a major profile.

当然，它确实变成了一个重要的简介，长达 4,000 字，因为我一看到彼得森的工作室，我就意识到，像我一直这样认为他是一名鸟类学家，就是错过了他生活的重点。他首先是一位艺术家。正是他作为画家的技巧，让数百万人了解了他关于鸟类的知识，并赋予了他作为作家、编辑和环保主义者的权威。我向他询问了他早期的老师和导师——约翰斯隆和埃德温狄金森等美国主要艺术家——以及伟大的鸟类画家詹姆斯奥杜邦和路易斯阿加西富埃特斯的影响，我的故事变成了一个艺术故事和一个教学故事以及一个鸟类故事，引起了我的许多兴趣。这也是一个幸存者的故事；在他 80 多岁的时候，彼得森的日程安排会让一个 50 岁的人感到负担重重。

Of course it did turn into a major profile, 4,000 words long, because as soon as I saw Peterson’s studio I realized that to think of him as an ornithologist, as I always had, was to miss the point of his life. He was above all an artist. It was his skill as a painter that had made his knowledge of birds accessible to millions and had given him his authority as a writer, editor and conservationist. I asked him about his early teachers and mentors—major American artists like John Sloan and Edwin Dickinson—and about the influence of the great bird painters James Audubon and Louis Agassiz Fuertes, and my story became an art story and a teaching story as well as a bird story, engaging many of my interests. It was also a survivor story; in his mid-80s Peterson was on a schedule that would tax a man of 50.

非虚构类作家的寓意是：广泛地思考你的任务。不要假设Audubon的文章必须严格地与自然有关，或者Car & Driver的文章必须严格地与汽车有关。突破你的主题的界限，看看它会把你带到哪里。将自己生活的一部分带入其中；在您编写之前，这不是您的故事版本。

The moral for nonfiction writers is: think broadly about your assignment. Don’t assume that an article for Audubon has to be strictly about nature, or an article for Car & Driver strictly about cars. Push the boundaries of your subject and see where it takes you. Bring some part of your own life to it; it’s not your version of the story until you write it.

至于我对彼得森故事的版本，它在奥杜邦播出后不久，我妻子在我们家的答录机上发现了一条消息，上面写着：“这是写自然的威廉·津瑟吗？” 她认为这很有趣，事实也确实如此。但事实上，我的文章被观鸟社区视为彼得森的权威肖像。我提到这一点是为了给所有非小说类作家带来信心：一个技巧点。如果你掌握了交易的工具——采访和有序构建的基础——如果你把你的一般智慧和人性带到任务中，你可以写任何主题。这是您通往有趣生活的入场券。

As for my version of the Peterson story, not long after it ran in Audubon my wife found a message on our home answering machine that said, “Is this the William Zinsser who writes about nature?” She thought it was hilarious, and it was. But in fact my article was received by the birding community as a definitive portrait of Peterson. I mention this to give confidence to all nonfiction writers: a point of craft. If you master the tools of the trade—the fundamentals of interviewing and of orderly construction—and if you bring to the assignment your general intelligence and your humanity, you can write about any subject. That’s your ticket to an interesting life.

尽管如此，还是很难不被专家的专业知识所吓倒。你会想，“这个人对他的领域非常了解，我太笨了，无法采访他。他会认为我很愚蠢。” 他之所以对自己的领域如此了解，是因为这是他的领域；你是一个多面手，试图让公众接触到他的作品。这意味着敦促他澄清对他来说如此显而易见的陈述，以至于他认为这些陈述对其他人来说都是显而易见的。相信你的常识来弄清楚你需要知道什么，不要害怕问一个愚蠢的问题。如果专家认为你很笨，那是他的问题。

Still, it’s hard not to be intimidated by the expertise of the expert. You think, “This man knows so much about his field, I’m too dumb to interview him. He’ll think I’m stupid.” The reason he knows so much about his field is because it’s his field; you’re a generalist trying to make his work accessible to the public. That means prodding him to clarify statements that are so obvious to him that he assumes they are obvious to everyone else. Trust your common sense to figure out what you need to know, and don’t be afraid to ask a dumb question. If the expert thinks you’re dumb, that’s his problem.

你的测试应该是：专家的第一个答案是否足够？通常不是。当我报名参加进入彼得森领地的第二次探险时，我了解到了这一点。艺术书籍出版商 Rizzoli 的一位编辑打电话说，该公司正在准备一本关于“罗杰·托里·彼得森的艺术与摄影”的咖啡桌书，其中包含数百个彩色图版。需要一篇 8,000 字的文字，作为新的彼得森权威，我被要求撰写。谈论热闹。

Your test should be: is the expert’s first answer sufficient? Usually it’s not. I learned that when I signed up for a second expedition into Peterson territory. An editor at Rizzoli, the publisher of art books, called to say that the firm was preparing a coffee-table volume on “The Art and Photography of Roger Tory Peterson,” with hundreds of color plates. An 8,000-word text was needed, and as the new Peterson authority I was asked to write it. Talk about hilarious.

我告诉编辑，我强调永远不要把同一个故事写两次。我第一次尽可能仔细地写了我的奥杜邦文章，并且无法修改它。不过，如果他能获得我的文章并在他的书中转载，他会很高兴。他同意，如果我再写 4,000 字——隐形编织——那将主要涉及彼得森作为艺术家和摄影师的方法。

I told the editor that I made it a point never to write the same story twice. I had written my Audubon article as carefully as I could the first time and wouldn’t be able to rework it. He would be welcome, however, to acquire and reprint my article in his book. He agreed to that if I would write an additional 4,000 words—invisible weaving—that would deal mainly with Peterson’s methods as an artist and a photographer.

这听起来很有趣，我带着一组新问题回到彼得森那里，比我为奥杜邦向他提出的问题更具技术性。那个听众想听听生活。现在我是为想知道这位艺术家是如何创作他的艺术的读者写作的，我的问题直接归结为过程和技术。我们从绘画开始。

That sounded interesting, and I went back to Peterson with a new set of questions, more technical than the ones I had put to him for Audubon. That audience had wanted to hear about a life. Now I was writing for readers who wanted to know how the artist created his art, and my questions got right down to process and technique. We began with painting.

“我称我的作品为‘混合媒体’，”彼得森告诉我，“因为我的主要目的是指导。我可能会从透明的水彩画开始，然后是水粉画，然后我给它涂上一层丙烯酸保护层，然后我用丙烯酸或淡淡的蜡笔、彩色铅笔、铅笔或墨水——任何能做的都可以我想要的是。”

“I call my work ‘mixed media,’” Peterson told me, “because my main purpose is to instruct. I may start with transparent watercolors, then I go to gouache, then I give it a protective coat of acrylic, then I go over that with acrylics or a touch of pastel, or colored pencil, or pencil, or ink—anything that will do what I want.”

从我之前的采访中我知道彼得森的第一个答案很少是足够的。他是一个沉默寡言的人，是瑞典移民的儿子，从不张扬。我问他现在的技术与以前的方法有何不同。

I knew from my earlier interview that Peterson’s first answer was seldom sufficient. He was a taciturn man, the son of Swedish immigrants, not given to amplitude. I asked him how his present technique differed from his previous methods.

“现在我正跨骑，”他说。“我试图在不失去简化效果的情况下添加更多细节。” 然后他又停了下来。

“Right now I’m straddling,” he said. “I’m trying to add more detail without losing the simplified effect.” Then he stopped again.

但为什么他觉得在他生命的这个晚期阶段他需要更多细节？

But why did he feel that he needed more detail at this late point in his life?

“多年来，很多人已经熟悉了我的鸟的笔直轮廓，”他说，“他们开始想要更多的东西：羽毛的外观，或者更立体的感觉。”

“Over the years so many people have become familiar with the straight profile of my birds,” he said, “that they’ve begun to want something more: the look of feathers, or a more three-dimensional feeling.”

在我们完成了绘画之后，我们转向了摄影。彼得森回忆起他曾经拥有的每一台鸟类拍摄相机，从 13 岁开始使用 Primo #9，它使用玻璃板和波纹管，最后以对自动对焦和补光闪光等现代技术的赞誉而告终。不是摄影师，我从来没有听说过自动对焦或补充闪光灯，但我只需要揭露我的愚蠢就可以了解为什么它们如此有用。自动对焦：“如果你能在取景器中找到鸟，相机就会完成剩下的工作。” Fill-in flash：“电影永远不会像你看到的那样多。人眼可以看到阴影中的细节，但补充闪光灯可以让相机捕捉到这些细节。”

After we got through with painting we moved on to photography. Peterson recalled every bird-shooting camera he ever owned, starting at age 13 with a Primo #9, which used glass plates and had bellows, and ended with praise for such modern technology as auto-focus and the fill-in flash. Not being a photographer, I had never heard of auto-focus or the fill-in flash, but I only had to reveal my stupidity to learn why they are so helpful. Auto-focus: “If you can get the bird in your viewfinder the camera will do the rest.” Fill-in flash: “Film never sees as much as you see. The human eye sees detail in the shadows, but the fill-in flash enables the camera to pick up that detail.”

然而，技术只是技术，彼得森提醒我。“很多人认为好的设备会让事情变得简单，”他说。“他们误以为相机可以搞定一切。” 他知道他的意思，但我需要知道为什么相机不能做到这一切。当我用我的“为什么不呢？”向他施压时 和我的“还有什么？” 我得到的不只是一个答案，而是三个：

Technology, however, is only technology, Peterson reminded me. “Many people think good equipment makes it easy,” he said. “They’re deceived into thinking the camera does it all.” He knew what he meant by that, but I needed to know why the camera doesn’t do it all. When I pressed him with my “Why not?” and my “What else?” I got not just one answer but three:

“作为一名摄影师，你会在这个过程中运用你的眼光和构图感，还有温暖——例如，你不会在正午或一天的开始或结束时拍摄照片。您还要注意光线的质量；薄薄的阴天可以做些好事。对动物的了解也是一个巨大的帮助：预测一只鸟会做什么。当鸟儿以成群结队的鱼为食时，您可以预见到诸如觅食狂潮之类的活动。狂热的喂食对摄影师来说很重要，因为鸟类做的基本事情之一就是吃东西，如果它们吃东西，它们会忍受你更长的时间。事实上，他们经常会忽视你。”

“As a photographer, you bring your eye and a sense of composition to the process, and also warmth—you don’t shoot pictures at high noon, for instance, or at the beginning or the end of the day. You’re also mindful of the quality of light; a thin overcast can do nice things. Knowledge of the animal is also a tremendous help: anticipating what a bird will do. You can anticipate such activities as a feeding frenzy, when birds feed on fish traveling in small groups. Feeding frenzies are important to a photographer because one of the basic things birds do is eat, and they’ll put up with you a lot longer if they’re eating. In fact, they’ll often ignore you.”

因此，专家先生和愚蠢先生，我们继续进行，直到我提取出许多我觉得有趣的想法。“我中途回到奥杜邦，”彼得森说——那很有趣——“所以我对因环保运动而发生的变化有一种感觉。” 他回忆说，在他的童年时代，每个拿着弹弓的孩子都会射鸟，许多物种已经被猎人杀死或濒临灭绝，猎人为了羽毛、卖给餐馆或娱乐而屠杀它们。好消息是，他已经活了足够长的时间才看到，许多物种在公民的帮助下从九死一生中卷土重来，公民现在在保护鸟类及其栖息地方面发挥积极作用。接着他说：“人对鸟的态度改变了鸟对人的态度。”

So we proceeded, Mr. Expert and Mr. Stupid, until I had extracted many ideas that I found interesting. “I go halfway back to Audubon,” Peterson said—that was interesting—“so I have a feeling for the changes that have taken place because of the environmental movement.” In his boyhood, he recalled, every kid with a slingshot would shoot birds, and many species had been killed off or brought close to extermination by hunters who slaughtered them for their plumes, or to sell to restaurants, or for sport. The good news, which he had lived long enough to see, was that many species had made a comeback from their narrow escape, helped by a citizenry that now takes an active role in protecting birds and their habitats. Then he said: “The attitude of people towards birds has changed the attitude of birds towards people.”

那很有趣。作为一名作家，我经常对自己说“这很有趣”，这让我感到震惊。如果您发现自己在说，请注意并跟随您的鼻子。相信您的好奇心，才能与读者的好奇心联系起来。

That was interesting. I’m struck by how often as a writer I say to myself, “That’s interesting.” If you find yourself saying it, pay attention and follow your nose. Trust your curiosity to connect with the curiosity of your readers.

彼得森所说的鸟类改变它们的态度是什么意思？

What did Peterson mean about birds changing their attitudes?

“乌鸦变得更驯服了，”他说。“海鸥增加了——它们是垃圾场的清理人员。最小的燕鸥已经开始在购物中心的顶部筑巢；几年前，密西西比州戈蒂埃的 Singing River Mall 屋顶上有一千双鞋。反舌鸟特别喜欢商场——它们喜欢种植，尤其是多花玫瑰；它的小臀部小到足以让它们吞咽。他们也喜欢购物中心的喧嚣——他们坐在​​那里指挥交通。”

“Crows are becoming tamer,” he said. “Gulls have increased—they’re the cleanup crew at garbage dumps. The Least Tern has taken to nesting on top of shopping malls; a few years ago there were a thousand pair on the roof of the Singing River Mall in Gautier, Mississippi. Mockingbirds are particularly fond of malls—they like the planting, especially the multiflora rose; its tiny hips are small enough for them to swallow. They also enjoy the bustle of shopping malls—they sit there and direct the traffic.”

我们在彼得森的工作室里谈了几个小时。这个工作室是艺术和科学的一个小前哨——画架、颜料、画笔、绘画、版画、地图、照相机、摄影器材、部落面具，以及成架的参考书和期刊——在我访问结束时，当他送我出去的时候，我说，“我都看到了吗？” 通常，在你放下铅笔后，在告别的闲聊中，你会得到最好的材料。接受采访的人，在努力让自己的生活在陌生人面前表现得体之后，摆脱了困境，想到了一些重要的事后想法。

We had been talking for several hours in Peterson’s studio. The studio was a small outpost of the arts and sciences—easels, paints, paintbrushes, paintings, prints, maps, cameras, photographic equipment, tribal masks, and shelves of reference books and journals—and at the end of my visit, as he was walking me out, I said, “Have I seen everything?” Often you’ll get your best material after you put your pencil away, in the chitchat of leave-taking. The person being interviewed, off the hook after the hard work of making his or her life presentable to a stranger, thinks of a few important afterthoughts.

当我问我是否看过所有东西时，彼得森说：“你想看看我的鸟类收藏吗？” 我说我当然会。他带我走下外面的楼梯，来到一扇地窖门，他打开了门，把我带到了一个满是橱柜和抽屉的地下室——科学储藏所熟悉的家具，让人想起每一个从未现代化过的小型大学博物馆。达尔文可能用过这样的抽屉。

When I asked whether I had seen everything, Peterson said, “Would you like to see my collection of birds?” I said I certainly would. He led me down an outside staircase to a cellar door, which he unlocked, ushering me into a basement full of cabinets and drawers—the familiar furniture of scientific storage, reminiscent of every small college museum that never got modernized. Darwin might have used such drawers.

“我这里有两千个标本用于研究，”他告诉我。“它们中的大多数都在一百岁左右，而且它们仍然有用。” 他拉开抽屉，拿出一只鸟，给我看标签，上面写着 ACORN WOODPECKER，1882 年 4 月 10 日。这只鸟已经 112 岁了，”他说。他打开了其他一些抽屉，轻轻地拿着其他几位已故的维多利亚时代人物让我思考——这与格罗弗克利夫兰的总统任期有关。

“I’ve got two thousand specimens down here that I use for research,” he told me. “Most of them are around a hundred years old, and they’re still useful.” He pulled open a drawer and took out a bird and showed me the tag, which said ACORN WOODPECKER, APRIL 10, 1882. “Think of it! This bird is 112 years old,” he said. He opened some other drawers and gently held several other late Victorians for me to ponder—a link to the presidency of Grover Cleveland.

里佐利 (Rizzoli) 的书连同令人惊叹的绘画和照片于 1995 年出版，一年后彼得森去世，他的探索终于结束，他已经看到了世界上 9,000 种鸟类中的“略多于 4,500 种”。我喜欢花在这两篇文章上的时间吗？我真的不能说我做到了；彼得森太闷闷不乐了，一点也不好玩。但我很高兴讲述了一个复杂的故事，它让我脱离了正常的经历。我还收藏了一只我自己的珍稀鸟类，当我把彼得森和我收集的其他标本一起放在抽屉里时，我想：这很有趣。

The Rizzoli book, with its stunning paintings and photographs, was published in 1995, and Peterson died a year later, his quest finally over, having sighted “scarcely more than 4,500” of the world’s 9,000 species of birds. Did I enjoy the time I spent on the two articles? I can’t really say I did; Peterson was too dour for that, not much fun. But I enjoyed having brought off a complicated story that took me outside my normal experience. I also had bagged a rare bird of my own, and when I put Peterson away in a drawer with my other collected specimens, I thought: that was interesting.

22

22

最终产品的暴政

The Tyranny of the Final Product

在我在曼哈顿新学校教授多年的写作课程中，学生们经常告诉我他们有一个想法可以完美地发表在纽约、体育画报或其他杂志上。这是我最不想听到的。他们已经可以将他们的故事印成印刷品：标题、布局、照片，最重要的是，署名。现在他们所要做的就是编写它。

In the writing course that I’ve taught for many years at the New School, in Manhattan, students often tell me they have an idea for an article that would be perfect for New York, or for Sports Illustrated, or for some other magazine. That’s the last thing I want to hear. They can already picture their story in print: the headline, the layout, the photographs and, best of all, the byline. Now all they have to do is write it.

这种对完成文章的固定给作者带来了很多麻烦，使他们偏离了为确定其形状、声音和内容而必须做出的所有早期决定。这是一种非常美国式的麻烦。我们是一种崇拜胜利结果的文化：联赛冠军，高分。教练的报酬是为了获胜，教师的价值在于让学生进入最好的大学。一路上取得的不那么光鲜亮丽的收获——学习、智慧、成长、自信、处理失败——没有得到同样的尊重，因为它们无法被给予评分。

This fixation on the finished article causes writers a lot of trouble, deflecting them from all the earlier decisions that have to be made to determine its shape and voice and content. It’s a very American kind of trouble. We are a culture that worships the winning result: the league championship, the high test score. Coaches are paid to win, teachers are valued for getting students into the best colleges. Less glamorous gains made along the way—learning, wisdom, growth, confidence, dealing with failure—aren’t given the same respect because they can’t be given a grade.

对于作家来说，获奖成绩就是支票。专业作家在写作会议上最常被问到的问题是“我怎样才能卖掉我的作品？” 这是我唯一不想回答的问题，部分原因是我不合格——我不知道当今市场的编辑在寻找什么；但愿我做了，可惜我没有。但主要是因为我没有兴趣教作家如何销售。我想教他们怎么写。如果流程合理，产品就会自行处理，销售也很可能随之而来。

For writers the winning grade is the check. The question that professional authors get asked most often at writing conferences is “How can I sell my writing?” It’s the only question I won’t try to answer, partly because I’m not qualified—I have no idea what editors in today’s market are looking for; I wish I did. But mainly it’s because I have no interest in teaching writers how to sell. I want to teach them how to write. If the process is sound, the product will take care of itself, and sales are likely to follow.

这是我在新学校开设课程的前提。它由思想开明的学者于 1919 年作为社会研究新学院创立，从那时起一直是该市最具活力的学习中心之一。我喜欢在那里教书，因为我一直对它的历史作用深表同情：提供信息，帮助积极进取的成年人继续他们的生活。我喜欢乘地铁来参加我的晚间课程，喜欢成为男男女女进出大楼和刚下课的人群中的一员。

That’s the premise of my course at the New School. Founded in 1919 by liberal-minded scholars as the New School for Social Research, it has been one of the city’s most vibrant centers of learning ever since. I like to teach there because I’ve always felt sympathetic to its historic role: to provide information that helps motivated adults to get on with their lives. I like arriving by subway for my evening class and being part of the rush of men and women entering the building and getting out of classes that have just ended.

我选择“人物和地点”作为我课程的标题，因为它们共同构成了说明文写作的核心。通过专注于这两个要素，我认为我能够教授非虚构类作家需要知道的大部分内容：如何将他们所写的内容放在特定的地方，以及如何让住在那个地方的人谈论是什么让它——或者曾经让它——特别。

I chose “People and Places” as the title of my course because together they are at the heart of expository writing. By concentrating on those two elements I thought I would be able to teach much of what nonfiction writers need to know: how to situate what they write in a particular place, and how to get the people who live in that place to talk about what makes it—or once made it—special.

但我也想进行一个实验。作为一名编辑和一名教师，我发现在非小说类写作中最未被教授和被低估的技能是如何组织一篇长篇文章：如何将拼图拼在一起。作家们被无休止地教导如何写出清晰的陈述句。但是让他们尝试更广泛的东西——一篇文章或一本书——他们的句子会像弹珠一样散落一地。冗长手稿的每位编辑都知道不可逆转的混乱的严峻时刻。这位作家的眼睛一直盯着终点线，却从来没有充分考虑过如何跑完比赛。

But I also wanted to conduct an experiment. As an editor and a teacher I’ve found that the most untaught and underestimated skill in nonfiction writing is how to organize a long article: how to put the jigsaw puzzle together. Writers are endlessly taught how to write a clear declarative sentence. But ask them to try something more extensive—an article or a book—and their sentences leach out all over the floor like marbles. Every editor of a lengthy manuscript knows that grim moment of irreversible chaos. The writer, his eye on the finish line, never gave enough thought to how to run the race.

我想知道是否有任何方法可以使作家摆脱对完整写作行为的迷恋。突然间，我有了一个激进的想法：我将教授一门不需要写作的写作课程。

I wondered if there was any way to wrest writers away from their infatuation with the completed act of writing. Suddenly I had a radical idea: I would teach a writing course in which no writing is required.

在我们的第一节课上，我的班级由两打成年人组成——从那以后一直如此——从二十多岁到六十多岁，大多数是女性。少数是郊区小报、电视台和行业杂志的记者。但他们主要是那些从事日常工作的人，他们想学习如何使用写作来理解他们的生活：找出他们在那个特定时刻是谁，他们曾经是谁，以及他们出生在什么样的背景下。

At our first session my class consisted—as it has ever since—of two dozen adults, ranging from their twenties to their sixties, mostly women. A few were journalists with small suburban newspapers and television stations and trade magazines. But mainly they were people with everyday jobs who wanted to learn how to use writing to make sense of their lives: to find out who they were at that particular moment, who they once were, and what heritage they were born into.

我在第一节课中专门介绍了我们所有人，并解释了一些关于人物和地方的写作原则。最后我说：“下周我要你来这里，准备好告诉我们一个你想写的对你来说很重要的地方。告诉我们你为什么要写它，以及你想如何写它。” 我从来不是一个喜欢大声朗读学生作文的老师，除非它非常好；人们对他们所写的东西太脆弱了。但我猜想他们不会对自己只是在想什么感到难为情。思想还没有投向圣纸；它们可以随时更改、重新排列或取消。尽管如此，我还是不知道会发生什么。

I devoted the first period to getting us all introduced and explaining some of the principles of writing about people and places. At the end I said: “Next week I want you to come here prepared to tell us about one place that’s important to you that you’d like to write about. Tell us why you want to write about it and how you want to write about it.” I’ve never been a teacher who likes to read student writing aloud unless it’s unusually good; people are too vulnerable about what they have written. But I guessed that they wouldn’t be self-conscious about what they were merely thinking. Thoughts haven’t been committed to sacred paper; they can always be changed or rearranged or disowned. Still, I didn’t know what to expect.

接下来一周的第一位志愿者是一位年轻女士，她说她想写下她位于第五大道上段的教堂，该教堂最近发生了一场大火。虽然教堂重新投入使用，但它的墙壁已经变黑，木头被烧焦，并且散发出烟味。这位女士觉得这很不安，她想弄清楚这场火灾对她作为教区居民和教会意味着什么。我问她打算写什么。她说她可能会采访部长、管风琴师、消防员、教堂司事或唱诗班指挥。

The first volunteer the following week was a young woman who said she wanted to write about her church, on upper Fifth Avenue, which had recently had a bad fire. Although the church was back in use, its walls were blackened and its wood was charred and it smelled of smoke. The woman found that unsettling, and she wanted to sort out what the fire meant to her as a parishioner and to the church. I asked her what she proposed to write. She said she might interview the minister, or the organist, or the firemen, or maybe the sexton, or the choirmaster.

“你给了我们五篇弗朗西斯·克林斯 (Francis X. Clines) 的好作品，”我告诉她，她指的是纽约时报的一位热情而出色地撰写当地特色的记者。“但它们对你、对我或对这门课程来说都不够好。我要你更深入。我希望你在你自己和你所写的地方之间找到一些联系。”

“You’ve given us five good pieces by Francis X. Clines,” I told her, referring to a New York Times reporter who writes local features warmly and well. “But they’re not good enough for you, or for me, or for this course. I want you to go deeper. I want you to find some connection between yourself and the place you’re writing about.”

女人问我想要什么样的作品。我说我不愿意推荐一个，因为课程的想法是集体思考我们的方式以找到可能的解决方案。但因为她是我们的第一只豚鼠，我会试一试。“接下来几周你去教堂的时候，”我说，“就坐在那里想想那场大火。三四个星期天之后，教堂会告诉你那场大火意味着什么。” 然后我说：“上帝会告诉那个教会告诉你火是什么意思。”

The woman asked what sort of piece I had in mind. I said I was reluctant to suggest one because the idea of the course was to think our way collectively to possible solutions. But since she was our first guinea pig I would give it a try. “When you go to church in the next few weeks,” I said, “just sit there and think about the fire. After three or four Sundays the church is going to tell you what that fire means.” Then I said: “God is going to tell that church to tell you what the fire means.”

教室里传来轻微的喘息声；美国人一提到宗教就会感到反感。但是学生们看到我是认真的，从那一刻起他们就认真对待了我的想法。每周他们都会邀请我们其他人进入他们的生活，告诉我们一些触动他们兴趣或情感的地方，并试图决定如何写它。我会在每堂课的前半部分教授技巧，并阅读非小说类作家的文章，他们解决了学生们正在努力解决的问题。另一半是我们的实验室：作家组织问题的解剖表。

There was a small gasp in the classroom; Americans get squeamish at any mention of religion. But the students saw that I was serious, and from that moment they took my idea seriously. Every week they invited the rest of us into their lives, telling us about some place that touched their interests or their emotions and trying to decide how to write about it. I would spend the first half of each class teaching the craft and reading passages by nonfiction writers who had solved issues the students were struggling with. The other half was our lab: a dissecting table of writers’ organizational problems.

到目前为止，最大的问题是压缩：如何从大量错综复杂的经验、感受和记忆中提炼出连贯的叙述。“我想写一篇关于爱荷华州小镇消失的文章，”一位女士告诉我们，她描述了自从她还是祖父母农场里的一个女孩以来，中西部的生活结构是如何支离破碎的。这是一个很好的美国主题，作为社会史很有价值。但是没有人能写出一篇关于爱荷华州小镇消失的像样的文章；这将是一概而论，没有人性。作家将不得不写一个爱荷华州的一个小镇，从而讲述她更大的故事，即使在那个小镇里，她也必须进一步缩小她的故事：一家商店、一个家庭或一个农民。我们讨论了不同的方法，作者逐渐将她的故事细化到人的尺度。

By far the biggest problem was compression: how to distill a coherent narrative from a huge and tangled mass of experiences and feelings and memories. “I want to write an article about the disappearance of small towns in Iowa,” one woman told us, describing how the fabric of life in the Midwest had frayed since she was a girl on her grandparents’ farm. It was a good American subject, valuable as social history. But nobody can write a decent article about the disappearance of small towns in Iowa; it would be all generalization and no humanity. The writer would have to write about one small town in Iowa and thereby tell her larger story, and even within that one town she would have to reduce her story still further: to one store, or one family, or one farmer. We talked about different approaches, and the writer gradually thought her story down to human scale.

令我震惊的是，我的学生经常通过摸索突然发现正确的道路，这对房间里的每个人来说都是显而易见的。一个人会说他想尝试写一篇关于他曾经居住过的小镇的​​文章，并会冒险尝试一种可能的方法：“我可以写关于X 的文章。” 然而，即使对他来说，X也毫无兴趣，缺乏任何独特性， Y和Z也是如此，P和Q和R也是如此，作者继续挖掘他生活的碎片，几乎是偶然地，他偶然发现了米，一个被遗忘已久的记忆，看似不重要但无可置疑的真实，将所有让他首先想写下这个小镇的事情都包含在一个事件中。“这是你的故事，”班上有几个人会说，而且确实如此。学生有时间找到它。

I was struck by how often my students’ gropings led to a sudden revelation of the proper path, obvious to everyone in the room. A man would say that he wanted to try a piece about the town where he once lived and would venture a possible approach: “I could write about X.” X, however, was uninteresting, even to him, lacking any distinctiveness, and so were Y and Z, and so were P and Q and R, the writer continuing to dredge up fragments of his life, when, almost accidentally, he stumbled into M, a long-forgotten memory, seemingly unimportant but unassailably true, encapsulating in one incident everything that had made him want to write about the town in the first place. “There’s your story,” several people in the class would say, and it was. The student had been given time to find it.

从即时性中释放出来是我想要进入学生新陈代谢的东西。我告诉他们，如果他们真的写了他们的文章，我会很高兴阅读它，即使他们在课程结束后将其发送给我，但这不是我的主要兴趣。我主要对过程感兴趣，而不是产品。起初，这让他们感到不安。这就是美国——他们不仅想要验证；还想要验证。这是他们的民族权利。相当多的人私下里，几乎是偷偷摸摸地来找我，好像让我知道了一些卑鄙的秘密，并说，“你知道，这是我上过的唯一一门不受市场驱动的写作课程。” 这是一个令人沮丧的句子。但过了一会儿，他们发现从最后期限中解脱出来是一种解放，这是他们所有学校、大学和研究生时代的怪物（“论文将于周五到期”），永不满足地要求喂食。他们放松并喜欢考虑以不同的方式到达他们想去的地方。其中一些方法行得通，而另一些则行不通。失败的权利是一种解放。

That release from immediacy was what I wanted to get into the metabolism of my students. I told them that if they actually wrote their piece I would be glad to read it, even if they sent it to me after the course was over, but that that wasn’t my primary interest. I was primarily interested in the process, not the product. At first that made them uneasy. This was America—they not only wanted validation; it was their national right. Quite a few came to me privately, almost furtively, as if letting me in on some shabby secret, and said, “You know, this is the only writing course I’ve ever taken that isn’t market-driven.” It’s a depressing sentence. But after a while they found it liberating to be freed from a deadline, the monster of all their school and college and postgraduate years (“the paper is due on Friday”), insatiably demanding to be fed. They relaxed and enjoyed considering different ways of getting where they wanted to go. Some of those ways would work and some wouldn’t. The right to fail was liberating.

偶尔我会在研讨会上向中小学教师介绍这门课程。我并没有特别期望他们会发现它适合他们的年龄段——青少年的记忆和依恋比成年人少。但他们总是催促我了解更多细节。当我问他们为什么如此感兴趣时，他们说，“你给了我们一个新的时间表。” 他们的意思是，传统的短期论文分配可能是教师长期以来毫无疑问地遵循的传统。他们开始考虑写作业，给学生更多的空间，并根据不同的期望来评判。

Occasionally I’ve described this course to elementary and high school teachers at a workshop. I didn’t particularly expect them to find it pertinent to their age group—adolescents with fewer memories and attachments than adults have. But they always pressed me for more details. When I asked why they were so interested they said, “You’ve given us a new timetable.” By which they meant that the traditional assigning of short-term papers may be a tradition that teachers have followed too unquestioningly for too long. They began to muse about writing assignments that would give their pupils more room and would be judged by different expectations.

我的课程方法——思考一个特定的地方——只是一种教学手段。我的真正目的是为作家提供一种新的心态，一种他们可以将其应用于此后可能尝试的任何写作项目的心态，并为旅程留出尽可能多的时间。对于我的一个学生，一名 30 多岁的律师，这段旅程花了三年时间。1996 年的一天，他打电话给我说，他终于克服了他在 1993 年向我们班提出的组织问题。我会看一下吗？

The methodology of my course—thinking of a particular place—is only a pedagogical device. My real purpose was to give writers a new mentality, one they could apply to whatever writing projects they might try thereafter, allowing as much time as they need for the journey. For one of my students, a lawyer in his late 30s, the journey took three years. One day in 1996 he called me to say that he had finally wrestled into submission the subject whose organizational problems he had presented to our class in 1993. Would I look at it?

到达的是一份 350 页的手稿。我承认我的一部分不想收到一份 350 页的手稿。但我内心的很大一部分人很高兴，因为我启动的过程已经走到了尽头。我也很好奇律师是怎么解决他的问题的，因为我记得很清楚。

What arrived was a 350-page manuscript. I’ll admit that one part of me didn’t want to receive a 350-page manuscript. But a larger part of me was delighted that the process I had set in motion had worked its way to a conclusion. I was also curious to see how the lawyer had solved his problems, because I remembered them well.

他告诉我们，他想写的地方是他长大的康涅狄格州郊区的小镇，他的主题是足球。作为一个男孩在校队踢球，他与其他五个和他一样热爱这项运动的男孩建立了亲密的友谊，他想写下这段亲密的经历，以及他对足球提供它的感激之情。我说这是一个好作家的主题：回忆录。

The place he wanted to write about, he told us, was the town in suburban Connecticut where he grew up, and his theme was soccer. Playing on the school team as a boy, he had formed close friendships with five other boys who loved the sport as much as he did, and he wanted to write about that bonding experience and his gratitude to soccer for providing it. I said that was a good writer’s subject: a memoir.

律师继续说，这种联系是如此牢固，以至于这六名男子在东北地区仍然作为中年专业人士保持联系——他们继续定期见面——他还想写下那次经历，以及他对这样的人的感激之情持久的友谊。我说那也是一个很好的主题：个人论文。

So strong was the bond, the lawyer went on to say, that the six men were still bonded as midlife professionals in the northeast—they continued to see each other regularly—and he also wanted to write about that experience and about his gratitude for such lasting friendships. I said that was also a good subject: a personal essay.

但还有更多。律师还想写一下今天的足球状况。他记得的这项运动的质地已经被社会变革侵蚀了。他说，在其他损失中，球员不再在更衣室更衣；他们在家里穿上制服，开车去田野，然后再开车回家。这位律师的想法是在他的母校自愿担任足球教练，并写下现在和过去的对比。这又是一个不错的主题：调查报道。

But there was more. The lawyer also wanted to write about the state of soccer today. The texture of the sport he remembered had been eroded by social change. Among other losses, he said, players no longer change in the locker room; they get into their uniform at home and drive to the field and then drive home again. The lawyer’s idea was to volunteer as a soccer coach at his old school and to write about the contrast between the present and the past. That was still another good subject: investigative reporting.

我很喜欢听律师的故事。我被带入了一个我一无所知的世界，而他对那个世界的热爱很吸引人。但我也知道他快要发疯了，我就这样告诉了他。他无法将所有这些故事都放在一个小屋檐下；他将不得不选择一个具有自身统一性的故事。事实证明，他确实把所有这些故事都安置在一个屋檐下，但房子必须大大扩大，这项工作花了三年时间。

I enjoyed hearing the lawyer’s story. I was being taken into a world I knew nothing about, and his affection for that world was appealing. But I also knew that he was about to drive himself crazy, and I told him so. He couldn’t fit all those stories under one small roof; he would have to choose one story that had its own unity. As it turned out, he did fit all those stories under one roof, but the house had to be greatly enlarged and the job took three years.

在我读完他的手稿《我们生命的秋天》后，他问我是否可以提交给出版商。还没有，我告诉他；它仍然是一个重写。也许他只是不想做出那样的努力。他想了想，说走了这么远，再试一次。

After I had read his manuscript, which was called The Autumn of Our Lives, he asked me if it was good enough to submit to a publisher. Not yet, I told him; it was still one rewrite away. Maybe he just didn’t want to make that kind of effort. He gave it some thought and said that, having traveled this far, he would give it one more shot.

“但即使它永远不会发表，”他说，“我很高兴我做到了。我无法开始告诉你这对我有多重要——写下足球在我生命中的意义是多么有益。”

“But even if it never gets published,” he said, “I’m glad I did it. I can’t begin to tell you how important this has been to me—how rewarding it’s been to write about what soccer has meant in my life.”

我想到了最后两个词。一个是追求，一个是意图。

Two final words occur to me. One is quest, the other is intention.

探索是讲故事中最古老的主题之一，是一种我们永远不会厌倦的信仰行为。回顾过去，我注意到我班上的许多学生被分配去思考一个对他们来说很重要的地方，他们利用这项作业去探索比这个地方本身更深刻的东西：一种意义、一种想法、过去的。结果是班级总是对一群陌生人充满热情。（有些班级甚至举行了聚会。）学生开始的每一次探索都会在我们自己的一些探索或渴望中找到回声。寓意：任何时候你都能以探索或朝圣的形式讲述一个故事，你就会领先于游戏。带有自己联想的读者会为您做一些工作。

The quest is one of the oldest themes in storytelling, an act of faith we never get tired of hearing about. Looking back, I notice that many students in my class, assigned to think about a place that was important to them, used the assignment to go on a quest for something deeper than the place itself: a meaning, an idea, some sliver of the past. The result was that the class always had a warm dynamic for a group of strangers. (Some classes even held reunions.) Every quest that a student embarked on found an echo in some search or yearning of our own. Moral: any time you can tell a story in the form of a quest or a pilgrimage you’ll be ahead of the game. Readers bearing their own associations will do some of your work for you.

意图是我们希望通过写作实现的目标。称之为作家的灵魂。我们可以写作来肯定和庆祝，也可以写作来揭穿和摧毁；选择权在我们。长期以来，破坏一直是一种新闻模式，奖励窥探者和打手（或女人）以及侵犯隐私的人。但是没有人可以让我们写我们不想写的东西。我们要保持意图。非虚构作家常常忘记，他们不需要默许庸俗的工作，不需要为有自己议程的杂志编辑搬运垃圾——销售商业产品。

Intention is what we wish to accomplish with our writing. Call it the writer’s soul. We can write to affirm and to celebrate, or we can write to debunk and to destroy; the choice is ours. Destruction has long been a journalistic mode, rewarding the snoop and the hatchet man (or woman) and the invader of privacy. But nobody can make us write what we don’t want to write. We get to keep intention. Nonfiction writers often forget that they are not required to acquiesce in tawdry work, to carry the trash for magazine editors who have an agenda of their own—to sell a commercial product.

写作与性格有关。如果你的价值观是正确的，你的写作就会是正确的。这一切都始于意图。弄清楚你想做什么以及你想怎么做，并以人道和诚信的方式完成文章。然后你就会有东西卖了。

Writing is related to character. If your values are sound, your writing will be sound. It all begins with intention. Figure out what you want to do and how you want to do it, and work your way with humanity and integrity to the completed article. Then you’ll have something to sell.

23

23

作家的决定

A Writer’s Decisions

这是一本关于决定的书——无数连续的决定进入每一个写作行为。有些决定很大（“我应该写什么？”），有些则小到最小的单词。但所有这些都很重要。

This has been a book about decisions—the countless successive decisions that go into every act of writing. Some of the decisions are big (“What should I write about?”) and some are as small as the smallest word. But all of them are important.

上一章是关于重大决策的：形状、结构、压缩、焦点和意图。本章是关于小决定的：组织一篇长文章的数百个选择。我认为用我自己的一件作品作为被解剖的标本来展示其中一些决定是如何做出的可能会有所帮助。

The previous chapter was about big decisions: matters of shape, structure, compression, focus and intention. This chapter is about little decisions: the hundreds of choices that go into organizing a long article. I thought it might be helpful to show how some of those decisions get made, using one of my own pieces as the specimen being dissected.

学习如何组织一篇长文章与学习如何写出清晰悦耳的句子一样重要。如果你不记住写作是线性的和连续的，逻辑是把它粘在一起的胶水，从一个句子到下一个句子，从一个段落到最后一个段落都必须保持张力，那么你所有清晰和令人愉快的句子都会分崩离析接下来，从一个部分到下一个部分，这种叙述——好的老式讲故事——应该让你的读者在没有注意到拖船的情况下继续前进。他们唯一应该注意的是你已经为你的旅程制定了一个合理的计划。每一步似乎都是不可避免的。

Learning how to organize a long article is just as important as learning how to write a clear and pleasing sentence. All your clear and pleasing sentences will fall apart if you don’t keep remembering that writing is linear and sequential, that logic is the glue that holds it together, that tension must be maintained from one sentence to the next and from one paragraph to the next and from one section to the next, and that narrative—good old-fashioned storytelling—is what should pull your readers along without their noticing the tug. The only thing they should notice is that you have made a sensible plan for your journey. Every step should seem inevitable.

我在Condé Nast Traveler上刊登的名为“廷巴克图的新闻”的文章是一位作家对一个问题的解决方案，但它说明了适用于非小说类所有扩展任务的问题。我已经对这篇文章进行了注释，解释了我一路上做出的决定。

My article, called “The News From Timbuktu,” which ran in Condé Nast Traveler, is one writer’s solution to one problem, but it illustrates issues that apply to all extended tasks of nonfiction. I’ve annotated the piece, explaining the decisions I made along the way.

关于任何文章，最艰难的决定是如何开始它。领导必须用一个有启发性的想法抓住读者，并继续逐个段落紧紧抓住他或她，逐渐添加信息。这些信息的目的是让读者感兴趣，以至于他们会在整个旅程中留下来。导言可以短至一段，也可以根据需要长短。当所有必要的工作都完成后，你就会知道一切都结束了，你可以用更轻松的语气继续你的叙述。这里的第一段给了读者一个引人注目的想法来思考——我希望他们以前从未想过。

The hardest decision about any article is how to begin it. The lead must grab the reader with a provocative idea and continue with each paragraph to hold him or her in a tight grip, gradually adding information. The point of the information is to get readers so interested that they will stick around for the whole trip. The lead can be as short as one paragraph and as long as it needs to be. You’ll know it’s over when all the necessary work has been done and you can take a more relaxed tone and get on with your narrative. Here the first paragraph gives readers an arresting notion to think about—one that I hope has never occurred to them before.

当我到达廷巴克图时，给我印象最深的是街道都是沙子。我突然意识到沙子和泥土有很大的不同。每个城镇都以泥泞的街道开始，随着居民的繁荣和环境的改善，这些街道最终被铺平。但沙子代表失败。有沙子街道的城市是边缘城市。

What struck me most powerfully when I got to Timbuktu was that the streets were of sand. I suddenly realized that sand is very different from dirt. Every town starts with dirt streets that eventually get paved as the inhabitants prosper and subdue their environment. But sand represents defeat. A city with streets of sand is a city at the edge.

请注意这五个句子是多么简单：简单的陈述句，看不到逗号。每个句子都包含一个想法——而且只有一个。读者一次只能处理一个想法，而且他们是按线性顺序处理的。作家遇到的大部分麻烦都来自于试图让一句话做太多的工作。永远不要害怕将一个长句分成两个短句，甚至三个。

Notice how simple those five sentences are: plain declarative sentences, not a comma in sight. Each sentence contains one thought—and only one. Readers can process only one idea at a time, and they do it in linear sequence. Much of the trouble that writers get into comes from trying to make one sentence do too much work. Never be afraid to break a long sentence into two short ones, or even three.

当然，这就是我去那里的原因：廷巴克图是边缘寻求者的终极目的地。在巴厘岛和塔希提岛、撒马尔罕和非斯、蒙巴萨和澳门这六个总是以名字来吸引游客的地方中，没有一个能比得上廷巴克图所传达的偏远。令我惊讶的是，有多少人听说了我的旅行，并不认为廷巴克图是一个真实的地方，或者，即使是真实的地方，也无法想象它在世界上的哪个地方。他们非常了解这个词——几乎遥不可及的所有同义词中最生动的一个，是上帝赐予坚持“oo”韵律的词曲作者的玩具，也是一个比喻一个痴情的男孩为了赢得无法赢得的女孩会走多远.

That, of course, is why I was there: Timbuktu is the ultimate destination for edge-seekers. Of the half-dozen places that have always lured travelers with the mere sound of their name—Bali and Tahiti, Samarkand and Fez, Mombasa and Macao—none can match Timbuktu for the remoteness it conveys. I was surprised by how many people, hearing of my trip, didn’t think Timbuktu was a real place, or, if it was, couldn’t think where in the world it might be. They knew it well as a word—the most vivid of all synonyms for the almost-unreachable, a God-given toy for songwriters stuck for an “oo” rhyme and a metaphor for how far a lovestruck boy would go to win the unwinnable girl. But as an actual place—surely Timbuktu was one of those “long-lost” African kingdoms like King Solomon’s Mines that turned out not to exist when the Victorian explorers went looking for them.

该段的第一句源自上一段的最后一句；读者没有机会躲开。之后的段落只有一个目的：它承认读者已经知道——或一半知道——关于廷巴克图的事情。因此，它欢迎他作为一个旅伴，一个与作家本人一样为旅行带来同样情感的人。它还添加了某种信息——不是确凿的事实，而是有趣的知识。

The first sentence of that paragraph grows out of the last sentence of the previous paragraph; the reader is given no chance to squirm away. After that the paragraph has one purpose: it acknowledges what the reader already knows—or half knows—about Timbuktu. It thereby welcomes him as a fellow traveler, someone who brings the same emotions to the trip as the writer himself. It also adds a certain kind of information—not hard facts, but enjoyable lore.

下一段谈到了艰苦的工作——不能再拖延的工作。请注意这三个句子中包含了多少信息：

The following paragraph gets down to hard work—work that can’t be put off any longer. Notice how much information is crammed into these three sentences:

然而，失落已久的廷巴克图终于找到了，尽管在经历了可怕的磨难之后终于找到它的人——1826 年的苏格兰人戈登·莱恩和 1828 年的法国人勒内·凯利——一定感到他们的努力受到了残酷的嘲笑。16 世纪旅行家 Leo Africanus 所描述的拥有 100,000 人口的传奇城市——一个拥有 20,000 名学生和 180 所古兰经学校的学习中心——是一个荒凉的泥建筑聚居地，它的辉煌和人口早已不复存在，幸存下来只是因为它独特的位置是穿越撒哈拉沙漠的重要骆驼商队路线的交汇点。大部分在非洲交易的东西，尤其是北方的盐和南方的黄金，都是在廷巴克图交易的。

The long-lost Timbuktu, however, got found, though the men who finally found it after terrible ordeals—the Scotsman Gordon Laing in 1826 and the Frenchman René Caillié in 1828—must have felt cruelly mocked for their efforts. The legendary city of 100,000 people described by the 16th-century traveler Leo Africanus—a center of learning with 20,000 students and 180 Koranic schools—was a desolate settlement of mud buildings, its glory and its population long gone, surviving only because of its unique location as the junction of important camel caravan routes across the Sahara. Much of what got traded in Africa, especially salt from the north and gold from the south, got traded in Timbuktu.

廷巴克图的历史及其成名的原因就这么多了。这就是杂志读者需要了解这座城市的过去及其意义的全部内容。不要给杂志文章的读者提供比他们需要的更多的信息；如果您想了解更多，请写一本书或为学术期刊撰稿。

So much for the history of Timbuktu and the reason for its fame. It’s all that a magazine reader needs to know about the city’s past and its significance. Don’t give readers of a magazine piece more information than they require; if you want to tell more, write a book or write for a scholarly journal.

现在，您的读者接下来想知道什么？在每一句话之后问自己这个问题。他们想知道的是：我为什么要去廷巴克图？我此行的目的是什么？下面的段落是正确的——再次保持上一句的主线：

Now, what do your readers want to know next? Ask yourself that question after every sentence. Here what they want to know is: why did I go to Timbuktu? What was the purpose of my trip? The following paragraph gets right to it—again, keeping the thread of the previous sentence taut:

我来到廷巴克图是为了观看其中一辆大篷车的到来。我是六个足够聪明或足够愚蠢的男人和女人之一——我们还不知道是哪一个——报名参加我们在星期日纽约时报上宣布的为期两周的旅行，由法国的一家小型旅行社经营起源于西非。（廷巴克图在马里，前法属苏丹。） 该机构的办公室在纽约，我星期一早上第一件事就是去那里，以避开人群；我问了一些常见的问题，得到了一些常见的答案——黄热病疫苗、霍乱疫苗、疟疾药片、不要喝水——并得到了一本小册子。

It was to watch the arrival of one of those caravans that I had come to Timbuktu. I was one of six men and women bright enough or dumb enough—we didn’t yet know which—to sign up for a two-week tour we had seen announced in the Sunday New York Times, run by a small travel agency of French origins that specializes in West Africa. (Timbuktu is in Mali, the former French Sudan.) The agency’s office is in New York, and I had gone there first thing Monday morning to beat the crowd; I asked the usual questions and got the usual answers—yellow fever shots, cholera shots, malaria pills, don’t drink the water—and was given a brochure.

除了解释这次旅行的起源外，该段还做了另一项工作：它确立了作者的个性和声音。在旅行写作中，你永远不应该忘记你是向导。仅仅带你的读者去旅行是不够的；你必须带着它们去旅行。让他们认同你——认同你的希望和忧虑。这意味着让他们了解您是谁。“足够聪明或足够愚蠢”这句话让人想起旅游文学中一个熟悉的人物：游客可能是替罪羊或小丑。另一个一次性的短语是关于打败人群的台词。我放它只是为了自娱自乐。严格地说，第四段说廷巴克图在哪里为时已晚。但是如果不拆开线索的结构，我找不到更早提到它的方法。

Besides explaining the genesis of the trip, that paragraph does one other job: it establishes the writer’s personality and voice. In travel writing you should never forget that you are the guide. It’s not enough just to take your readers on a trip; you must take them on your trip. Make them identify with you—with your hopes and apprehensions. This means giving them some idea of who you are. The phrase “bright enough or dumb enough” calls up a familiar figure in travel literature: the tourist as a possible patsy or buffoon. Another throwaway phrase is the line about beating the crowd. I put it in just to amuse myself. Strictly, that fourth paragraph is too late to say where Timbuktu is. But I couldn’t find a way to mention it earlier without pulling apart the fabric of the lead.

这是第五段：

Here’s paragraph five:

“这是您参加千载难逢的盛会的机会——一年一度的 Azalai Salt Caravan 前往廷巴克图！” 小册子开始了。“想象一下：成百上千的骆驼背着大块珍贵的盐（内陆西非当地人称之为“白金”）凯旋进入廷巴克图，这是一座拥有约 7,000 名居民的古老而神秘的部分沙漠/部分城市。驾着大篷车的五颜六色的游牧民族已经穿越撒哈拉沙漠 1,000 英里，以户外盛宴和传统部落舞蹈来庆祝他们跋涉的结束。作为部落首领的客人在沙漠帐篷中过夜。”

“It’s your opportunity to participate in a once-in-a-lifetime extravaganza—the annual Azalai Salt Caravan to Timbuktu!” the brochure began. “Picture this: Hundreds of camels carrying huge slabs of precious salt (‘white gold’ to the natives of land-locked West Africa) make their triumphant entry into Timbuktu, an ancient and mystical part desert/part city of some 7,000 inhabitants. The colorful nomads who drive the caravans have traveled 1,000 miles across the Sahara to celebrate the end of their trek with outdoor feasts and traditional tribal dances. Spend the night in a desert tent as guest of the tribal chief.”

这是一个典型的例子，说明作家如何让其他人为他做有用的工作——用他们的话来说，通常比作家的话更能说明问题。在这种情况下，宣传册不仅告诉读者承诺了什么样的旅行；它的语言本身就是一种娱乐，也是了解发起人宏大的窗口。留意有趣或自私的引语，并怀着感激之情使用它们。这是导语的最后一段：

That’s a typical example of how a writer can get other people to do helpful work for him—in their words, which are usually more revealing than the writer’s words. In this case the brochure not only tells the reader what kind of trip has been promised; its language is an amusement in itself and a window into the grandiosity of the promoters. Be on the watch for funny or self-serving quotes and use them with gratitude. Here’s the last paragraph of the lead:

好吧，那是我的旅行，即使不一定是我的散文，结果也是我妻子的旅行和其他四个人的旅行。这些年来，我们从中年晚期到医疗保险。我们五个人来自曼哈顿中部，一个是马里兰州的寡妇，我们所有人都养成了去边缘地区旅行的终生习惯。像威尼斯和凡尔赛这样的名字并没有出现在我们早期旅行的记录中，甚至马拉喀什、卢克索或清迈也没有出现。他们谈论的是不丹和婆罗洲、西藏、也门和摩鹿加群岛。现在——赞美真主！——我们已经到达廷巴克图。我们的骆驼商队正要进来。

Well, that’s my kind of trip, if not necessarily my kind of prose, and it also turned out to be my wife’s kind of trip and four other people’s kind of trip. In years we ranged from late middle age to Medicare. Five of us were from mid-Manhattan, one was a widow from Maryland, and all of us had made a lifelong habit of traveling to places on the edge. Names like Venice and Versailles didn’t bob up in our accounts of earlier trips, or even Marrakech or Luxor or Chiang Mai. The talk was of Bhutan and Borneo, Tibet and Yemen and the Moluccas. Now—praise Allah!—we had made it to Timbuktu. Our camel caravan was about to come in.

领先优势到此结束。这六段的写作时间与文章的其余部分一样长。但当我最终将它们固定到位时，我感到自信满满。也许其他人可以为那个故事写出更好的线索，但我不能。我觉得和我在一起的读者会坚持到最后。

That concludes the lead. Those six paragraphs took as long to write as the entire remainder of the piece. But when I finally wrestled them into place I felt confidently launched. Maybe someone else could write a better lead for that story, but I couldn’t. I felt that readers who were still with me would stay to the end.

与关于结构的决定同样重要的是关于单个单词的决定。平庸是好作品的敌人。挑战在于不要像其他人一样写作。必须首先说明的一个事实是我们六个人的年龄。最初我写了一些有用的东西，比如“我们五六十岁”。但仅仅有用的是一种拖累。有没有什么办法可以新鲜的陈述事实？好像没有。最后，一位仁慈的缪斯给了我医疗保险——因此有了“从中年晚期到医疗保险”这句话。如果你看得足够久，你通常可以找到一个合适的名字或一个比喻，使那些枯燥但必要的事实栩栩如生。

No less important than decisions about structure are decisions about individual words. Banality is the enemy of good writing; the challenge is to not write like everybody else. One fact that had to be stated in the lead was how old the six of us were. Initially I wrote something serviceable like “we were in our fifties and sixties.” But the merely serviceable is a drag. Was there any way to state the fact with freshness? There didn’t seem to be. At last a merciful muse gave me Medicare—and thus the phrase “from late middle age to Medicare.” If you look long enough you can usually find a proper name or a metaphor that will bring those dull but necessary facts to life.

更多的时间花在了关于威尼斯和凡尔赛的句子上。最初我写道，“像伦敦和巴黎这样的名字并没有出现在我们之前旅行的记录中。” 那里没什么好玩的。我试图想到其他受欢迎的首都。罗马和开罗？雅典和曼谷？没有更好的。也许头韵会有所帮助——读者喜欢任何努力来满足他们的节奏感和节奏感。马德里和莫斯科？特拉维夫和东京？太棘手了。我不再去想首都，而是试着去想旅游者密集的城市。威尼斯突然出现在我的脑海中，我很高兴看到它；每个人都去威尼斯。还有其他城市以V开头吗？只有维也纳，它在几个方面与威尼斯太近了。最后，我将我的想法从旅游城市转移到旅游景点，精神上从主要首都散开，而正是在其中一次短途旅行中，我到达了凡尔赛宫。这让我很高兴。

Even more time went into the sentence about Venice and Versailles. Originally I wrote, “Names like London and Paris didn’t turn up in our accounts of earlier trips.” Not much fun there. I tried to think of other popular capitals. Rome and Cairo? Athens and Bangkok? No better. Maybe alliteration would help—readers enjoy any effort to gratify their sense of rhythm and cadence. Madrid and Moscow? Tel Aviv and Tokyo? Too tricky. I stopped thinking of capitals and tried to think of tourist-infested cities. Venice popped into my head and I was glad to see it; everybody goes to Venice. Did any other cities begin with V? Only Vienna, which was too close to Venice in several respects. Finally I shifted my thinking from tourist cities to tourist sites, mentally fanning out from the major capitals, and it was on one of those excursions that I hit Versailles. It made my day.

接下来我需要一个比“出现”更新鲜的动词。我想要一个传达图像的主动动词。通常的同义词没有一个是完全正确的。最后我想到了“bob”——一个三个字母的单词，简单得可笑。然而，这是一个完美的词：它描绘了一个物体周期性地浮出水面的画面。这只剩下一个决定：对于六位报名参加廷巴克图的旅行者来说，哪些略显另类的旅游景点似乎司空见惯？我最终选择的三个城市——卢克索、马拉喀什和清迈——在 1950 年代，当我第一次访问它们时，它们非常具有异国情调。今天他们不是；喷气式飞机旅行的时代使它们几乎与伦敦和巴黎一样受欢迎。

Next I needed a fresher verb than “turn up.” I wanted an active verb that conveyed an image. None of the usual synonyms was quite right. Finally I thought of “bob”—a three-letter word, ludicrously simple. Yet it was the perfect word: it paints a picture of an object periodically rising to the surface of the water. That left just one decision: what slightly offbeat tourist sites would seem commonplace to six travelers who had signed up for Timbuktu? The three that I finally chose—Luxor, Marrakech and Chiang Mai—were quite exotic in the 1950s, when I first visited them. Today they’re not; the age of jet travel has made them almost as popular as London and Paris.

总共，这句话花了将近一个小时。但我一点也不吝啬。相反，看到它落到实处让我非常高兴。没有任何写作决定太小而不值得花费大量时间。当你的挑剔劳动得到正确句子的回报时，你和读者都知道这一点。

Altogether, the sentence took almost an hour. But I didn’t begrudge a minute of it. On the contrary, seeing it fall into place gave me great pleasure. No writing decision is too small to be worth a large expenditure of time. Both you and the reader know it when your finicky labor is rewarded by a sentence coming out right.

请注意，引导末尾有一个星号。（它也可以是一个空格。）那个星号是一个路标。它向读者宣布您已经以某种方式组织了您的文章，并且新的阶段即将开始——也许是时间顺序的变化，例如倒叙，或者主题、重点或语气的变化。在这里，在高度压缩的引导之后，星号使作者能够深呼吸并重新开始，这次是以讲故事的人更悠闲的步态：

Notice that there’s an asterisk at the end of the lead. (It could also be a blank space.) That asterisk is a signpost. It announces to the reader that you have organized your article in a certain way and that a new phase is about to begin—perhaps a change of chronology, such as a flashback, or a change of subject, or emphasis, or tone. Here, after a highly compressed lead, the asterisk enables the writer to take a deep breath and start over, this time at the more leisurely gait of a storyteller:

我们从纽约飞往科特迪瓦首都阿比让，然后从那里乘飞机前往北部邻国马里首都巴马科，从而抵达通布图。与青翠欲滴的象牙海岸不同，马里干燥，南半部主要由尼日尔河滋养，上半部是纯沙漠；廷巴克图实际上是穿越撒哈拉沙漠北上的旅行者的最后一站，或者是南下旅行者的第一站——在经历了数周的炎热和干渴之后，地平线上令人垂涎的斑点。

We got to Timbuktu by flying from New York to Abidjan, capital of the Ivory Coast, and taking a plane from there to Bamako, capital of Mali, its neighbor to the north. Unlike the verdant Ivory Coast, Mali is dry, its southern half nourished mainly by the Niger River, its upper half pure desert; Timbuktu is literally the last stop for travelers going north across the Sahara, or the first stop for travelers coming south—a coveted speck on the horizon after weeks of heat and thirst.

旅行中的我们都不太了解马里或对马里有什么期望——我们的注意力集中在我们在廷巴克图与盐商会合的地方，而不是我们要穿越到那里的国家。我们没想到的是，我们会立即被它吸引。马里沉浸在色彩之中：英俊的人们穿着令人陶醉的设计面料，市场上摆满了水果和蔬菜，孩子们的笑容是常有的奇迹。马里极度贫穷，但人却很富有。绿树成荫的巴马科市以其活力和自信令我们欣喜若狂。

None of us on the tour knew much about Mali or what to expect of it—our thoughts were fixed on our rendezvous with the salt caravan at Timbuktu, not on the country we would cross to get there. What we didn’t expect was that we would be so instantly taken with it. Mali was an immersion in color: handsome people wearing fabrics of intoxicating design, markets bright with fruits and vegetables, children whose smile was a routine miracle. Desperately poor, Mali was people-rich. The tree-lined city of Bamako delighted us with its energy and confidence.

第二天一早起来，我们在一辆面包车里开了十个小时，这辆面包车的日子过得更好，但也好不了多少，到达圣城杰内，尼日尔的中世纪贸易和伊斯兰学术中心，它早于廷巴克图并与尼日尔相媲美它有光泽。今天杰内只能乘小渡轮到达，当我们在难以形容的道路上蹦蹦跳跳，赶在天黑前赶到时，其伟大的粘土清真寺的尖顶和塔楼看起来像一座遥远的沙堡，似乎在后退，嘲笑着我们。当我们终于到达那里时，清真寺看起来仍然像一座沙堡——一座优雅的堡垒，可能是由孩子们在海滩上建造的。在建筑上（我后来才知道）它是苏丹风格的；这些年来，海滩上的孩子们一直在建造苏丹风格的建筑。黄昏时分在杰内的古老广场逗留是我们旅行的高潮时刻。

Up early the next morning, we drove for ten hours in a van that had seen better days, but not much better days, to reach the holy city of Djenné, a medieval center of trade and Islamic scholarship on the Niger that predated Timbuktu and rivaled it in luster. Today Djenné can only be reached by a small ferry, and as we bounced over unspeakable roads, hurrying to arrive before dark, the spires and turrets of its great clay mosque, looking like a distant sandcastle, taunted us by seeming to recede. When we finally got there the mosque still looked like a sandcastle—an elegant fortress that might have been built by children on a beach. Architecturally (I later learned) it was in the Sudanese style; all these years, children on beaches have been building in the Sudanese style. To linger in Djenné’s ancient square at dusk was a high moment of our trip.

接下来的两天同样丰富。其中一个是开车进出多贡国家。多贡人生活在外人不易到达的悬崖上，人类学家因其万物有灵论文化和宇宙观而受到艺术收藏家的珍视，因其面具和雕像而受到艺术收藏家的珍视，我们花几个小时在他们的村庄周围攀爬并观看假面舞会让我们对一个远非简单的社会有了过于简短的一瞥。第二天是在莫普特度过的，这是尼日尔河上一个充满活力的集镇，我们非常喜欢它，但也离开得太早了。但我们在廷巴克图有个约会，还有一架包机带我们去那里。

The next two days were no less rich. One was spent driving into—and back out of—Dogon country. The Dogon, who live on an escarpment not easily reached by outsiders, are prized by anthropologists for their animist culture and cosmology and by art collectors for their masks and statues, and the few hours that we spent climbing around their villages and watching a masked dance gave us too brief a glimpse of a society that was far from simple. The second day was spent in Mopte, a vibrant market town on the Niger that we liked enormously and also left too soon. But we had a date in Timbuktu and a chartered plane to take us there.

显然，关于马里，要说的远比塞进这四段中的要多得多——许多关于多贡文化和尼日尔河民族的学术著作都有。但这不是一篇关于马里的文章；这是关于寻找骆驼商队。因此，必须决定这件作品的较大形状。我的决定是尽快穿越马里——用最少的句子解释我们走了什么路线，以及我们停靠的地方有什么重要意义。

Obviously there’s far more to say about Mali than is jammed into those four paragraphs—many scholarly books have been written about the Dogon culture and the Niger River peoples. But this wasn’t an article about Mali; it was about a quest for a camel caravan. Therefore a decision had to be made about the larger shape of the piece. My decision was to get across Mali as fast as possible—to explain in the barest number of sentences what route we took and what was important about the places where we stopped.

在这种时候，我会问自己一个非常有用的问题：“这件作品到底是关于什么的？” （不仅仅是“这篇文章讲的是什么？”）如果您选择讲述的故事不是核心内容，那么您费尽心思收集的材料的喜爱并不足以成为将其包含在内的充分理由。需要近乎受虐狂的自律。丢失这么多材料的唯一安慰是它并没有完全丢失。它作为读者可以感觉到的无形资产保留在您的作品中。读者应该总是觉得你对你的主题的了解比你写的要多。

At such moments I ask myself one very helpful question: “What is the piece really about?” (Not just “What is the piece about?”) Fondness for material you’ve gone to a lot of trouble to gather isn’t a good enough reason to include it if it’s not central to the story you’ve chosen to tell. Self-discipline bordering on masochism is required. The only consolation for the loss of so much material is that it isn’t totally lost; it remains in your writing as an intangible that the reader can sense. Readers should always feel that you know more about your subject than you’ve put in writing.

回到“但我们在廷巴克图有个约会”：

Back to “But we had a date in Timbuktu”:

那个日期的准确性是我访问旅行社时最担心的。我问该机构的负责人，她怎么能确定盐商队会在 12 月 2 日到达？游牧民族牵着骆驼并不是我对按时间表行事的人的看法。我的妻子并没有因为我对骆驼和旅行社等生命力的乐观态度而受到诅咒，她确信我们在廷巴克图会被告知盐商队来了又走了，或者更有可能的是，我们没有听到任何消息全部。旅行社对我的问题嗤之以鼻。

The exactness of that date was what had worried me most when I visited the travel agency. I asked the head of the agency how she could be so sure the salt caravan would arrive on December 2; nomads leading camels aren’t my idea of people operating on a timetable. My wife, who isn’t cursed with my optimism about such life forces as camels and travel agents, was certain we would be told at Timbuktu that the salt caravan had come and gone, or, more probably, hadn’t been heard from at all. The travel agent scoffed at my question.

“我们与大篷车保持着密切联系，”她说。“我们派侦察兵进入沙漠。如果他们告诉我们大篷车要晚几天，我们就可以调整你在马里的行程。” 这对我来说是有道理的——乐观主义者可以理解任何事情——现在我乘坐的飞机比林德伯格的飞机大不了多少，向北飞向廷巴克图，地势非常贫瘠，我看不到下面有人居住的迹象。然而，与此同时，数百只骆驼背着巨大的盐块向南移动来迎接我。即使是现在，部落首领也在考虑如何在他们的沙漠帐篷里招待我。

“We’re in close touch with the caravan,” she said. “We send scouts into the desert. If they tell us the caravan is going to be a few days late we can juggle your itinerary in Mali.” That made sense to me—optimists can make sense of anything—and now I was in a plane not much bigger than Lindbergh’s, flying north toward Timbuktu over terrain so barren that I saw no sign of human habitation below. Simultaneously, however, hundreds of camels carrying huge slabs of salt were moving south to meet me. Even now tribal chiefs were turning their thoughts to how to entertain me in their desert tent.

前面两段都带有幽默感——小笑话。同样，他们努力让自己开心。但它们也是一种故意维持角色的尝试。旅行写作和幽默写作中最古老的风格之一是叙述者的永恒轻信。适度使用，让自己容易上当受骗——或者彻头彻尾的愚蠢——会给读者带来优越感的巨大乐趣。

Both of the preceding paragraphs contain touches of humor—tiny jokes. Again, they are efforts to keep myself amused. But they are also a deliberate attempt to maintain a persona. One of the oldest strains in travel writing and humor writing is the eternal credulity of the narrator. Used in moderation, making yourself gullible—or downright stupid—gives the reader the enormous pleasure of feeling superior.

我们的飞行员在廷巴克图上空盘旋，让我们鸟瞰这座我们远道而来的城市。那是一大片杂乱无章的泥土建筑，看上去废弃已久，就像Beau Geste尽头的 Zinderneuf 堡一样死寂。肯定没有人还活着。撒哈拉沙漠不断侵蚀，在非洲中部形成了被称为萨赫勒的干旱带，它早已推过廷巴克图并使其陷入困境。我感到一阵恐惧。我不想在这样一个被遗弃的地方被放下。

Our pilot circled over Timbuktu to give us an aerial view of the city we had traveled so far to see. It was a large sprawl of mud buildings that looked long abandoned, as dead as Fort Zinderneuf at the end of Beau Geste; surely nobody was alive down there. The Sahara in its steady encroachment, which has created the drought belt across central Africa known as the Sahel, had long since pushed past Timbuktu and left it marooned. I felt a tremor of fear; I didn’t want to be put down in such a forsaken place.

提及Beau Geste是为了挖掘读者对故事的联想。使廷巴克图成为传奇的很多东西都是由好莱坞放在那里的。通过援引津德新堡的命运——布赖恩·唐利维扮演了一个虐待狂的法国外籍军团指挥官，他将士兵的尸体撑回了堡垒的壁龛——我正在揭示我自己对这种类型的喜爱，并与其他电影建立联系爱好者。我追求的是共鸣；它可以完成许多作家无法独自完成的情感工作。

The reference to Beau Geste is an effort to tap into associations that readers bring to the story. Much of what makes Timbuktu legendary was put there by Hollywood. By invoking the fate of Fort Zinderneuf—Brian Donlevy played a sadistic French Foreign Legion commandant who propped the dead bodies of his soldiers back into the niches of the fort—I’m revealing my own fondness for the genre and striking a bond with fellow movie buffs. What I’m after is resonance; it can do a great deal of emotional work that writers can’t achieve on their own.

两个词——“震颤”和“遗弃”——花了一段时间才找到。当我在我的 Roget 词库中找到“forsaken”时，我非常确定我以前从未使用过它。我很高兴在同义词中看到它。作为耶稣的遗言之一（谈到共鸣），它几乎无法传达出更多的孤独和遗弃。

Two words—“tremor” and “forsaken”—took a while to find. When I found “forsaken” in my Roget’s Thesaurus I was quite sure I had never used it before. I was glad to see it there among the synonyms. As one of Jesus’s last words (speaking of resonance), it could hardly convey more loneliness and abandonment.

在机场迎接我们的是当地向导，一位名叫穆罕默德·阿里的图阿雷格人。对于旅行爱好者来说，他是一个令人欣慰的景象——如果说有人可以说拥有撒哈拉沙漠的这一部分，那就是图阿雷格人，这是一群自豪的柏柏尔人，他们不会向阿拉伯人或后来席卷北方的法国殖民者屈服非洲，而是撤退到沙漠中，并将其作为自己的保护区。穆罕默德·阿里 (Mohammed Ali) 身着图阿雷格人传统的蓝色长袍，有一张黝黑而聪明的脸，五官的棱角有点阿拉伯风格，他一动不动，自信满满，这显然是他性格的一部分。事实证明，他在十几岁的时候就和父亲一起去朝圣了到麦加（许多图阿雷格人最终皈依了伊斯兰教），并在阿拉伯和埃及呆了七年，学习英语、法语和阿拉伯语。图阿雷格人有自己的语言，有复杂的书写字母表，称为 Tamashek。

At the airport we were met by our local guide, a Tuareg named Mohammed Ali. For a travel buff he was a consoling sight—if anybody can be said to own this part of the Sahara, it is the Tuareg, a race of proud Berbers who wouldn’t submit to the Arabs or the later French colonials who swept into North Africa, withdrawing instead into the desert and making it their preserve. Mohammed Ali, who was wearing the traditional blue robe of Tuareg men, had a dark, intelligent face, somewhat Arabic in the angularity of its features, and he moved with an assurance that was obviously part of his character. As a teen-ager, it turned out, he had gone with his father on the haj to Mecca (many Tuareg eventually converted to Islam) and had stayed for seven years in Arabia and Egypt to study English, French and Arabic. The Tuareg have a language of their own, with a complex written alphabet, called Tamashek.

穆罕默德阿里说他必须先带我们去廷巴克图的警察局检查我们的护照。我看过太多的电影，在这种采访场景中感觉不舒服，当我们坐在一个地牢般的房间里接受两名武装警察的审问时，在离监狱牢房不远的地方我们可以看到一个男人和一个男孩在睡觉, 我有另一个倒叙——这个倒叙是《四根羽毛》和长期被关押在恩图曼的英国士兵的场景。当我们回来时，压迫感一直伴随着我，穆罕默德·阿里带我们穿过这座荒凉的城市，尽职尽责地向我们展示了它的几个“兴趣点”：大清真寺、市场和三座破旧的房子，用牌匾纪念，莱恩， Caillié 和德国探险家海因里希·巴特 (Heinrich Barth) 居住在这里。我们没有看到任何其他游客。

Mohammed Ali said he had to take us first to the police station in Timbuktu to have our passports checked. I’ve seen too many movies to feel comfortable in this kind of interview situation, and as we sat in a dungeon-like room being interrogated by two armed policemen, not far from a jail cell where we could see a man and a boy sleeping, I had another flashback—this one to The Four Feathers and the scene of the British soldiers long imprisoned at Omdurman. The oppressiveness stayed with me when we got back out and Mohammed Ali walked us through the forlorn city, dutifully showing us its few “points of interest”: the Grand Mosque, the market, and three dilapidated houses, commemorated by plaques, where Laing, Caillié and the German explorer Heinrich Barth lived. We didn’t see any other tourists.

同样，四根羽毛的典故，就像提到Beau Geste一样，会给任何了解这部电影的人带来一种认可的寒意。这部电影取材于一场真实的战役——基钦纳为报复马赫迪击败戈登将军而远征尼罗河——这一事实让这句话充满了恐惧。显然，撒哈拉沙漠边陲的阿拉伯司法仍远非仁慈。

Again, the Four Feathers allusion, like the mention of Beau Geste, will bring a chill of recognition to anyone who knows the movie. The fact that the movie was based on a real campaign—Kitchener’s expedition up the Nile to avenge the Mahdi’s defeat of General Gordon—gives the sentence an edge of fear. Obviously Arab justice in outposts of the Sahara is still far from merciful.

星号再一次宣告情绪的变化。它实际上是在说：“廷巴克图本身就到此为止。现在我们要进入故事的正题：寻找骆驼商队。” 在一篇冗长而复杂的文章中进行这些划分不仅有助于读者遵循您的路线图。它还消除了写作过程中的一些焦虑，使您能够将材料分解成可管理的块，并且一次取一个块。总的任务似乎不那么艰巨，并且避免了恐慌。

Once more the asterisk announces a change of mood. It says, in effect: “So much for Timbuktu itself. Now we’re going to get down to the real business of the story: looking for a camel caravan.” Making these divisions in a long and complex article not only helps the reader to follow your road map. It also takes some of the anxiety out of the act of writing, enabling you to break your material into manageable chunks and to take one chunk at a time. The total task seems less formidable, and panic is staved off.

在 Azalai 酒店，我们似乎是唯一的客人，我们问穆罕默德·阿里，有多少游客在廷巴克图迎接盐商队。

At the Azalai Hotel, where we appeared to be the only guests, we asked Mohammed Ali how many tourists were in Timbuktu to greet the salt caravan.

“六，”他说。“你们六个。”

“Six,” he said. “The six of you.”

“但是……”我心里有什么不想把这句话说完。我采取了不同的方法。“我不明白‘Azalai’这个词是什么意思。为什么叫阿扎莱盐商队？”

“But …” Something in me didn’t want to finish the sentence. I took a different approach. “I don’t understand what this word ‘Azalai’ means. Why is it called the Azalai Salt Caravan?”

“这是法国人使用的词，”他说，“当他们组织大篷车并且所有骆驼每年一起旅行一次时，大约在 12 月初。”

“That’s the word the French used,” he said, “when they organized the caravan and all the camels made the trip together once a year, around the beginning of December.”

“他们现在做什么？” 几个声音问道。

“What do they do now?” several voices asked.

“好吧，当马里获得独立时，他们决定让商人随时将他们的盐商队带到廷巴克图。”

“Well, when Mali got its independence they decided to let the traders bring their salt caravans to Timbuktu whenever they wanted to.”

马里于 1960 年获得独立。我们在廷巴克图参加了 27 年未举办的活动。

Mali got its independence in 1960. We were in Timbuktu for an event that hadn’t been held in 27 years.

最后一句话是在故事中投下的一颗小炸弹。但它可以自己说话——请只说事实——不加评论。我没有添加感叹号来通知读者这是一个了不起的时刻。那会破坏他们自己发现的乐趣。相信你的材料。

The last sentence is a small bomb dropped into the story. But it is allowed to speak for itself—just the facts, please—without comment. I didn’t add an exclamation point to notify readers that it was an amazing moment. That would have spoiled their own pleasure of discovery. Trust your material.

我的妻子和其他人并不感到惊讶。我们冷静地接受了这个消息：老手相信他们会以某种方式找到他们的骆驼商队。主要是我们的反应是惊讶于广告中的真实准则被如此厚颜无耻地忽视。穆罕默德·阿里 (Mohammed Ali) 对小册子中提出的华而不实的承诺一无所知。他只知道他被雇来带我们去见一个盐商队，他告诉我们早上我们会去寻找一个，然后在撒哈拉沙漠过夜。他说，12 月初通常是大篷车开始抵达的时间。关于酋长的帐篷，他只字未提。

My wife, among others, was not surprised. We took the news calmly: old travel hands who have faith that they will find their camel caravan one way or another. Mainly our reaction was one of amazement that the canons of truth-in-advertising had been so brazenly disregarded. Mohammed Ali knew nothing about the gaudy promises tendered by the brochure. He only knew he had been hired to take us to meet a salt caravan, and he told us that in the morning we would go looking for one and would spend the night in the Sahara. Early December, he said, was the usual time for caravans to start arriving. He didn’t say anything about a chieftain’s tent.

更精心挑选的词：“canons”、“brazardly”、“华而不实”、“tendered”。它们生动而精确，但既不长也不花哨。最重要的是，它们是读者可能没有预料到的词，因此他们很欢迎。关于酋长帐篷的句子，引用了宣传册上的一句话，又是一个小笑话。段落末尾的这些“快照”会促使读者阅读下一段，并让他们心情愉快。

More carefully chosen words: “canons,” “brazenly,” “gaudy,” “tendered.” They’re vivid and precise, but not long or fancy. Best of all, they are words that readers probably weren’t expecting and that they therefore welcome. The sentence about the chieftain’s tent, referring back to a phrase in the brochure, is another tiny joke. These “snappers” at the end of a paragraph propel readers into the next paragraph and keep them in a good mood.

早上，我的妻子——一个处于无限边缘的理智的声音——说除非我们乘坐两辆车，否则她不会进入撒哈拉沙漠。因此，我很高兴看到两辆路虎在酒店外等着我们。其中一个正在让一个男孩用自行车打气筒给它的前轮胎打气。我们四个人挤进了一辆路虎的后座；穆罕默德·阿里坐在前面，紧挨着司机。第二辆路虎载着我们另外两名旅行团成员和两个被称为“学徒”的男孩。没有人说他们学徒的目的。

In the morning my wife—a voice of reason at the edge of infinity—said she wouldn’t go into the Sahara unless we went in two vehicles. I was therefore glad to see two Land Rovers awaiting us outside the hotel. One of them was having its front tire pumped up by a boy with a bicycle pump. Four of us squeezed into the back seat of one Land Rover; Mohammed Ali sat in front, next to the driver. The second Land Rover took our other two tour members and two boys who were described as “apprentices.” Nobody said what they were apprenticing for.

另一个无需修饰的惊人事实——轮胎充气——以及最后的另一个小笑话。

Another startling fact that needs no embellishment—the tire-pumping—and another small joke at the end.

我们直接开进了撒哈拉沙漠。沙漠是一张棕色的毯子，没有尽头，也没有任何痕迹。下一个大城市是阿尔及尔。那是我感到最边缘的时刻，一个小声音说：“这太疯狂了。你为什么做这个？” 但我知道为什么；我正在寻找一个可以追溯到我第一次接触英国“沙漠怪人”的书——这些孤独者如查尔斯·道蒂、理查德·伯顿爵士、TE 劳伦斯和威尔弗雷德·塞西格，他们住在贝都因人中间。我一直想知道那种简朴的生活是什么样的。它对那些痴迷的英国人有什么影响？

We drove straight out into the Sahara. The desert was a brown blanket without any end and with no tracks of any kind; the next big town was Algiers. That was the moment when I felt most at the edge, when a small voice said, “This is crazy. Why are you doing this?” But I knew why; I was on a quest that I could trace back to my first encounters with the books by Britain’s “desert eccentrics”—solitaries such as Charles Doughty, Sir Richard Burton, T. E. Lawrence and Wilfred Thesiger, who lived among the Bedouin. I had always wondered what that austere existence was like. What was its hold over those obsessed Englishmen?

更多的共鸣。提到 Doughty 和他的同胞们提醒我们，沙漠的书面文学不亚于电影文学。它为我背负的情感包袱又增加了一项，读者有权知道。

More resonance. The reference to Doughty and his compatriots is a reminder that the desert has a written literature no less powerful than its movie literature. It adds one more item to the emotional baggage that I was carrying and that the reader was entitled to know about.

以下句子追问上一段结尾的问题：

The following sentence pursues the question that ended the previous paragraph:

现在我开始发现了。当我们驶过沙滩时，穆罕默德·阿里偶尔给司机做了个手势：向右多一点，向左多一点。我们问他怎么知道他要去哪里。他说他可以根据沙丘判断。然而，沙丘看起来都很相似。我们问我们要开车多久才能找到盐商队。穆罕默德·阿里说他希望不会超过三四个小时。我们继续开车。在我面向对象的眼中，几乎没有什么可看的。但过了一会儿，几乎虚无本身变成了一个物体——沙漠的整个点。我试图让这个事实进入我的新陈代谢。它让我陷入某种接受，我完全忘记了我们为什么在那里。

Now I was starting to find out. As we drove over the sand, Mohammed Ali gave the driver an occasional gesture: a little more to the right, a little more to the left. We asked how he knew where he was going. He said he could tell by the dunes. The dunes, however, all looked alike. We asked how long we would have to drive to find a salt caravan. Mohammed Ali said he hoped it wouldn’t be more than three or four hours. We kept driving. To my object-oriented eye there was almost nothing to see. But after a while the almost-nothingness became an object in itself—the entire point of the desert. I tried to get that fact into my metabolism. It lulled me into a certain acceptance and I totally forgot why we were out there.

突然，司机向左急转，停了下来。“骆驼，”他说。我睁大了都市人的眼睛，什么也没看到。然后它在远处成为焦点：一支由 40 头骆驼组成的商队正以庄严的步态朝廷巴克图进发，一千年来骆驼商队一直这样做，从距北方 20 天的 Taoudenni 的矿山运来盐。我们驱车来到距离大篷车一百码以内——不能更近，穆罕默德·阿里解释说，因为骆驼是神经质的动物，很容易被任何“陌生”的事物惊慌失措。（不可否认，我们很奇怪。）他说，骆驼总是在深夜被带到廷巴克图卸下盐，当时这个城市空无一人。“胜利进入”​​到此为止。

Suddenly the driver made a sharp left and came to a stop. “Camels,” he said. I strained my urban eyes and didn’t see anything. Then it came into focus, far away: a caravan of forty camels moving at a stately gait toward Timbuktu, as camel caravans have for a thousand years, bringing salt from the mines at Taoudenni, twenty days to the north. We drove to within a hundred yards of the caravan—no nearer, Mohammed Ali explained, because camels are nervous creatures, easily panicked by anything “strange.” (We were undeniably strange.) He said that the camels are always brought into Timbuktu to unload the salt late at night, when the city is empty of people. So much for the “triumphant entry.”

这是一个激动人心的景象，比有组织的游行更具戏剧性。大篷车的孤独是每一个曾经穿越撒哈拉沙漠的大篷车的孤独。骆驼相互拴在一起，步履一致，节奏起伏，就像火箭女郎一样精准。每只骆驼的每一侧都有两块盐。盐看起来像肮脏的白色大理石。这些石板（我随后在 Timbuktu 市场测量）长 3.5 英尺，高 1.5 英尺，厚 3/4 英寸——大概是骆驼可以装载的最大尺寸和重量。我们坐在沙滩上，看着商队，直到最后一头骆驼消失在沙丘上。

It was a thrilling sight, far more dramatic than an organized march would have been. The aloneness of the caravan was the aloneness of every caravan that had ever crossed the Sahara. The camels were hitched to each other and seemed to be walking in unison, as precise as Rockettes in their undulating rhythm. Each camel had two slabs of salt roped to each side. The salt looked like dirty white marble. The slabs (which I subsequently measured in the Timbuktu market) are 3½ feet long, 1½ feet high, and ¾ inch thick—the maximum size and weight, presumably, that can be loaded onto a camel. We sat on the sand and watched the caravan until the last camel disappeared over a dune.

语气现在变成了直截了当的叙述——一个接一个的陈述句。唯一艰难的决定涉及“孤独”，这不是我喜欢的词——它太“诗意”了。但我最终决定没有其他词可以完成同样的工作，我不情愿地保留了它。

The tone has now settled into straight narrative—one declarative sentence after another. The only hard decision involved “aloneness,” which is not my kind of word—it’s too “poetic.” But I finally decided that there was no other word that could do the same job, and I reluctantly stayed with it.

此时已是中午，太阳火辣辣的。我们爬回我们的路虎车，继续开进沙漠，直到穆罕默德·阿里发现一棵树的影子刚好可以容纳五个纽约人和一个马里兰州的寡妇，我们在那里一直待到大约 4 点，享用野餐午餐，凝视当我们的影子随着太阳移动时，在褪色的风景中打瞌睡，不时地移动我们的毯子。整个午睡时间，两位司机都在修理并似乎要拆掉其中一辆路虎的引擎。一个游牧民族不知从哪里冒出来，停下来问我们有没有奎宁。另一个游牧民不知从哪里冒出来，短暂地停下来说话。后来我们看到两个人穿过沙漠向我们走来，并越过他们……这是我们的第一个海市蜃楼吗？那是另一辆盐商队，五十骆驼长，映衬在天空中。天知道离我们多远，两人已经离开商队过来拜访了。其中一位是一位老者，满脸笑意。他们与穆罕默德·阿里坐下来了解廷巴克图的最新消息。

By now it was midday and the sun was fiercely hot. We climbed back into our Land Rovers and drove farther into the desert until Mohammed Ali found a tree that cast a shadow just big enough for five New Yorkers and a widow from Maryland, and there we stayed until about 4, having a picnic lunch, gazing at the bleached-out landscape, dozing, moving our blanket periodically as our shadow moved with the sun. The two drivers spent the entire siesta tinkering with and seeming to dismantle the engine of one of the Land Rovers. A nomad appeared from nowhere and stopped to ask if we had any quinine. Another nomad appeared from nowhere and stopped briefly to talk. Later we saw two men walking toward us across the desert and beyond them … was it our first mirage? It was another salt caravan, this one fifty camels long, silhouetted against the sky. Spotting us from God knows how far away, the two men had left the caravan to come over for a visit. One of them was an old man, full of laughter. They sat down with Mohammed Ali and got the latest news of Timbuktu.

最严厉的句子是关于司机修补路虎的句子。我希望它像所有其他句子一样简单，但其中隐藏着一个小惊喜——一丝讽刺的幽默。否则我此时的目的是尽可能简单地讲述故事的其余部分：

The hardest sentence there was the one about the drivers tinkering with the Land Rover. I wanted it to be as simple as all the other sentences and yet have a small surprise tucked into it—a wry touch of humor. Otherwise my purpose at this point was to tell the remainder of the story as simply as possible:

所以四个小时过去了，我们才知道他们走了，就好像我们已经滑进了一个不同的时区，撒哈拉沙漠时间，在下午晚些时候，当太阳的热量开始退去时，我们回到了我们的路虎车，令我惊讶的是，他仍然在工作，并开始穿越撒哈拉沙漠，前往穆罕默德·阿里所说的我们的“营地”。我想象着，如果不是酋长的帐篷，至少是一个帐篷——一种宣称自己是营地的东西。当我们终于停下来时，它停在了一个看起来与我们一整天开车经过的地方惊人相似的地方。然而，它确实有一棵小树。一些贝都因妇女蹲在它下面——身穿黑衣，脸上蒙着面纱——穆罕默德·阿里把我们放在她们旁边的沙漠上。

So the four hours passed before we knew they were gone, as if we had slipped into a different time zone, Sahara time, and in the late afternoon, when the sun’s heat had begun to ebb, we got back into our Land Rovers, which, to my surprise, still worked, and set out across the Sahara for what Mohammed Ali called our “encampment.” I pictured, if not a chieftain’s tent, at least a tent—something that announced itself as an encampment. When we finally did stop, it was at a spot that looked strikingly similar to what we had been driving over all day. It did, however, have one small tree. Some Bedouin women were crouched under it—black-garbed figures, their faces veiled—and Mohammed Ali put us down on the desert next to them.

女人们一看到我们就退缩了——白人外星人突然倒在了她们中间。它们紧紧地挤在一起，看起来就像一道饰带。显然，穆罕默德·阿里 (Mohammed Ali) 只是在第一眼看到他偶然为他的游客找到的“地方色彩”时就停下来，指望我们在那之后自己管理。我们只能坐下来，装出一副友好的样子。但我们非常清楚自己是入侵者，我们可能看起来和我们感觉的一样不舒服。我们在那里坐了一会儿，黑色的楣板才慢慢散开，变成四个女人、三个孩子和两个赤裸的婴儿。穆罕默德·阿里去了某个地方，似乎不想与贝都因人有任何关系；也许作为图阿雷格人，他认为他们是沙漠里的痞子。

The women shrank back at the sight of us—white aliens dumped abruptly in their midst. They were huddled so close together that they looked like a frieze. Obviously Mohammed Ali had just stopped at the first sight of “local color” that he happened to find for his tourists, counting on us to manage for ourselves after that. We could only sit and try to look friendly. But we were very conscious of being intruders, and we probably looked as uncomfortable as we felt.
